Meaning (Hindi): हे पार्थ! जब मनुष्य मन में उत्पन्न होने वाली समस्त इच्छाओं को त्याग देता है और आत्मा में ही आत्मा द्वारा संतुष्ट रहता है, तभी वह स्थितप्रज्ञ (स्थिर बुद्धि वाला) कहा जाता है।

Meaning (English): O Partha, when a man completely casts off all the desires of the mind, and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then he is said to be of steady wisdom (sthita-prajna).

This verse is the beginning of Lord Krishna's description of a "Sthita-prajna" — a person of steady wisdom, equanimity, and spiritual realization.

"Prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha manogatān" A person who has given up all desires that arise in the mind. These are not just physical cravings, but also subtle mental desires — for recognition, control, pleasure, etc. It doesn't mean repression, but transcendence — desires lose their hold on him.

"Ātmani eva ātmanā tuṣṭaḥ" He is satisfied in the Self, by the Self. He no longer looks outside for happiness — neither in objects, people, nor achievements. He finds contentment in his true inner being, which is unchanging, eternal, and divine.

"Sthita-prajñaḥ tadā ucyate" Such a person is called sthita-prajna — one whose intellect is firm and steady. They are not shaken by joy or sorrow, gain or loss, success or failure. This state is a result of spiritual maturity and inner detachment.

श्लोक 2.56

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमना: सुखेषु विगतस्पृह: ।
वीतरागभयक्रोध: स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते ॥५६॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो पुरुष दुःखों में विचलित नहीं होता, सुखों में जिसकी इच्छा समाप्त हो चुकी है, जो राग, भय और क्रोध से रहित है - ऐसा स्थितप्रज्ञ (स्थिर बुद्धिवाला) मुनि कहा जाता है।

Meaning (English): He whose mind remains undisturbed amidst sorrows, who does not crave pleasures, and who is free from attachment, fear, and anger — such a sage is said to be of steady wisdom (sthitaprajna).

This verse is part of Lord Krishna's explanation of the qualities of a Sthitaprajna — one whose wisdom is steady and unwavering. Here's the breakdown:

1. Undisturbed in Sorrows (duḥkheṣhu anudvigna-manāḥ): A person of stable wisdom does not get emotionally disturbed by pain or grief. Life naturally brings suffering (loss, failure, sickness), but the wise learn to accept it without losing inner peace.

2. Free from Craving Pleasures (sukheṣu vigata-spṛihaḥ): The wise do not become greedy or overly attached to pleasures. They enjoy what comes their way but don't seek happiness solely in external things.

3. Free from Attachment, Fear, and Anger (vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ): These three — attachment, fear, and anger — are the main enemies of the mind. The person of steady wisdom has transcended:

Attachment (Raga): No clinging to people, objects, or outcomes.

Fear (Bhaya): No fear of loss, death, or failure — because of inner trust in the divine and detachment from outcomes.

Anger (Krodha): Arises from unfulfilled desires or attachments; without them, there's no reason for anger.

4. Called a Sage of Steady Wisdom (sthita-dhīr muniḥ): Such a person is a muni (sage) — one who contemplates and reflects deeply — and remains established in spiritual wisdom.

श्लोक 2.57

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

या: सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम् ।
नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥५७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो पुरुष हर स्थान पर आसक्तियों से रहित है और जो शुभ तथा अशुभ किसी वस्तु को प्राप्त करके न हर्षित होता है, न द्वेष करता है—उसकी बुद्धि स्थिर है।

Meaning (English): He who is without attachment everywhere, who neither rejoices when he obtains good nor hates when he encounters evil — his wisdom is steady.

This verse continues Lord Krishna's description of a Sthita-prajna — a person of steady wisdom.

"Yaḥ sarvatrānabhi-snehaḥ": One who has no attachment anywhere — meaning he lives in the world, interacts with people and situations, but remains inwardly detached.

"Tattat prāpya śubhāśubham": Whether he obtains good (pleasurable) or bad (painful) results.

"Nābhinandati na dveṣṭi": He neither rejoices (gets overly excited) in good fortune, nor hates (gets disturbed) in misfortune.

Such a person's equanimity reflects inner stability and spiritual maturity. His mind does not get swayed by external events. He accepts the dualities of life — success and failure, praise and blame, gain and loss — with equanimity.

This doesn't mean he becomes emotionless or indifferent, but rather he doesn't get enslaved by emotions. His joy comes from within, not from external circumstances.

श्लोक 2.58

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥५८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जब मनुष्य अपने सभी इन्द्रियों को इन्द्रिय विषयों से ऐसे समेट लेता है जैसे कछुआ अपने अंगों को चारों ओर से समेट लेता है, तब उसकी बुद्धि स्थिर कही जाती है।

Meaning (English): When, like a tortoise that withdraws its limbs from all sides, a person withdraws his senses from sense objects, then his wisdom is firmly established.

This shloka is part of the “Sthita-prajna Lakshana” section of Chapter 2, where Lord Krishna describes the qualities of a person whose wisdom is steady (Sthita-prajna).

Tortoise Analogy: Just as a tortoise pulls its limbs into its shell for protection when danger is sensed, a wise person withdraws the senses from indulgence in external objects when needed. The tortoise doesn't lose its limbs; it simply pulls them back at the right time. Similarly, a wise person doesn't become emotionless but has control and self-restraint.

Indriyas (Senses): Sight, sound, smell, taste, and touch constantly pull us toward worldly pleasures. When the intellect (buddhi) gains strength, a person can control the impulsive desires of the senses.

Firm Wisdom (Prajna-Pratishthita): A person who has such mastery is said to have stable wisdom. This means their understanding is not easily shaken by temptations, emotions, or distractions.

श्लोक 2.59

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः ।
रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते ॥५९॥

Meaning (Hindi): निराहारी (व्रती) पुरुष के लिए विषय (इन्द्रिय भोग) दूर चले जाते हैं, लेकिन उनका रस (आसक्ति) बाकी रहता है। परंतु जब वह परम तत्व (परब्रह्म) को देख लेता है, तब वह रस भी नष्ट हो जाता है।

Meaning (English): The objects of the senses turn away from the abstinent person, but the taste for them remains. However, even this taste ceases when one experiences the Supreme.

This verse highlights a deep psychological and spiritual truth:

Renunciation of Objects: A person might forcibly withdraw from sensual pleasures (sense objects), such as delicious food, luxurious items, or sensual indulgences. This is like a person fasting or abstaining, but still desiring the food mentally.

Lingering Desire: Even when one stops indulging in sense pleasures, the subtle desire (rasa) or attraction for those pleasures still remains within the mind. This is crucial — simply suppressing actions does not eliminate desire.

True Renunciation through Realization: The only way to truly transcend this lingering desire is to experience something higher — the Supreme Reality (referred to here as Parāṁ Dṛṣṭvā - having seen the Supreme). Once one realizes or tastes the higher bliss of the divine, the lower worldly pleasures naturally lose their charm.

In essence, desire is not destroyed by force but by replacing it with a higher joy.

श्लोक 2.60

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः ।
इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः ॥६०॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे कौन्तेय! यत्नशील, विवेकी पुरुष का भी मन, उन प्रबल और चंचल इन्द्रियों द्वारा बलपूर्वक हर लिया जाता है।

Meaning (English): O Kaunteya (Arjuna), the turbulent senses forcibly carry away the mind of even a wise and striving person.

This verse is a powerful reminder of the strength and restlessness of the senses. Even a person who is wise (vipaschit) and striving for self-realization (yatatah) can be overpowered by the senses if they are not vigilant.

Restlessness of the Senses: The senses (sight, taste, touch, hearing, smell) are described as "pramāthīni" - turbulent and agitating. They constantly crave sensory pleasures and distractions.

Mind's Vulnerability: Even the mind of a discerning person can be forcibly diverted by these senses if not carefully controlled.

Importance of Discipline: This shloka warns us that intellectual knowledge alone isn't enough. Practical discipline and vigilant self-control are required to stay on the path of spiritual and moral progress.

श्लोक 2.61

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः ।
वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥६१॥

Meaning (Hindi): उन (इन्द्रियों) को सब प्रकार से वश में करके, मन को मुझमें लगाकर, जो मनुष्य इन्द्रियों को वश में किए हुए रहता है, उसकी बुद्धि स्थिर होती है।

Meaning (English): Having restrained all the senses, he should remain steadfast, with the mind focused on Me. For one whose senses are under control, his intelligence is firmly established.

In this verse, Lord Krishna continues explaining the qualities of a person with steady wisdom (sthitaprajna). This comes as a continuation from previous verses where He warns about the consequences of uncontrolled senses.

"Restraining all the senses" Krishna advises that a person aspiring for wisdom and spiritual progress must consciously restrain their senses. The senses naturally wander towards sensory objects (sights, sounds, tastes, etc.), and unchecked indulgence leads to desire and ultimately suffering.

"Being devoted to Me (matparah)" Self-control isn't about mere suppression. The mind needs a positive anchor. Krishna recommends that the seeker fix their mind on Him, or in broader terms, on a higher ideal, purpose, or truth. This channelizes mental energy and makes restraint meaningful.

"Such a person's wisdom is firmly established" When the senses are under control and the mind is focused on the Divine (or a higher purpose), the person becomes undisturbed, wise, and emotionally balanced. Their decisions stem from clarity, not impulse.

श्लोक 2.62

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते ।
सङ्गात्सञ्जायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते ॥६२॥

Meaning (Hindi): जब मनुष्य विषयों (इन्द्रियों के भोगों) का चिन्तन करता है, तो उन विषयों में आसक्ति उत्पन्न होती है। आसक्ति से कामना उत्पन्न होती है और कामना से क्रोध पैदा होता है।

Meaning (English): While contemplating the objects of the senses, a person develops attachment to them. From attachment arises desire, and from desire arises anger.

This shloka explains the psychological progression of human downfall due to uncontrolled attachment to sensory pleasures. Let's break it down step-by-step:

"Dhyayato vishayan pumsaḥ": When a person keeps thinking about sense objects (things that give pleasure to the senses — like food, wealth, status, etc.), his or her mind becomes occupied with them.

"Sangas teshu upajayate": Constant contemplation leads to attachment. You become emotionally linked to the object — the idea that you "need" it to be happy starts forming.

"Sangat sanjayate kamah": From attachment arises desire (kama) — a strong craving to possess or enjoy that object.

"Kamat krodho 'bhijayate": When that desire is unfulfilled, or someone or something comes in its way, it leads to anger (krodha). This is because the mind feels obstructed or disappointed.

So, it describes a chain reaction:

Contemplation ➝ Attachment ➝ Desire ➝ Anger ➝ Delusion ➝ Loss of intellect ➝ Downfall. (Expanded upon in the next verse, 2.63)

श्लोक 2.63

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः ।
स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति ॥६३॥

Meaning (Hindi): क्रोध से मोह उत्पन्न होता है, मोह से स्मृति में भ्रम होता है। स्मृति के भ्रम से बुद्धि का नाश होता है और बुद्धि के नष्ट होने से मनुष्य का पतन हो जाता है।

Meaning (English): From anger arises delusion; from delusion, confusion of memory. from confusion of memory, loss of intelligence; and from loss of intelligence, one falls down (into destruction).

This verse describes the psychological chain reaction that leads to a person's downfall when they are controlled by desire and anger. It continues the sequence Krishna began in the earlier shlokas of Chapter 2, especially starting from shloka 62.

Anger arises when desire is obstructed: When you don't get what you desire, or someone stands in your way, you feel frustrated. That frustration turns into anger.

Anger leads to delusion (sammoha): In anger, a person loses clarity. They become irrational and emotionally reactive. Their perception of reality gets distorted.

Delusion causes loss of memory (smriti vibhrama): "Memory" here refers to your spiritual knowledge, values, and wisdom—what you have learned about right and wrong, what your purpose is, etc. Delusion clouds your mind and causes you to forget your moral compass.

Loss of memory destroys the intellect (buddhi nasha): Your decision-making ability is lost. You're no longer guided by wisdom, but by impulse and confusion.

With the destruction of the intellect, one perishes (pranashyati): This doesn't necessarily mean physical death—it means spiritual and moral ruin. You make poor choices that lead to suffering and degradation.

श्लोक 2.64

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन् ।
आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति ॥६४॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो मनुष्य राग (आसक्ति) और द्वेष (घृणा) से रहित होकर, इंद्रियों द्वारा विषयों का सेवन करता है, और जिसकी इंद्रियाँ संयमित हैं तथा मन (आत्मा) उसके वश में है, वह प्रसन्नता (आंतरिक शांति) को प्राप्त करता है।

Meaning (English): But a person free from attachment and aversion, and who moves among the sense objects with the senses under control, and who is self-disciplined, attains peace.

Rāga (Attachment) and Dveṣa (Aversion): These are emotional reactions of liking and disliking that bind us to worldly experiences. They disturb the balance of mind and provoke desires and aversions that lead to suffering.

Indriyāṇi (Senses) and Viṣayān (Sense Objects): Sense objects are things we see, hear, taste, touch, and smell. The uncontrolled mind runs after these, creating disturbances.

Ātma-vaśya (Self-control): It means the mind is under one's own control, not controlled by impulses or external stimuli.

Prasāda (Peace/Grace): When the senses are controlled and the mind is detached from both attraction and repulsion, the individual experiences serenity and inner calm.

Krishna is teaching that true peace and clarity of mind come not by suppressing the senses, but by engaging with the world without emotional entanglement. The one who does not react impulsively to pleasurable or painful experiences, and instead remains centered and composed, gains a deep inner tranquility (prasāda) which is the foundation for spiritual growth.

श्लोक 2.65

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते ।
प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते ॥६५॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिस पुरुष के अंतःकरण में शांति है, उसके समस्त दुःखों का नाश हो जाता है। उस शांतचित्त व्यक्ति की बुद्धि शीघ्र ही स्थिर हो जाती है।

Meaning (English): In the state of inner tranquility (prasāda), all sorrows are destroyed. For the one whose mind is peaceful, the intellect soon becomes firmly established.

"Prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hānir asyopajāyate": When one attains inner prasāda (tranquility, grace, or mental calm), all kinds of sorrows and mental disturbances vanish. This prasāda isn't external joy but a deep inner satisfaction born from detachment and clarity.

"Prasanna-chetasaḥ hi āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate": For the one whose mind is clear and cheerful, the buddhi (intellect/discrimination) quickly becomes steady and resolute. A peaceful mind allows a person to think wisely, make better decisions, and not be swayed by emotions.

In essence, peace of mind is the foundation of wise thinking. Without inner peace, the intellect remains restless, clouded by desires and fears.

श्लोक 2.66

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना ।
न चाभावयत: शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतस्तमा ॥६६॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति दिव्य चेतना से जुड़ा हुआ नहीं होता, उसके पास बुद्धि नहीं होती। और जिस व्यक्ति के पास बुद्धि नहीं होती, उसके पास ध्यान नहीं होता। बिना ध्यान के शांति नहीं हो सकती, और बिना शांति के सुख नहीं मिल सकता।

Meaning (English): For one who is not connected with the divine consciousness, there is no intelligence. And for one who has no intelligence, there is no meditation. Without meditation, how can there be peace? And without peace, how can there be happiness?

"No Intelligence for One Who is Not Connected with the Divine": The verse begins by highlighting the importance of connecting with a higher consciousness or divine awareness. For someone who is disconnected from this higher self or divine understanding, true intelligence does not arise. This is not intellectual intelligence but spiritual intelligence, which helps one navigate through life's challenges with wisdom and clarity.

"No Meditation Without Intelligence": The next point is that, without intelligence (or wisdom), meditation is impossible. Meditation requires a calm and focused mind, which can only be achieved through self-awareness and intelligence. The person who is mentally scattered, full of doubts, and confusion will struggle to focus, let alone meditate.

"No Peace Without Meditation": The verse also emphasizes that peace cannot be attained without meditation. Meditation is a tool that helps the mind become still and focused. Only when the mind is at peace can a person experience tranquility, which is essential for a happy life. Without meditation, the mind is restless and troubled.

"No Happiness Without Peace": Finally, the verse concludes that true happiness cannot exist without inner peace. External circumstances may provide temporary joy, but lasting happiness is rooted in the inner peace of the mind. This inner peace comes from spiritual wisdom, meditation, and a clear connection to the divine.

श्लोक 2.67

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनु विधीयते ।
तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि ॥६७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जब चंचल इंद्रियाँ विषयों में लगी रहती हैं और उनमें मन भी लिप्त हो जाता है, तब वह मनुष्य की बुद्धि को वैसे ही हर लेती हैं, जैसे जल में चल रही नाव को तेज हवा उड़ा ले जाती है।

Meaning (English): As a boat on the water is swept away by a strong wind, even so the mind that yields to the wandering senses carries away the intelligence.

"Indriyaani charataam" - When the senses wander toward the sense objects (sight, sound, taste, etc.).

"Yan mano'nuvidhīyate" - And the mind follows those senses.

"Tadasya harati prajñām" - That mind, influenced by the senses, takes away one's wisdom/discrimination.

"Vaayur naavam iva ambhasi" - Like the wind drives a boat off-course in the water, the mind pulled by the senses leads one away from the path of clarity and self-realization.

Krishna is emphasizing how lack of discipline over senses and the mind can destroy a person's spiritual insight and wisdom. Just like a boat without control drifts aimlessly on water, a person whose mind follows uncontrolled senses loses direction in life.

श्लोक 2.68

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥६८॥

Meaning (Hindi): इसलिए हे महाबाहो! जिसके सब इन्द्रियाँ विषयों से सब प्रकार से हटा ली गई हैं, उसकी बुद्धि स्थिर है।

Meaning (English): Therefore, O mighty-armed one, he whose senses are completely restrained from their objects — his intellect is firmly established.

In this shloka, Shri Krishna is explaining a core concept of self-discipline and inner stability to Arjuna. Here's a breakdown of the key ideas:

"तस्मात्" (Therefore): This refers back to the previous verses where Krishna talked about how the uncontrolled senses can carry away even the wise person's mind and disturb their inner peace. So, "therefore" is drawing a conclusion — that self-control is essential for spiritual wisdom.

"यस्य इन्द्रियाणि निगृहीतानि सर्वशः" (One whose senses are fully restrained): The senses (eyes, ears, tongue, skin, etc.) are naturally drawn toward sensory pleasures — sights, sounds, tastes, etc. Krishna says that true wisdom requires restraining these senses from running after their respective objects. "Nigrihītāni" means not suppression but conscious control, where the senses are under the guidance of intellect rather than impulses.

"इन्द्रियार्थेभ्यः" (From sense objects): This phrase emphasizes detachment from worldly temptations. It doesn't mean you shouldn't enjoy the world, but that you shouldn't be enslaved by it.

"तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता" (His wisdom is firmly established): This line is the conclusion: When one successfully controls the senses, the buddhi (intellect) becomes steady and focused. Such a person doesn't swing between emotions or desires; they experience inner clarity and peace.

श्लोक 2.69

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी ।
यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः ॥६९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो (बाह्य विषयों में) सब प्राणियों के लिए रात (अज्ञानरूप) है, उसमें संयमी पुरुष जागता है; और जिसमें (बाह्य विषयों में) सब प्राणी जागते हैं, वह (बुद्धियुक्त) मुनि के लिए रात के समान (अज्ञानरूप) है।

Meaning (English): What is night for all beings, there the self-controlled one is awake. where all beings are awake, that is night for the sage who sees.

This verse uses a poetic and philosophical metaphor to highlight the contrast between a spiritually awakened person (a Yogi or Muni) and the worldly-minded individuals.

"Night" and "Day" here are not literal but symbolic:

For worldly people, material pleasures, desires, and sensory experiences are their "day" — the focus of their lives. For a realized soul, these same pursuits appear meaningless — like "night" when everything is dark and inactive.

Conversely, the inner spiritual reality, self-discipline, and higher wisdom — which seem like "night" (unknown or boring) to worldly people — are the "day" for the Yogi.

The self-controlled one (Saṁyamī) is awake to the inner truth, detached from fleeting pleasures, and aware of the soul (Atman). The common people are awake only to worldly affairs, remaining asleep to the deeper spiritual truths.

श्लोक 2.70

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं
समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्।
तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे
स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी ॥७०॥

Meaning (Hindi): जैसे नदियाँ समुद्र में जाकर मिलती हैं, जो सदा भरा हुआ है और अचल (अडिग) है, वैसे ही सभी इन्द्रिय-विषय उस व्यक्ति में समा जाते हैं, जो इच्छाओं से रहित है। ऐसा व्यक्ति ही शान्ति को प्राप्त करता है, न कि वह जो इच्छाओं के पीछे भागता रहता है।

Meaning (English): As the waters of different rivers enter into the ocean, which though full on all sides remains undisturbed, so also into the peaceful person enter all desires, and he attains peace, not the person who is desirous of desires.

This shloka uses a beautiful metaphor to explain the state of inner peace and detachment:

The ocean symbolizes a person of wisdom (sthitaprajna) — one who is spiritually stable.

The rivers are like worldly desires — constantly flowing towards the ocean.

Even though countless rivers enter the ocean, the ocean remains steady and unchanged.

Similarly, a person who has mastered self-control and does not get disturbed by the incoming desires, remains calm and peaceful.

The shloka contrasts this peaceful person with the one who is "kāma-kāmī" — someone who longs for pleasures. Such a person never finds peace, as they are always chasing after unfulfilled desires.

श्लोक 2.71

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः ।
निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति ॥७१॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो पुरुष समस्त कामनाओं को त्यागकर, इच्छा-रहित, ममता-रहित और अहंकार-रहित होकर विचरण करता है — वही शांति को प्राप्त करता है।

Meaning (English): That person who abandons all desires and moves about free from longing, without the sense of 'mine' and without ego—he attains peace.

This verse continues to define the state of a sthita-prajna—one who is steady in wisdom.

"Vihāya kāmān" (Having abandoned all desires): The seeker gives up worldly desires, which are the root cause of restlessness. Desires arise from attachments and expectations from the external world.

"Yaḥ sarvān pumān carati niḥspṛhaḥ" (Moves about without longing): Even while living in the world and interacting with it, the wise person acts without craving or emotional dependency.

"Nirmamaḥ" (Free from possessiveness): He does not feel "this is mine." The feeling of ownership over people, objects, or results is relinquished. This helps in overcoming attachment and anxiety.

"Nirahankāraḥ" (Free from ego): He has transcended the ego, the sense of "I" as the doer. Such a person understands that the Self is not the body or mind but something higher and eternal.

"Saḥ śāntim adhigacchati" (He attains peace): Only such a person who is desireless, selfless, and egoless can attain true inner peace—a peace not disturbed by outer circumstances.

श्लोक 2.72

श्रीभगवान उवाच।

एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति ।
स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति ॥७२॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे पार्थ! यह ब्राह्मी स्थिति है, जिसे प्राप्त करके मनुष्य मोहित नहीं होता। और जो अंत समय में भी इस स्थिति में स्थित रहता है, वह ब्रह्मनिर्वाण (परम मोक्ष) को प्राप्त होता है।

Meaning (English): O Partha (Arjuna), this is the state of Brahman (Self-realization). Having attained this, one is not deluded. Being established in this state even at the time of death, a person attains liberation (Brahma-nirvana).

This verse concludes Chapter 2 (Sankhya Yoga or Yoga of Knowledge) by describing the ultimate goal of spiritual practice—the state of Brahmi Sthiti or the state of divine consciousness.

“This is the Brahmi state, O Partha” Krishna tells Arjuna that the state of equanimity, detachment, and wisdom he has described (especially in verses 54-71) is called Brahmi Sthiti, the state of being established in the Supreme Self (Brahman).

“One who attains this is not deluded” When a person reaches this level of self-realization, they are free from ignorance, illusions, and emotional disturbances. They no longer identify with ego, body, or desires.

“Even at the time of death” The emphasis here is powerful. If a person can attain this enlightened state even at the time of death, they are truly liberated. Death, which is often associated with fear and loss, becomes a doorway to moksha (liberation) rather than rebirth.

“He attains Brahma-nirvana” This means freedom from the cycle of birth and death, complete peace, and unity with the Supreme Consciousness.

Click to view Itinerary
Click to view summary

श्लोक 3.1

अर्जुन उवाच।

ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन ।
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव ॥१॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे जनार्दन! यदि आपकी बुद्धि में ज्ञान (बुद्धियोग) कर्म से श्रेष्ठ है, तो हे केशव! आप मुझे इस भयानक कर्म (युद्ध) में क्यों लगाना चाहते हैं?

Meaning (English): O Janardana (Krishna), if you consider knowledge (of renunciation) superior to action, then why do you urge me to engage in this terrible action (war), O Keshava?

This verse opens Chapter 3, where Arjuna is confused again. In Chapter 2, Lord Krishna emphasized the value of Buddhiyoga (the path of knowledge and wisdom), detachment, and equanimity. Arjuna misunderstood this and thought Krishna was glorifying the renunciation of action.

So here, Arjuna raises a logical doubt:

"If knowledge is superior to action, then why are you pushing me into war (action)?"

This shows a classic confusion between Jnana Yoga (Path of Knowledge) and Karma Yoga (Path of Action). Arjuna is trying to reconcile the spiritual path Krishna described with the physical reality of war in front of him.

He is essentially saying:

"Krishna, you just said wisdom and detachment are the best ways to liberation. If that's true, then why are you asking me to fight this gruesome war, which seems so worldly and violent?"

श्लोक 3.2

अर्जुन उवाच।

व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे ।
तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् ॥२॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे केशव! आपके वचनों से मेरी बुद्धि जैसे भ्रमित हो गई है, क्योंकि आप ज्ञान (सांख्य) और कर्म दोनों की प्रशंसा कर रहे हैं। कृपा करके निश्चित रूप से एक मार्ग बताइए, जिससे मैं परम कल्याण को प्राप्त कर सकूं।

Meaning (English): O Krishna, by your seemingly contradictory words, you are confusing my understanding. Therefore, please tell me decisively that one path by which I may attain the highest good.

In this shloka, Arjuna is expressing confusion. In the previous chapter (Chapter 2), Krishna explained both:

Sankhya Yoga (Path of Knowledge) - leading to renunciation,

Karma Yoga (Path of Action) - leading to selfless action.

Arjuna feels these paths appear contradictory: one talks of renouncing actions, while the other encourages performing duties without attachment.

He is essentially saying, “Krishna, I am confused. Are you asking me to renounce actions or perform them? Please guide me clearly on the one path that will truly lead to my ultimate good (śreyas).”

This shows Arjuna's humility and desire for clarity, a mark of a sincere seeker.

श्लोक 3.3

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

लोकेऽस्मिन् द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ ।
ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् ॥३॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे निष्पाप अर्जुन! इस संसार में दो प्रकार की निष्ठा (मार्ग) पूर्वकाल में मैंने बताई थी— सांख्य योगियों (ज्ञानियों) के लिए ज्ञानयोग और कर्मयोगियों (कर्म करने वालों) के लिए कर्मयोग।

Meaning (English): O sinless Arjuna, in this world, two paths of spiritual discipline were taught by Me in the beginning— the path of knowledge (Jñāna Yoga) for the contemplative (Sankhyas), and the path of action (Karma Yoga) for the active (Yogis).

In this verse, Lord Krishna addresses the confusion Arjuna has about renunciation (sannyāsa) versus action (karma). Krishna explains that spiritual realization isn't confined to only one path. Instead, there are two well-established paths suited to different types of people:

Jñāna Yoga (Path of Knowledge): For those inclined toward contemplation, introspection, and philosophical understanding. Such seekers follow Sankhya philosophy, which emphasizes renunciation, self-inquiry, and realizing the Self as distinct from the body and mind. It is an inward path best suited for individuals who can withdraw from worldly duties and meditate on the Self.

Karma Yoga (Path of Selfless Action): For individuals who are action-oriented and live within the world (like Arjuna himself). Here, one performs their duties without attachment to the results, dedicating the action and its outcome to the Divine. This is not about inactivity, but about non-attachment while performing righteous action.

Krishna clarifies that both paths are valid and ultimately lead to the same goal: liberation (moksha). The difference lies in the temperament and disposition of the seeker.

श्लोक 3.4

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते ।
न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति ॥४॥

Meaning (Hindi): मनुष्य केवल कर्मों को न करने से कर्मरहित (नैष्कर्म्य) नहीं हो सकता, और केवल संन्यास (त्याग) करने से सिद्धि (परम लक्ष्य) को प्राप्त नहीं करता।

Meaning (English): A person does not attain freedom from action by merely abstaining from work, nor does he achieve perfection (siddhi or liberation) merely by renunciation alone.

Here, Krishna is addressing a common misconception:

That merely renouncing action (karmas) or physically withdrawing from duties leads to spiritual liberation or perfection.

"Na karmaṇām anārambhān naiṣkarmyaṁ puruṣo'śnute" A person does not attain the state of actionlessness (naiṣkarmya, meaning freedom from binding actions or karmic bondage) by simply not initiating action.

"Na ca sannyasanād eva siddhiṁ samadhigacchati" Nor does one attain siddhi (perfection, liberation, or realization) just by taking sannyasa (renunciation of worldly life or duties).

Lord Krishna emphasizes that action is essential. Mere physical renunciation (like quitting your job, going to the forest, or living as a monk) without the right understanding or inner transformation does not lead to spiritual success.

श्लोक 3.5

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत् ।
कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः ॥५॥

Meaning (Hindi): कोई भी व्यक्ति एक क्षण के लिए भी बिना कर्म किए नहीं रह सकता, क्योंकि सभी लोग प्रकृति द्वारा उत्पन्न गुणों से विवश होकर कर्म करने को बाध्य होते हैं।

Meaning (English): No one can remain without action even for a moment. Everyone is compelled to act, helplessly indeed, by the qualities (gunas) born of nature (Prakriti).

This shloka emphasizes the inevitability of action in human life. Lord Krishna is explaining to Arjuna that inaction is not possible. Every living being is driven by the modes (gunas) of nature — Sattva (goodness), Rajas (passion), and Tamas (ignorance). These gunas inherently push individuals toward various actions.

Even if a person decides to sit idle or remain physically still, mental activity continues — thoughts, emotions, memories, desires — all of which are forms of subtle action. Therefore, absolute inaction is an illusion.

Krishna is indirectly cautioning Arjuna against misinterpreting the idea of renunciation. Renunciation doesn't mean escaping duties or becoming inactive, but rather performing one's duties without attachment.

श्लोक 3.6

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन् ।
इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते ॥६॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति कर्मेन्द्रियों को तो रोककर बैठा रहता है, पर मन से इन्द्रियों के विषयों का चिन्तन करता रहता है—वह मूढ़ आत्मा मिथ्याचार (पाखंडी) कहलाता है।

Meaning (English): One who restrains the organs of action but continues to dwell in the mind on the sense objects, such a deluded person is called a hypocrite.

This verse is a powerful insight into the inner and outer dimensions of self-discipline and spiritual practice.

"Karmendriyani samyamya": refers to someone who externally restrains the organs of action (hands, legs, speech, etc.), meaning they avoid engaging in physical actions.

"Manasa smaran": but mentally continues to contemplate the objects of the senses (pleasures, desires).

"Indriyarthan vimudha-atma": such a person is deluded, lacking true understanding or wisdom.

"Mithyacharah": a hypocrite, someone who pretends to be righteous externally but is not inwardly.

In essence, Lord Krishna is criticizing false renunciation — simply refraining from physical actions while the mind continues to indulge in desire is not true detachment or spiritual progress. True renunciation requires both the body and mind to be aligned.

श्लोक 3.7

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन ।
कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते ॥७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो पुरुष इन्द्रियों को मन से वश में करके आसक्ति रहित होकर कर्मेन्द्रियों द्वारा कर्मयोग में लगा रहता है, वह श्रेष्ठ है।

Meaning (English): But one who controls the senses with the mind, O Arjuna, and engages in karma yoga (the path of selfless action) with the organs of action, without attachment, is far superior.

In this verse, Shri Krishna contrasts two kinds of people:

Those who restrain from action externally but still dwell mentally on sense pleasures.

Those who control their senses through the mind and selflessly engage in rightful action.

Krishna praises the latter. He's saying that simply suppressing action is not true renunciation if the mind is still obsessed with desires. A person who: Has mastered the senses (through the discipline of the mind), is free from attachment, acts through their physical faculties (hands, speech, body) for a righteous cause, without craving the result of action (success/failure, gain/loss), such a person is truly superior.

This is karma yoga in practice: selfless action done with discipline and detachment.

श्लोक 3.8

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः ।
शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः ॥८॥

Meaning (Hindi): तुम नियत (निर्धारित) कर्म करो, क्योंकि कर्म करना अकर्म (कुछ न करना) से श्रेष्ठ है। अकर्म करने से तो तुम्हारी यह शरीर-यात्रा भी सफल नहीं होगी।

Meaning (English): Perform your prescribed duty, for action is better than inaction. Even the maintenance of your body would not be possible without action.

In this verse, Lord Krishna instructs Arjuna to perform his niyat karma — that is, the duties assigned to him according to his role (as a Kshatriya and as a part of the society).

1. "Niyatam kuru karma tvam" - Perform your prescribed duties: Krishna emphasizes the importance of duty-bound actions. Each individual has responsibilities (whether as a student, worker, soldier, parent, etc.) and fulfilling those is essential for maintaining personal discipline and social harmony.

2. "Karma jyaayo hi akarmanah" - Action is superior to inaction: Here, Krishna is discouraging escapism or laziness. Doing nothing may seem peaceful, but in reality, it leads to stagnation, confusion, and even destruction. Constructive karma (action) helps in personal evolution and keeps the wheel of society moving.

3. "Sharira-yatra api cha te na prasiddhyed akarmanah" - Even your bodily maintenance is not possible without action: Even something as basic as keeping the body alive (eating, breathing, earning a living) requires action. Inaction leads to decay, not liberation.

This subtly rebukes Arjuna's desire to abandon the battlefield to avoid sin or grief. Krishna says: “Avoiding action doesn't make one pure—it only leads to neglect and ignorance.”

श्लोक 3.9

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः ।
तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसंगः समाचर ॥९॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे कौन्तेय! यज्ञ के लिए किए गए कर्मों को छोड़कर अन्य सभी कर्म बंधन का कारण होते हैं। इसलिए तू आसक्ति (लगाव) से मुक्त होकर केवल यज्ञ के लिए ही कर्म कर।

Meaning (English): O Kaunteya (Arjuna), except actions done as a sacrifice (for Yajña), all actions cause bondage in this world. Therefore, perform your duties for that sake, free from attachment.

This verse is part of Lord Krishna's guidance on Karma Yoga — the path of selfless action.

1. "Yajñārthāt karmaṇaḥ" - Actions done for the sake of sacrifice: "Yajña" here doesn't just refer to ritualistic offerings in fire. It symbolizes selfless acts, duties done as an offering to a higher purpose, such as for society, dharma (righteousness), or the divine.

2. "Anyatra loko 'yaṁ karma-bandhanaḥ" - Other actions cause bondage: If actions are done selfishly, for personal gain, desire, or ego, they result in karma-bandhana — bondage of karma. These karmas bind the soul to the cycle of birth and death (samsara), through their consequences (karma-phala).

3. "Tad-artham karma kaunteya" - Therefore, for that sake (Yajña), perform action: Krishna urges Arjuna to align his duties with a higher cause, not with selfish motives.

4. "Mukta-saṅgaḥ samāchara" - Perform them without attachment: Do your actions without emotional dependency on the outcome — success or failure.

This is the essence of Karma Yoga — act sincerely, but stay mentally detached from the results.

श्लोक 3.10

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः ।
अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् ॥१०॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान ने सृष्टि की रचना के प्रारंभ में प्रजाओं (मनुष्यों) के साथ यज्ञ की भी रचना की और कहा — "तुम यज्ञ के द्वारा समृद्ध होओ; यह यज्ञ तुम्हारी कामनाओं की पूर्ति करने वाला होगा।"

Meaning (English): At the beginning of creation, the Creator (Prajapati or Brahma) created mankind along with the spirit of yajna (sacrifice) and said: “By this (yajna), may you prosper; let this be the fulfiller of all your desires.”

This shloka highlights the divine law of selfless action and sacrifice as an eternal principle embedded in the very foundation of creation. It reveals a cosmic symbiosis — a balance between humans and nature through mutual support.

“Sahayajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā” - This means that when the universe was created, yajna (sacrifice or selfless service) was embedded within human existence. Every being was given the power and responsibility to contribute to the harmony of the cosmos.

“Purovāca prajāpatiḥ” - The Creator (Prajapati or Brahma) instructed the beings that sacrifice is essential for sustenance and prosperity.

“Anena prasaviṣyadhvam” - Through sacrifice, mankind will prosper, thrive, and grow — not just materially, but also spiritually. “Eṣa vo 'stv iṣṭa-kāmadhuk” - This yajna will become the "wish-fulfilling cow" (kāmadhuk), a metaphor indicating that through selfless action and contribution to the welfare of others, one's righteous desires will be fulfilled.

श्लोक 3.11

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः ।
परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ ॥११॥

Meaning (Hindi): इस यज्ञ रूप कर्म से देवताओं को प्रसन्न करो और वे देवता तुम्हें प्रसन्न करेंगे। इस प्रकार एक-दूसरे को प्रसन्न करते हुए तुम परम कल्याण को प्राप्त करोगे।

Meaning (English): Nourish the gods with this sacrifice, and may those gods nourish you in return. By mutually supporting one another, you shall attain the highest good.

In this verse, Lord Krishna explains the principle of mutual cooperation between humans and celestial forces (Devas), which is central to the functioning of the universe.

Yajna (Sacrifice): Here, yajna doesn't only mean fire rituals but refers more broadly to selfless action performed for the greater good — for society, for nature, and for the divine.

Devas (Gods/Nature's Forces): Devas symbolize various natural forces — like the sun, rain, wind, etc. — that sustain life. They are nourished or pleased when humans live harmoniously and fulfill their duties (dharma) through righteous actions.

Mutual Support: Krishna emphasizes a cyclical, cooperative relationship. When humans offer their labor and actions as sacrifices (in the form of duty), they uphold nature's balance. In turn, nature (or devas) supports human life.

Higher Good (Shreyas): This cooperative balance leads not only to material prosperity but also to spiritual elevation, helping individuals progress on the path to liberation (moksha).

श्लोक 3.12

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः ।
तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः ॥१२॥

Meaning (Hindi): यज्ञ से संतुष्ट देवता तुम्हें वांछित भोग देंगे। लेकिन यदि तुम उन्हें (देवताओं को) अर्पण किए बिना उन भोगों का उपभोग करते हो, तो तुम चोर हो।

Meaning (English): The gods, nourished by sacrifice, will give you the desired enjoyments. But he who enjoys their gifts without offering them in return is verily a thief.

This shloka continues the theme of karma and yajna (sacrifice) from the earlier verses of Chapter 3.

Yajna (Sacrifice) as a Cosmic Principle: Krishna emphasizes that the entire cosmos operates in a cycle of giving and receiving. Yajna here does not only mean ritualistic offerings in a fire — it refers to any selfless action done in alignment with dharma (duty), and with an attitude of offering to a higher purpose.

Mutual Cooperation (Devas and Humans): The Devas (divine forces or gods) represent the natural and cosmic powers (like rain, sun, wind, etc.). When humans perform their duties with the spirit of yajna, the devas are satisfied and, in turn, provide the necessities and pleasures of life (like food, rain, health, etc.). This reflects the principle of interdependence in the universe.

Condemnation of Selfish Consumption: Those who consume the gifts of nature (the devas) without acknowledging or giving back through sacrifice or selfless duty are called "thieves". The term "thief" here is significant — it implies not legal but moral and spiritual theft. You're taking from the world but not contributing anything in return.

श्लोक 3.13

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः ।
भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात् ॥१३॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो लोग यज्ञ के लिए अर्पित अन्न का सेवन करते हैं, वे समस्त पापों से मुक्त हो जाते हैं। परंतु जो लोग केवल अपने लिए भोजन बनाते हैं, वे पाप ही खाते हैं।

Meaning (English): The righteous who eat the remnants of sacrifices are freed from all sins, but those sinful ones who cook food only for themselves eat nothing but sin.

This verse speaks about the spiritual and ethical significance of selflessness, yajña (sacrifice), and duty towards others.

"Yajña-śhiṣṭāśhinaḥ santo" - Those who eat the remnants of sacrifice: Here, yajña doesn't only mean fire rituals. In the Gita, it refers more broadly to selfless action done in a spirit of devotion and offering. After performing duties as a sacrifice (offering the fruits to God or the welfare of others), when people consume what remains, it is purified, and their actions do not bind them with sin.

"Muchyante sarva-kilbiṣhaiḥ" - Are freed from all sins: Because their actions are not selfish, such people are spiritually purified. Selfless work aligns with dharma and helps purify the mind and soul, leading to inner peace and liberation.

"Bhuñjate te tvagham pāpāḥ" - But those who eat sin: The contrast is with those who cook for their own sake only, not as an offering or in a spirit of sharing. This refers to self-centered living, where one's actions are only for personal gain, pleasure, or ego. Such actions are considered tainted, since they bind the doer in karma and lead to further desires and consequences.

श्लोक 3.14

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः ।
यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः ॥१४॥

Meaning (Hindi): अन्न से प्राणी उत्पन्न होते हैं, वर्षा से अन्न होता है, यज्ञ से वर्षा होती है और यज्ञ कर्म से उत्पन्न होता है।

Meaning (English): All living beings are born from food; food is produced by rain; rain is produced by sacrifice (yajña), and sacrifice arises from prescribed duties (karma).

This shloka describes the cosmic cycle of sustenance and duty—how all life is interconnected through the system of nature and righteous action (karma).

"Beings are born from food": All living creatures survive and grow by consuming food. This highlights the fundamental role of food in sustaining life.

"Food comes from rain": Without rain, crops cannot grow. This line shows that nature (especially the rain cycle) is essential for food production.

"Rain is the result of yajña (sacrifice)": Here, "yajña" does not only mean ritualistic fire sacrifices. In the Gita's broader context, yajña implies selfless actions done as offerings to the divine or for the greater good. When humans perform their duties ethically and selflessly, it brings balance and harmony to nature, symbolized as "rain."

"Yajña is born of karma (prescribed duties)": Performing one's swadharma (righteous duties) without selfish desires, as prescribed by scriptures and society, is considered yajña. Thus, karma is the origin of all sacrifices, which in turn sustain the cycle of life.

श्लोक 3.15

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम् ।
तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् ॥१५॥

Meaning (Hindi): कर्म को ब्रह्म (वेद) से उत्पन्न जानो, और ब्रह्म को अविनाशी परमात्मा से उत्पन्न जानो। इसलिए सर्वत्र व्याप्त ब्रह्म सदा यज्ञ में प्रतिष्ठित है।

Meaning (English): Know that all actions originate from the Vedas, and the Vedas originate from the Imperishable (Akshar Brahma). Hence, the all-pervading Brahman is eternally situated in sacrifice (Yajna).

This verse continues the discourse on selfless action and sacrifice (Yajna).

"Karma brahmodbhavam viddhi" - "Action arises from the Vedas": This means that the rules and principles guiding human action (karma) have been laid down in the Vedas, the most ancient spiritual scriptures. The Vedas prescribe duties, rituals, and righteous conduct, hence, action is said to originate from the Vedas.

"Brahma akshara-samudbhavam" - "The Vedas come from the Imperishable": The Vedas themselves are not eternal in the sense of being self-born — they are revealed from the Akshara (the eternal, imperishable - referring to Brahman, the Supreme Being). Thus, the ultimate source of guidance, law, and dharma is God (Brahman).

"Tasmāt sarva-gataṁ brahma nityaṁ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam": Since Brahman (the Divine) pervades all, and the Vedas originate from Him, and actions originate from the Vedas, therefore, the Divine is always present in Yajna (sacrifice or selfless duty).

In essence, the cycle is as follows:

God (Brahman) → Vedas (knowledge) → Prescribed Duties (karma) → Performed as Yajna (sacrifice).

श्लोक 3.16

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह य: ।
अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति ॥१६॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे पार्थ! जो मनुष्य इस प्रकार (कर्मों के) चलाए गए चक्र में नहीं चलता, अर्थात् जो यज्ञ के लिए कर्म नहीं करता, वह पापमय जीवन जीता है। वह केवल इंद्रियों के सुख में लिप्त रहता है और उसका जीवन व्यर्थ है।

Meaning (English): O Partha (Arjuna), he who does not follow the wheel of creation set in motion (by the Creator), and lives sinfully, delighting in the senses, such a person lives in vain.

This verse is part of Karma Yoga, where Krishna emphasizes the importance of performing one's duties in harmony with the cosmic order.

"Evam pravartitam chakram" - The Eternal Cycle: Krishna refers to the cosmic cycle of creation, sustenance, and sacrifice.

This cycle includes:

Humans performing selfless actions (karma).

Offering the fruits to Yajña (sacrifice).

Yajña sustains the gods/nature.

Gods return blessings as rain, food, and well-being.

This mutual cooperation maintains balance and harmony in the world.

"Na anuvartayati" - One who does not follow this: Those who break this divine cycle—who do not perform actions for the welfare of all—are acting selfishly. Such people exploit resources, live for sensory pleasures, and contribute nothing back.

"Aghāyur" - Sinful life: The one who ignores this system lives a life of sin because their existence burdens the world. They consume but do not contribute, violating their dharma.

"Mogham sa jīvati" - Lives in vain: A selfish person's life has no real purpose or meaning. They might live materially well, but spiritually and morally, their life is wasted.

श्लोक 3.17

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः ।
आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते ॥१७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो मनुष्य केवल आत्मा में ही अनुरक्त रहता है, आत्मा में ही तृप्त रहता है और आत्मा में ही संतुष्ट रहता है, उसके लिए कोई कर्तव्य (कर्म) नहीं है।

Meaning (English): But the man who is delighting in the Self alone, who is satisfied in the Self, and content in the Self only—for him, there is no duty to perform.

This shloka is spoken by Lord Krishna to Arjuna in the context of explaining Karma Yoga—the yoga of selfless action.

Here, Krishna describes a highly evolved spiritual person, one who has attained Self-realization.

"Yas tu ātmā-ratiḥ eva syāt" - "He who delights in the Self alone": This refers to a person who finds joy not in external pleasures, possessions, or relationships, but in the inner Self (Atman).

"Ātma-tṛptaś ca mānavaḥ" - "Who is satisfied in the Self": Such a person is completely fulfilled from within. They don't need validation or happiness from the world. They are content by simply being who they are.

"Ātmany eva ca santuṣṭaḥ" - "And is content in the Self alone": This emphasizes inner peace and satisfaction, without desires for external outcomes.

"Tasya kāryam na vidyate" - "For him, no duty exists": A Self-realized person is free from obligatory duties, because they are no longer bound by karma. They don't act out of personal desire or compulsion—they may still act, but without attachment.

In essence, when one realizes the Self, all worldly duties dissolve, because there's no ego left to bind them to actions.

श्लोक 3.18

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन ।
न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः ॥१८॥

Meaning (Hindi): उस पुरुष के लिए, जिसने आत्मसाक्षात्कार कर लिया है, ना तो कर्म करने में कोई प्रयोजन रहता है, और ना ही कर्म न करने में कोई हानि होती है। साथ ही, उसे किसी प्राणी पर किसी प्रकार की आश्रयता नहीं रहती।

Meaning (English): For one who has realized the Self, there is no purpose to be served by performing work, nor is there any loss by not performing it. Moreover, such a person has no dependence on any being for anything.

This shloka describes the state of a Self-realized person (a Jnani) — someone who has understood their true divine nature and lives in constant awareness of the Atman (soul) or Brahman (universal consciousness).

"naiva tasya kṛtenārtho" - He has nothing to gain from action: A Self-realized person doesn't perform actions to fulfill desires, earn merit, or gain recognition. Their happiness does not depend on external achievements. They act from a place of completeness, not for completion.

"nākṛteneha kaścana" - Nor does he lose anything by inaction: Inaction also doesn't harm such a person. They are internally fulfilled. Their identity is no longer tied to the success or failure of actions.

"na cāsya sarvabhūteṣu kaścid artha-vyapāśrayaḥ" - He depends on no one for any purpose: Such a person is inwardly independent. They do not rely on others for emotional validation, material support, or existential purpose. Their existence is rooted in Self-awareness, not in social roles or relationships.

श्लोक 3.19

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

तस्मात्सक्तः सदा कर्म समाचर‍‍ ।
असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः ॥१९॥

Meaning (Hindi): इसलिए, सदैव आसक्ति रहित होकर अपने कर्तव्य कर्म को भली-भांति करते रहो; क्योंकि आसक्ति से रहित होकर कर्म करने वाला मनुष्य परमात्मा को प्राप्त होता है।

Meaning (English): Therefore, Always perform your prescribed duties without attachment; for by performing duties without attachment, a person attains the Supreme.

This verse is a cornerstone of Karma Yoga, the path of selfless action.

"Saktah" (Attachment) vs. "Asaktah" (Detachment): Krishna emphasizes that action (karma) should be performed without clinging to results or expectations. Detachment doesn't mean negligence or lack of care — it means doing your duty without selfish motives or emotional dependence on the outcome.

"Sada karma samachara": This means always engage in your duty, not just occasionally. Discipline, consistency, and dedication are vital.

"Param apnoti purushaḥ": A person who performs their duties selflessly attains the Supreme (Param) — this can mean liberation (moksha), inner peace, or union with the Divine.

श्लोक 3.20

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः ।
लोकसंग्रहमेवापि सम्पश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि ॥२०॥

Meaning (Hindi): केवल कर्म के द्वारा ही जनक आदि राजाओं ने सिद्धि (मोक्ष) को प्राप्त किया है। इसलिए तू भी लोक-संग्रह (जनहित) की दृष्टि से कर्म करने के योग्य है।

Meaning (English): It is through action alone that Janaka and others attained perfection. You too should perform your duty for the sake of the welfare of the world.

Historical Reference - Janaka

Krishna references King Janaka, a famous Rajarshi (king-sage), who is considered an ideal example of someone who attained spiritual perfection while fulfilling his worldly duties. He didn't renounce the world but attained liberation (moksha) through selfless action.

This example is to show Arjuna that spiritual growth is not limited to renunciates, but also possible for householders and leaders who engage actively in the world.

Core Message: Krishna emphasizes "karma yoga"—the path of selfless action. He says that: Perfection or liberation (siddhi) is not exclusive to monks or ascetics. One can achieve it through dedicated, detached action, done without selfish motives. Such action not only uplifts the self but also benefits society (लोकसंग्रह).

Lokasangraha (Welfare of the World): A key concept here is "lokasangraha"—acting for the welfare and maintenance of the world. Leaders, like Arjuna, must set an example by fulfilling their duties. If they abandon action, others will follow, potentially leading to chaos or adharma (unrighteousness). Therefore, even spiritually advanced souls must act for the stability and good of the world.

श्लोक 3.21

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः ।
स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते ॥२१॥

Meaning (Hindi): श्रेष्ठ पुरुष जैसा आचरण करता है, सामान्य लोग भी वैसा ही करते हैं। वह जो आचरण करता है, लोग उसी को प्रमाण मानकर उसका अनुकरण करते हैं।

Meaning (English): Whatever action a great person performs, common people follow. Whatever standard they set by their actions, the world pursues.

This shloka highlights the power of example and the responsibility of leadership. Krishna tells Arjuna that people naturally follow the actions of those they look up to—leaders, teachers, or influencers.

The term "śhreṣhṭhaḥ" (श्रेष्ठ) refers to someone who is distinguished—morally, socially, or intellectually. It can be a king, teacher, parent, spiritual guide, or any role model. Their behavior becomes the blueprint for society. People often don't just listen to what great people say—they imitate what they do.

This applies not only in spiritual life but in all fields—politics, education, parenting, management, etc.

Krishna is also indirectly guiding Arjuna here: as a Kshatriya prince and hero, his decisions and actions will influence others. If he avoids duty (Dharma) out of personal reasons, others may justify neglecting their duties too.

श्लोक 3.22

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

न मे पार्थ अस्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन ।
नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि ॥२२॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे पार्थ! तीनों लोकों में मुझे कुछ भी कर्तव्य नहीं है, अर्थात् कोई भी कर्म ऐसा नहीं है जिसे मुझे करना आवश्यक हो। न मुझे कुछ अप्राप्त है जो प्राप्त करना है। फिर भी मैं कर्तव्य कर्म में लगा रहता हूँ।

Meaning (English): O Partha (Arjuna), there is nothing in the three worlds that I am obliged to do. Nor is there anything unattained that I desire to attain—yet I engage in action (karma).

This shloka is spoken by Lord Krishna to emphasize the value of selfless action (nishkama karma). Here's a breakdown of its deeper meaning:

"Na me pārtha asti kartavyam" - Krishna says that He, as the Supreme Lord, has no duties to perform. He is complete, self-sufficient, and beyond the cycle of karma.

"Triṣu lokeṣu kiñcana" - In all the three realms (heaven, earth, and the netherworld), He lacks no possession or position. He doesn't act out of compulsion or desire.

"Nānavāptam avāptavyam" - There's nothing unattained that He needs to gain. Unlike humans who act to fulfill needs, He acts out of choice, not necessity.

"Varta eva ca karmaṇi" - Still, He continues to perform actions. Why? To set an example and maintain the cosmic order (loka-sangraha).

This is a powerful lesson in leadership and responsibility. Even though Krishna is beyond all duties, He chooses to act for the benefit of the world. It's a divine expression of detached duty and purpose-driven action.

श्लोक 3.23

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः ।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः ॥२३॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे पार्थ! यदि मैं सदा कर्म करने में सावधान न रहूँ, तो मनुष्य सर्व प्रकार से मेरे मार्ग का ही अनुकरण करेंगे।

Meaning (English): O Partha, if I did not carefully perform prescribed duties at all times, then all men would follow My path in every way.

In this shloka, Lord Krishna is emphasizing the importance of performing karma (action/duty) — even for those who are beyond the need for personal gain or spiritual elevation, such as himself.

He tells Arjuna:

Even though He is God and has no obligation to perform any worldly duties (since He has nothing to gain or lose), He still engages actively in karma. Why? Because people tend to imitate their leaders, especially those they revere. If Krishna were to renounce action, the world would follow suit and fall into chaos and inaction.

This shloka is an expression of leadership by example.

It also answers a subtle question: If someone has no personal attachment or desire, can they renounce all work? Krishna says no — because society depends on those at the top to set an example.

श्लोक 3.24

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम् ।
सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः ॥२४॥

Meaning (Hindi): यदि मैं कर्म न करूं, तो ये समस्त लोक नष्ट हो जाएंगे। मैं संकर (वर्ण-व्यवस्था का उल्लंघन) का कारण बनूंगा और इन प्राणियों का विनाश कर दूंगा।

Meaning (English): If I did not perform prescribed duties, O Partha, all these worlds would perish. I would be the cause of creating social disorder, and I would destroy the peace of all living beings.

This verse is part of Lord Krishna's explanation to Arjuna on why action (karma) must not be abandoned, even by the wise or realized souls like Krishna himself.

Krishna is the Supreme Being, yet He takes on a human form and performs worldly duties. Here, He sets an example:

If even He, the most exalted, stops performing actions, others in society would follow His example and also abandon their responsibilities.

This would lead to social chaos (sankara) and moral degradation, as people imitate their leaders.

The world functions on the principle of karma (action/duty). If that principle is violated, dharma collapses, and society disintegrates.

Hence, Krishna acts not out of personal need, but for the welfare of the world (loka-sangraha). This shloka emphasizes the interconnectedness of all beings. One person's actions, especially a leader's, ripple out to affect many.

श्लोक 3.25

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत ।
कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम् ॥२५॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे भारत! जैसे अज्ञानी पुरुष फल की आसक्ति से कर्म करते हैं, वैसे ही ज्ञानी मनुष्य भी लोक-संग्रह (जन-कल्याण) की इच्छा से आसक्ति के बिना ही कर्म करें।

Meaning (English): O Bharata (Arjuna), just as the ignorant perform actions with attachment to results, so should the wise act without attachment—for the sake of guiding the people and maintaining social order (loka-sangraha).

This verse addresses the conduct of a wise person—one who has spiritual knowledge (jnani). Lord Krishna makes a key distinction here between the ignorant and the wise:

1. Ignorant (avidvamsah): These are people who do not have spiritual knowledge.
They perform actions with attachment to the results (desire for success, reward, pleasure, etc.).
They are driven by ego, desires, or societal expectations.

2. Wise (vidvan): These are those who know the truth about the Self (Atman) and the illusory nature of the material world.
Though they may be inwardly detached, they still engage in action.
They do so without attachment to the results—purely to set an example or to contribute to society (loka-sangraha).

3. Loka-Sangraha (लोक-संग्रह): It means welfare of the world or social harmony.
If the wise were to abandon action, thinking they are beyond karma, others might follow suit, leading to chaos and inactivity.

So, Krishna urges the wise to act, not out of personal desire, but out of responsibility and compassion.

श्लोक 3.26

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम् ।
जोषयेत् सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान् युक्तः समाचरन् ॥२६॥

Meaning (Hindi): ज्ञानी मनुष्य को अज्ञानी कर्म में आसक्त लोगों की बुद्धि में भ्रम उत्पन्न नहीं करना चाहिए। स्वयं सम्यक् आचरण करते हुए, उन्हें भी समस्त कर्मों में प्रवृत्त करना चाहिए।

Meaning (English): The wise should not unsettle the minds of the ignorant who are attached to action; rather, by performing all actions in the right spirit, the wise should inspire them to act as well.

This verse is about practical wisdom and social sensitivity. Here's a deeper explanation:

Context: Lord Krishna is speaking to Arjuna about the importance of Karma Yoga — the path of selfless action. By now, Krishna has established that a wise person acts without attachment and for the welfare of the world.

Key Idea:
Wise people (jnanis) have realized that Atman (Self) is not the doer, and actions are merely performed by the gunas (qualities) of nature.
However, ignorant people (ajñānīs) are still attached to their actions, believing “I am doing this” and expecting results.
If such people are suddenly told to stop action or act differently without proper understanding, it will confuse and demotivate them.
Hence, the wise should not disturb their belief or discourage them, but continue to perform actions in a detached and exemplary way, inspiring others through example.

Practical Wisdom:
Real transformation takes time and tact. You don't force people to abandon action or change overnight.
Teach by living the teaching, not preaching.
Even if someone doesn't understand the deeper philosophy, let them do their duties sincerely. Spiritual evolution is gradual.

श्लोक 3.27

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः ।
अहंकारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहम् इति मन्यते ॥२७॥

Meaning (Hindi): प्रकृति के गुणों से सभी कर्म स्वभावतः होते हैं। जो अहंकार से मोहित हुआ है, वह सोचता है कि "मैं ही कर्ता हूँ"।

Meaning (English): All actions are performed by the modes (gunas) of material nature (prakriti). But one whose mind is deluded by ego thinks, “I am the doer.”

This verse explains the illusion of doership caused by ego (ahankara).

Prakriti (Nature): Refers to material nature governed by three gunas: sattva (goodness), rajas (passion), and tamas (ignorance).
Gunas (Qualities): They compel actions, not the individual soul (Atman).
Ahankara (Ego): The false identification of the self with the body and mind, leading one to think "I am the doer".
Vimūḍha-ātmā (Deluded soul): One who is confused about their true nature.

Philosophical Message: The soul (ātman) is eternal, non-active, and only a witness.
All actions are driven by nature - bodily instincts, emotions, desires, tendencies - which are all expressions of the gunas.
But due to ego, a person falsely identifies with the body and its actions, claiming "I am the doer".
This is the root of bondage and karma - the illusion that we are the cause of action and result, rather than recognizing we are simply instruments.

Connection to Karma Yoga: Krishna is reinforcing the idea that one should act without ego or attachment.
Seeing oneself as an instrument of divine nature (prakriti) frees one from the binding effects of karma.

श्लोक 3.28

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः ।
गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते ॥२८॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे महाबाहो! तत्व को जानने वाला मनुष्य गुणों और कर्मों के विभाग को समझकर यह जानता है कि गुण ही गुणों में बरतते हैं, इस प्रकार सोचकर वह आसक्त नहीं होता।

Meaning (English): O mighty-armed Arjuna, one who understands the truth about the divisions of the modes of nature and their functions, realizes that it is the gunas (modes) acting upon the gunas. Therefore, he does not become attached.

To fully appreciate this shloka, we must understand the context of "gunas" and the self in Sankhya and Karma Yoga philosophy:

1. What are Gunas?
In the Bhagavad Gita, all actions in the material world are governed by the three gunas:
Sattva (purity, knowledge, harmony)
Rajas (passion, action, restlessness)
Tamas (ignorance, inertia, darkness)
These gunas are the qualities of prakriti (material nature). Every being and action is a combination of these gunas.

2. Who is a Tattvavit (Knower of Truth)?
A tattvavit is one who understands the true nature of the Self (Atman) and the mechanism of action (karma) as being driven by prakriti (nature) through these gunas.
Such a person knows:
"I am not the body or the mind."
"Actions are not done by the real Self but by the modes of nature acting through the body-mind mechanism."

3. Gunāḥ Guṇeṣu Vartanta - Modes act upon modes
This profound statement means: "The qualities (gunas) of nature act upon the objects (also composed of gunas). It is prakriti acting within itself."
So, for instance:
A rajasic mind may be attracted to stimulating experiences—this is simply rajas interacting with rajas.
The Self (Atman) is not involved—it merely observes.
Thus, a wise person does not get entangled or attached, knowing it's just nature interacting with itself, like waves moving in the ocean.

4. Freedom from Attachment
The person who understands this does not get:
Egoistic ("I am the doer")
Attached ("This is mine", "I want this", "I fear that")
Disturbed by success, failure, or opinions
Because they see that all action is just nature's play.

श्लोक 3.29

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु ।
तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत् ॥२९॥

Meaning (Hindi): प्रकृति के गुणों से मोहित लोग गुणों के द्वारा होने वाले कर्मों में आसक्त हो जाते हैं। परन्तु सम्पूर्ण तत्व को जानने वाला ज्ञानी मनुष्य उन अल्पबुद्धि, अपूर्णज्ञान वाले मूढ़ लोगों को विचलित नहीं करता।

Meaning (English): Those who are deluded by the modes of material nature become attached to the actions of the gunas. But the wise, who know the whole truth, should not disturb the minds of the ignorant who are unaware of the complete picture.

This shloka continues Krishna's teaching on Karma Yoga and how a wise person (kṛtsnavit) should behave in society.

✅ Key Points:
Many people are deluded by prakriti (nature) and its gunas - sattva, rajas, tamas - and get deeply attached to actions and results.
They are called अकृत्स्नविदः - those who do not see the full picture (i.e., don't understand the Self or the deeper truths of Karma Yoga).
These people are मन्दाः - simple-minded or less spiritually evolved.
A wise person (kṛtsnavit) who knows that the soul is different from the body and the actions are done by prakriti, should not disturb or unsettle these ignorant ones by abruptly telling them to renounce or stop acting.

Krishna is advising spiritual compassion and maturity - don't push higher truths onto people who aren't ready.

श्लोक 3.30

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा ।
निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः ॥३०॥

Meaning (Hindi): अपने सारे कर्मों को मुझमें अर्पित करके, अध्यात्मबुद्धि से युक्त होकर, ममता से रहित और मानसिक संताप (चिंता, भय, मोह) से रहित होकर तू युद्ध कर।

Meaning (English): Renounce all your actions unto Me, with your mind centered on the Self (spiritual consciousness). Free from desire, selfishness, and mental agitation, engage in battle.

This verse is a profound teaching on how to act without attachment and with spiritual awareness. Here's a breakdown:

1. "मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्य"
(Surrender all actions unto Me)
Krishna is asking Arjuna (and all of us) to perform actions as an offering to the Divine, without the egoistic notion of "I am the doer." This is Karma Yoga — the path of selfless action.

2. "अध्यात्मचेतसा"
(With a mind rooted in spiritual consciousness)
Our intellect and awareness should be focused on the Self (the Atman), not the material body or ego. One should act from a place of inner clarity and divine purpose.

3. "निर्ममः"
(Without possessiveness)
Do not think "this is mine" — whether it is wealth, position, results of work, or relationships. Acting without possessiveness removes anxiety and promotes equanimity.

4. "विगतज्वरः"
(Free from mental fever/agitation)
When one acts with detachment and surrender, the fever of worry, doubt, fear, and stress disappears. Krishna says, Fight — not with hatred, but with a calm, detached mind.

श्लोक 3.31

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः ।
श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः ॥३१॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो मनुष्य मेरी इस शिक्षा का नित्य पालन करते हैं, श्रद्धा और निरभिमान (दोषारोपण रहित) होकर, वे समस्त कर्मों के बंधन से मुक्त हो जाते हैं।

Meaning (English): Those people who constantly follow this teaching of Mine, with faith and without envy, are freed from the bondage of actions.

"Ye Me Matam Idam Nityam Anutishthanti"
Those who follow My teachings (the principles of Karma Yoga, or selfless action) consistently and regularly, not just occasionally or when convenient.

"Shraddhavanto Anasuyanto"
With faith (shraddha) and without envy or fault-finding (anasuya). This means:
Believing in the wisdom and authority of the divine. Not criticizing or doubting the teacher or the teachings (especially the divine instructions from Krishna).

"Muchyante Te'pi Karmabhiḥ"
They too are liberated from the bondage of karma (action). Even though they perform actions in the world, such people are not bound by the consequences, because:
They act selflessly.
They act as a service to the Divine, not for personal gain.

श्लोक 3.32

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम् ।
सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः ॥३२॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो लोग मेरी इन शिक्षाओं की निंदा करते हैं और मेरे इस मत का पालन नहीं करते, उन्हें मूर्ख समझो। वे सब ज्ञान से भ्रष्ट और विवेकहीन हैं, और उनका विनाश निश्चित है।

Meaning (English): But those who, out of envy, do not follow My teachings and do not practice them—know them to be deluded in all knowledge, senseless, and doomed to destruction.

Context of the Shloka
This verse follows Lord Krishna's explanation of the importance of Karma Yoga—selfless action without attachment to the results. He encourages Arjuna to act according to dharma (duty) without desire for the outcome. In this verse, Krishna warns against those who reject His teachings.

Abhyasūyantaḥ (अभ्यसूयन्तः) - Those who criticize or are envious.
Na Anutiṣṭhanti (न अनुतिष्ठन्ति) - Do not follow/practice.
Sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhān (सर्व-ज्ञान-विमूढान्) - Deluded in all kinds of knowledge.
Naṣṭān (नष्टान्) - Lost or destroyed.
Acetasaḥ (अचेतसः) - Unwise, lacking discrimination or wisdom.

This verse is a strong statement from Krishna. He categorizes people who:
Reject His teachings out of arrogance, pride, or ignorance,
Refuse to perform their duties even when they are aware of them,
Deny the validity of the Gita's wisdom, and
Criticize the path of selfless action (Karma Yoga)
—as individuals who are deluded, lacking true wisdom, and are headed toward spiritual ruin.

Such people may appear learned externally, but Krishna says their inner wisdom is absent. They are misusing intellect, often driven by ego or selfish desires, and ultimately move away from liberation (moksha).

श्लोक 3.33

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि ।
प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति ॥३३॥

Meaning (Hindi): ज्ञानी पुरुष भी अपनी ही प्रकृति के अनुसार ही कार्य करता है। सभी प्राणी अपनी-अपनी प्रकृति का ही अनुसरण करते हैं। दमन (जबरदस्ती दबाना) क्या करेगा?

Meaning (English): Even a wise person acts according to their own nature. All living beings follow their nature. What can repression accomplish?

This verse speaks about human nature (प्रकृति) and the limits of self-control through suppression.

🔹 1. Even the Wise Act According to Their Nature
Lord Krishna says that even a person of knowledge behaves according to their innate tendencies, shaped by their gunas (Sattva, Rajas, Tamas) and past karma. Knowledge alone does not completely erase one's basic nature. Awareness can guide behavior, but habitual nature still exerts a strong influence.

🔹 2. All Beings Follow Their Nature
Every living being has a natural disposition (स्वभाव), formed over lifetimes. Plants grow upward, fire burns, rivers flow — similarly, humans have inclinations based on physical, mental, and emotional tendencies. We are pulled by these patterns.

🔹 3. Suppression Doesn't Help
Trying to forcibly control or suppress one's nature without understanding or transforming it doesn't work in the long run. Repression often leads to internal conflict or eventual breakdown. Real transformation must come from inner growth, not external pressure.

श्लोक 3.34

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ ।
तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ ॥३४॥

Meaning (Hindi): हर इन्द्रिय (ज्ञानेन्द्रियों और कर्मेन्द्रियों) के विषय में राग (आकर्षण) और द्वेष (विकर्षण) स्वाभाविक रूप से स्थित होते हैं। मनुष्य को उन दोनों के अधीन नहीं होना चाहिए क्योंकि वे आत्मोन्नति के मार्ग में बाधक हैं।

Meaning (English): Attachment (rāga) and aversion (dveṣa) are naturally present in every sense object with respect to the senses. One should not come under their control, for they are obstacles on the path of self-realization.

This shloka is a guidance on sense control and detachment, which are central themes of Karma Yoga.

Indriyasya indriyasya arthe: Every sense (like eyes, ears, tongue, etc.) is naturally drawn to its respective objects (form, sound, taste).

Rāga-dveṣa: The duality of attraction (rāga) and repulsion (dveṣa) is embedded in human nature. For example, one might feel:
Rāga (attachment) for sweets
Dveṣa (aversion) to bitterness or heat

Tayor na vaśam āgacchet: Krishna warns—do not become a slave to these feelings. Don't let your actions be dictated by likes and dislikes.

Tau hyasya paripanthinau: These two are enemies to spiritual progress. They pull the mind into emotional turbulence, cloud judgment, and disrupt disciplined living.

श्लोक 3.35

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

श्रेयान् स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् ।
स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः ॥३५॥

Meaning (Hindi): अपने धर्म में दोष होने पर भी वह श्रेष्ठ है, दूसरे का धर्म भली-भांति निभाने पर भी भय को उत्पन्न करने वाला होता है। अपने धर्म में मरना भी कल्याणकारी है, परधर्म तो भय को ही उत्पन्न करता है।

Meaning (English): It is better to fail while performing one's own duty (swadharma), even if done imperfectly, than to succeed in another's duty (paradharma). Death while performing one's own dharma is better; performing another's dharma is dangerous.

This shloka is a powerful message about authenticity, self-identity, and duty.

Swadharma vs Paradharma:
Swadharma refers to one's own prescribed duties, based on nature (guna) and position (varna, not merely caste but aptitude).
Paradharma means duties belonging to someone else — not aligned with your nature or role.

Imperfect but Authentic vs Perfect but Alien:
Krishna says it's more spiritually and ethically uplifting to perform your own role imperfectly than to do someone else's role perfectly.
The quality of action (viguna - with faults) is secondary; the alignment with your inner nature is primary.

Why is Paradharma 'Bhayavaha' (fearful/dangerous)?
Because it creates internal conflict, lack of satisfaction, and often leads to failure or downfall despite external success.
It disconnects you from your purpose (svabhava), which can cause emotional distress, guilt, fear, or even karmic repercussions.

Death in one's dharma is better:
This is metaphorical and literal. Even if performing your dharma leads to difficulty or death, it's a noble path, leading to spiritual evolution.

श्लोक 3.36

अर्जुन उवाच ।

अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः ।
अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः ॥३६॥

Meaning (Hindi): अर्जुन ने कहा: हे वार्ष्णेय (श्रीकृष्ण)! मनुष्य अनिच्छा होते हुए भी किसके द्वारा प्रेरित होकर पाप कर्म करता है, मानो बलात् विवश किया गया हो?

Meaning (English): Arjuna asks: O Krishna, what is it that impels a person to commit sinful acts, even unwillingly, as if driven by force?

This verse marks the beginning of a very profound question from Arjuna that resonates with the inner moral struggles of every human being.

Arjuna observes that even when a person does not want to do wrong, they end up doing it, as if something more powerful is pushing them.
He asks Krishna: What is this force that compels even the wise or disciplined person to commit actions against their values or desires?
The use of the word "बलात्" (balāt) — meaning forcibly or against one's will — shows the intense inner conflict.
Arjuna's question is not just philosophical; it is psychological and spiritual. It touches on the root of human behavior, especially when it contradicts our intentions or ideals.

श्लोक 3.37

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः ।
महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम् ॥३७॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान श्रीकृष्ण ने कहा: यह काम (इच्छा/वासना) है, यह क्रोध (anger) है — जो रजोगुण से उत्पन्न होता है, अत्यंत भक्षण करने वाला और महापापी है। जान लो कि यही इस संसार में मनुष्य का शत्रु है।

Meaning (English): Lord Krishna said: It is desire, it is anger, born of the mode of passion (Rajo Guna), all-devouring and extremely sinful. Know this to be the enemy in this world.

This shloka answers Arjuna's question from the previous verse (3.36): "What is it that forces a person to act sinfully, even unwillingly?"
