Desire (Kāma) and Anger (Krodha)
Desire is the root cause. When desire is fulfilled, it leads to attachment and pride.
When desire is unfulfilled, it turns into anger.
Both are born from Rajo Guna, the mode of passion, which drives activity, ambition, restlessness, and indulgence.

All-Devouring (Mahāśanaḥ)
Desire and anger are compared to a fire that can never be fully satisfied.
The more you feed them, the more they grow.

Extremely Sinful (Mahā-Pāpmā)
These two are responsible for clouding human judgment and leading people away from dharma (righteous action).
They are not external enemies — but internal enemies, more dangerous than any outside threat.

Know Them as Your Enemy (Viddhi Enam Vairiṇam)
Lord Krishna personifies desire and anger as enemies one must conquer.
They bind the soul and keep it rotating in the cycle of karma and rebirth.

श्लोक 3.38

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथाऽऽदर्शो मलेन च ।
यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम् ॥३८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जैसे अग्नि को धुएँ से, दर्पण को मैल से, और गर्भस्थ शिशु को गर्भ से ढक दिया जाता है, वैसे ही यह ज्ञान कामना (इच्छा) से ढक दिया जाता है।

Meaning (English): Just as fire is covered by smoke, a mirror by dust, and an embryo by the womb, so is knowledge covered by desire (kāma).

This verse uses three analogies to explain how desire clouds wisdom:

Fire covered by smoke -
The fire is there, but the smoke prevents its full expression. This symbolizes mild obstruction. It hints that knowledge exists but is partially veiled by desires.

Mirror covered by dust -
A dirty mirror does not reflect clearly, although the potential is there. This represents a moderate obstruction, where the individual's clarity and self-awareness are dulled.

Embryo covered by the womb -
The embryo is completely hidden. This analogy shows complete obstruction, symbolizing a mind fully consumed by desire, where spiritual knowledge is completely inaccessible.

Philosophical Essence:
Desire (कामना / kāma) is the root cause of delusion.
It veils wisdom, just as natural elements hide objects in the above analogies.
Knowledge is always within us, but our desires distort or hide it.
These desires are often linked to attachment, greed, and ego, and they take us away from the higher Self (Atman).

श्लोक 3.39

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा ।
कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुर्निर्विणेन चाशिना ॥३९॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे कौन्तेय! यह ज्ञान कामरूप (इच्छा के रूप) वाले इस तृप्त न होने वाले नित्य शत्रु (वासना) द्वारा आच्छादित (ढका) है, जो ज्ञानी का भी शत्रु है।

Meaning (English): O Kaunteya (Arjuna), this wisdom is veiled by the eternal enemy of the wise—desire, which is insatiable and burns like fire.

This shloka highlights a critical psychological insight from the Gita.

"Āvṛtaṁ jñānam" - The knowledge, or innate wisdom of the Self (the Atman), is covered or veiled.
"Etena" - By this, i.e., desire or lust (kāma).
"Jñāninaḥ nitya-vairiṇā" - This desire is described as the eternal enemy of the wise.
"Kāma-rūpeṇa" - Desire takes many forms, making it harder to detect and control.
"Durnirvīreṇa chāśinā" - It is insatiable, like a fire that keeps growing when fed.

Desire (kāma) is portrayed not just as a moral or ethical issue but as a fundamental obstacle to realizing one's true nature. This shloka comes right after Krishna explains how knowledge is the purifier and liberator. But here, he introduces the main antagonist — desire — which clouds and contaminates that knowledge.

Why is Desire the "Eternal Enemy"?
It never ends: One fulfilled desire leads to another.
It corrupts discrimination: Even the wise lose clarity under its influence.
It creates attachment, delusion, and suffering.
It grows stronger if not checked, like fire fed with fuel.

श्लोक 3.40

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते ।
एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम् ॥४०॥

Meaning (Hindi): इंद्रियाँ, मन और बुद्धि — यह तीनों कामना के वास स्थान (आधार) माने गए हैं। यह (कामना) इनके द्वारा देहधारी जीव का ज्ञान आच्छादित (ढँक) करके उसे मोह में डाल देती है।

Meaning (English): The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its (desire's) seat. Through these, desire deludes the embodied soul by covering its knowledge.

This verse is part of the discussion where Krishna explains the root cause of human delusion and downfall — primarily Kama (desire or lust). Here's a breakdown:

"Indriyani" (The senses):
These are the organs of perception (eyes, ears, skin, tongue, nose). They are the gateways through which the external world influences the inner self.

"Manah" (Mind):
The mind processes sensory inputs and forms attachments, preferences, and aversions.

"Buddhih" (Intellect):
The decision-making faculty, which has the ability to discriminate between right and wrong.

"Asya adhiṣṭhānam" (Its abode):
The shloka says that lust (or desire) resides in these three — senses, mind, and intellect.

"Avṛitya jñānam" (Covers knowledge):
Desire envelops or veils the true knowledge, leading to ignorance.

"Vimohayati dehinam" (Deludes the embodied soul):
Once knowledge is covered, the soul gets deluded, loses discrimination, and acts against Dharma or higher good.

Philosophical Insights and Meaning
Desire is not just a sensory issue; it penetrates even the intellect. That means even intelligent or wise people can fall prey to it. It acts like a veil over wisdom — even if a person knows what is right, he may still do the wrong thing under the influence of desire.
This shloka beautifully explains how human error happens: It starts at the senses → grows in the mind → hijacks the intellect → and then, deludes the soul.

श्लोक 3.41

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ ।
पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम् ॥४१॥

Meaning (Hindi): इसलिए, हे भरतश्रेष्ठ (अर्जुन)! तू पहले इन्द्रियों को वश में कर, फिर इस ज्ञान और विज्ञान को नष्ट करने वाले पाप रूपी काम (वासनाओं) का नाश कर।

Meaning (English): Therefore, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), restrain your senses first, and then destroy this sinful desire which is the destroyer of knowledge and wisdom.

This shloka continues Krishna's explanation on how desire (kāma), arising from rajoguna (mode of passion), leads to a person's spiritual and intellectual downfall. In the previous verses (especially 3.39 and 3.40), Krishna identified lust/desire as the enemy of the soul. Now, He instructs on how to deal with this inner enemy.

"Tasmāt" (Therefore):
This connects logically to the previous verses. Since desire clouds the intellect and causes delusion, action is needed.

"Indriyāṇi ādau niyamya":
Krishna advises starting with sensory control. The senses are the entry points through which desires enter the mind. If we control what we see, hear, touch, etc., we can reduce the fuel of desire.

"Pāpmānaṁ prajahi":
Krishna refers to desire as a sinful force, the root of many evils (greed, anger, envy, delusion). He says to slay this enemy - not with weapons, but with discipline, control, and awareness.

"Jñāna-vijñāna-nāśanam":
Desire doesn't just obstruct theoretical knowledge (jñāna) but also practical realization (vijñāna). Hence, it not only blocks understanding but also disrupts spiritual experience and wise action.

श्लोक 3.42

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः ।
मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः ॥४२॥

Meaning (Hindi): इन्द्रियाँ श्रेष्ठ मानी गई हैं, इन्द्रियों से बढ़कर मन है, मन से भी ऊपर बुद्धि है, और बुद्धि से भी श्रेष्ठ वह आत्मा है।

Meaning (English): The senses are said to be superior (to the body), the mind is higher than the senses, the intellect is higher than the mind, and higher than the intellect is the Self (Atman).

This shloka is part of the spiritual psychology laid out by Lord Krishna. He is helping Arjuna understand the hierarchy of human functioning in the context of controlling desires and performing one's duty (karma yoga).

1. Senses (Indriyani):
The first layer that connects us to the external world.
They are powerful but can be influenced.
If uncontrolled, they chase sensory pleasures and lead to attachment and distraction.

2. Mind (Manah):
Manages thoughts, emotions, and desires.
It directs the senses, deciding where to focus.
However, the mind is often fickle and swayed by desires.

3. Intellect (Buddhi):
The discriminative power that judges right from wrong.
It can override the impulses of the mind and senses.
A sharp, disciplined intellect can guide one toward dharma (righteous action).

4. Self (Atman):
The eternal, unchanging consciousness.
It is the true Self beyond physical, mental, and intellectual identities.
When realized, it frees one from desires, ego, and ignorance.
Lord Krishna reveals this hierarchy to guide Arjuna (and all of us) on how to rise above the pull of desires and act from a place of wisdom and Self-realization.

श्लोक 3.43

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना ।
जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम् ॥४३॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे महाबाहो (शक्तिशाली अर्जुन)! इस प्रकार तू बुद्धि से आत्मा को श्रेष्ठ जानकर, मन को आत्मा के द्वारा वश में करके उस कामरूपी (इच्छा, वासना रूपी) दुष्ट शत्रु का नाश कर।

Meaning (English): O mighty-armed Arjuna, thus knowing the Self to be transcendental to material intelligence, steady the mind by spiritual strength, and conquer this insatiable enemy known as desire.

In 3.42, Krishna is presenting a hierarchy of control — a ladder of inner strength that helps us understand how to overcome desire:

Body < Senses < Mind < Intellect < Self (Ātman)
This is like showing the levels of command inside us:
The senses tempt us with pleasures.
The mind processes and reacts emotionally.
The intellect evaluates and decides.
But even higher is the Self, your true, eternal consciousness, untouched by desires.

Then, in 3.43, Krishna tells Arjuna:
“Now that you understand this hierarchy, use it to win the inner war against desire.”
So:
Recognize that desire operates through the senses and mind.
Use your intellect to discriminate, but even intellect must surrender to the Self's wisdom — pure awareness.
Through this spiritual vision and discipline, conquer desire, the real enemy, which binds the soul to karma and suffering.

1. The Real Battle Is Within
Krishna is not just preparing Arjuna for physical war; he's equipping him for the spiritual war against desire — which leads to anger, delusion, and loss of purpose (as discussed in 2.62-2.63).
Desire is not eliminated by indulging it — it grows stronger. It must be dismantled by rising above it.

2. You Are Higher Than Your Mind
The mind feels attraction/repulsion.
But you are not your mind. You are the witnessing Self, beyond thoughts and senses.
Once you realize this, you can step back and respond wisely, not impulsively.

3. The Role of Intellect and the Self
The intellect (buddhi) acts as the guardian — deciding what is right and wrong.
But even intellect is subject to ego, bias, or confusion.
So Krishna says: “Go further — awaken to the Self — the unchanging truth inside you.”

4. Desire Is the Root of Bondage
Earlier in 3.37, Krishna clearly identifies:
“It is desire, born of passion (rajas), that is the enemy.”
3.42-3.43 explain how to defeat this enemy through spiritual knowledge and inner control.

Click to view Itinerary
Click to view summary

श्लोक 4.1

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम् ।
विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् ॥१॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान श्रीकृष्ण ने कहा: मैंने यह अविनाशी योग (ज्ञान) पहले विवस्वान (सूर्यदेव) को बताया। विवस्वान ने इसे मनु को कहा, और मनु ने इसे इक्ष्वाकु को बताया।

Meaning (English): Lord Krishna said: I instructed this imperishable yoga (divine knowledge) to Vivasvan (the Sun God); Vivasvan taught it to Manu (the father of mankind), and Manu in turn instructed it to Ikshvaku (a royal sage and ancestor of Lord Rama).

This verse marks the beginning of Chapter 4 - Jnana Karma Sanyasa Yoga (The Yoga of Knowledge and Renunciation of Action).

Context:
Lord Krishna is highlighting the eternal lineage and importance of the knowledge He is about to reveal to Arjuna. He says this yoga (spiritual science) is not something newly created but is timeless and was handed down through generations.

Avyayam Yoga (Imperishable Knowledge):
Refers to the eternal truths of Karma, Bhakti, and Jnana — the knowledge of how to live a righteous life, attain liberation, and understand one's divine nature.

Vivasvan → Manu → Ikshvaku:
Vivasvan (Sun God) is symbolic of illumination and enlightenment. He received this knowledge first.
Manu: The progenitor of mankind; represents moral law (Manusmriti).
Ikshvaku: The founder of the solar dynasty (Suryavansha), to which Lord Rama belongs.

Guru-Shishya Parampara (Spiritual Lineage):
Knowledge was traditionally passed from guru to disciple. Krishna shows that He is part of that divine succession and hence the authority of the knowledge He imparts.
Indirectly, Krishna is preparing Arjuna for the revelation that He (Krishna) is the original source of this knowledge, subtly hinting at His divine nature (Avatarhood).

श्लोक 4.2

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

एवं परम्परा-प्राप्तम् इमं राजर्षयो विदुः ।
स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप ॥२॥

Meaning (Hindi): इस प्रकार यह योग परंपरा से प्राप्त हुआ, जिसे राजर्षियों ने जाना। लेकिन, हे परंतप अर्जुन! कालक्रम में यह योग लुप्त हो गया।

Meaning (English): This supreme knowledge (Yoga) was thus received through the lineage of disciplic succession, and the royal sages understood it in that way. But over the course of time, O Arjuna, this yoga was lost from the world.

In this verse, Lord Krishna is continuing from verse 1 where He stated that He first taught this eternal knowledge (Karma Yoga or Jnana Yoga) to Vivasvan (the Sun God), who passed it to Manu, and then it went to Ikshvaku, thereby establishing a disciplic succession (parampara).

Now, in this verse, Krishna emphasizes that:
This knowledge of Yoga (Self-realization, detachment in action, divine wisdom) was not something newly created; it was passed through generations via an unbroken chain of enlightened royal sages called Rajrishis (राजर्षि = राजा + ऋषि). These were kings who were also sages, exemplifying wisdom and leadership.
However, over time, due to neglect, ego, materialism, misinterpretation, or lack of qualified teachers and students, this ancient knowledge was lost. The parampara (disciplic chain) was broken, and thus the original essence of Yoga was no longer preserved.
The term "परन्तप" (Parantapa) is a respectful way of addressing Arjuna, meaning "scorcher of enemies," emphasizing his warrior nature. Krishna addresses him this way to catch his attention before revealing the need to revive this lost wisdom.

श्लोक 4.3

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः ।
भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम् ॥३॥

Meaning (Hindi): वही यह परम रहस्यरूप प्राचीन योग आज मैंने तुझसे कहा है, क्योंकि तू मेरा भक्त तथा मित्र है। यह उत्तम रहस्य है।

Meaning (English): That same ancient yoga has now been told to you by Me today, because you are My devotee and My friend; this is the supreme secret.

In this shloka, Lord Krishna continues His explanation of the eternal knowledge of Karma Yoga, which He has passed on from generation to generation, starting with the Sun God (as stated in the previous shloka). Here, He says:

“Sa evāyaṁ mayā te'dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ”
"This very ancient yoga has now been told to you by Me today" - Krishna emphasizes that what He is teaching is not a new philosophy, but a timeless truth that has existed for ages.

“bhakto'si me sakhā ceti”
"Because you are My devotee and My friend" - Krishna reveals why He is imparting this sacred knowledge to Arjuna: because Arjuna is not only a devoted follower (bhakta) but also a close friend (sakha). This dual relationship represents both spiritual receptivity and emotional closeness, making Arjuna worthy of receiving this knowledge.

“rahasyaṁ hyetaduttamam”
"This is the supreme secret" - The knowledge of Karma Yoga is described as the supreme spiritual secret. It's not just about performing actions, but doing so with the right attitude and understanding, which leads to liberation (moksha).

श्लोक 4.4

अर्जुन उवाच ।

अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः ।
कथं एतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति ॥४॥

Meaning (Hindi): अर्जुन ने कहा: आपका जन्म तो अभी हुआ है, और विवस्वान का जन्म तो बहुत पहले हुआ था। फिर मैं कैसे समझूं कि आपने प्रारंभ में यह ज्ञान उन्हें दिया था?

Meaning (English): Arjuna said: Your birth is recent, whereas the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun God) was in ancient times. How am I to understand that You instructed this science to him in the beginning?

This verse is Arjuna's doubt or curious question in response to Lord Krishna's statement in verse 4.1, where Krishna says that He taught this eternal knowledge of Yoga to the Sun God, Vivasvan, at the beginning of creation.

But now Arjuna is perplexed.
He sees Krishna as his contemporary, a human prince.
He knows that Vivasvan (the Sun God) is a very ancient divine being.
Arjuna wonders, "How can someone like you, who was born recently, have taught this to someone so ancient?"
This question is rational and logical from Arjuna's perspective, as he only sees Krishna's human form, not His divine nature.

श्लोक 4.5

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन ।
तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप ॥५॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान श्रीकृष्ण ने कहा: हे परंतप अर्जुन! मेरे और तुम्हारे बहुत-से जन्म हो चुके हैं। मुझे वे सभी स्मरण हैं, परंतु तुम उन्हें नहीं जानते।

Meaning (English): Shri Bhagavan said: Many births of Mine and yours have passed, O Arjuna. I know them all, but you do not know them, O scorcher of enemies.

This verse is part of a profound revelation where Lord Krishna begins to explain His divine nature and His incarnation on Earth. The context is that Arjuna has just been told that Krishna appears from age to age (4.4), and Arjuna questions how that is possible since Krishna appears to be his contemporary.

In response, Krishna makes three important points in this shloka:

1. Both Arjuna and Krishna have taken many births
Krishna confirms that both He and Arjuna have taken numerous births. This introduces the concept of rebirth or reincarnation — a fundamental tenet of Sanatana Dharma (Hindu philosophy). Unlike what we perceive with a single lifetime, our soul goes through many cycles of birth and death.

2. Krishna remembers all His births
Krishna, being divine, remembers all His past incarnations, actions, and roles. This shows that He is not an ordinary being — but an Avatar (divine incarnation) who consciously takes birth for a purpose.

3. Arjuna, as a human, does not remember his past lives
This highlights the difference between an ordinary soul (jiva) and the Supreme Soul (Paramatma). Humans, due to their limited consciousness, cannot remember their past lives, which is why we struggle with understanding our karmic journey.

श्लोक 4.6

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन् ।
प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय सम्भवाम्यात्ममायया ॥६॥

Meaning (Hindi): हालाँकि मैं अजन्मा (जन्मरहित) और अविनाशी आत्मा हूँ और समस्त प्राणियों का स्वामी भी हूँ, फिर भी मैं अपनी योगमाया (दैवी शक्ति) के अधीन होकर अपनी स्वरूप शक्ति द्वारा प्रकट होता हूँ।

Meaning (English): Though I am unborn, imperishable, and the Lord of all beings, I manifest Myself by My own Yoga Maya (divine power), keeping My Prakriti (nature) under control.

In this verse, Lord Krishna explains His divine incarnation (avatar). Even though He is beyond birth and death, unchanging, and the supreme ruler of all beings, He chooses to take a human form to uphold dharma.

"Ajo'pi san" (Though I am unborn)
Krishna states that He is not born like ordinary beings. His divine nature transcends the physical processes of birth and death.

"Avyayātmā" (Imperishable self)
His spiritual identity is eternal, untouched by time or change, unlike the soul in the cycle of birth and rebirth.

"Bhūtānām īśvaraḥ api san" (Though I am the Lord of all beings)
Even though He is the supreme controller and creator, He is not obligated by karma like ordinary beings.

"Prakṛtim svām adhiṣṭhāya" (Residing in His own nature)
He takes form by controlling His divine nature, not under the influence of ignorance or compulsion.

"Sambhavāmi ātma-māyayā" (I appear through My own Maya or power)
Krishna does not take birth due to karma but manifests Himself voluntarily using His Yoga Maya, which is His divine creative power, distinct from the ordinary material illusion (Maya).

श्लोक 4.7

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत ।
अभ्युत्थानम् अधर्मस्य तदाऽअत्मानं सृजाम्यहम् ॥७॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे भारत (अर्जुन), जब-जब धर्म की हानि होती है और अधर्म की वृद्धि होती है, तब-तब मैं स्वयं की सृष्टि करता हूँ (अवतार लेता हूँ)।

Meaning (English): O Bharata (Arjuna), whenever there is a decline in righteousness (dharma) and a rise in unrighteousness (adharma), at that time I manifest Myself (take incarnation).

This shloka is one of the most quoted verses of the Bhagavad Gita and lays down the foundation of divine intervention in the world.

1. “Yada Yada hi Dharmasya Glanir Bhavati”
“Whenever there is a decline in righteousness (dharma)”: This refers to times when people lose moral values, duties are not followed, and chaos or spiritual degradation spreads in society.

2. “Abhyutthanam Adharmasya”
“And there is a rise in unrighteousness (adharma)”: This suggests a time when injustice, corruption, ego, cruelty, and unethical behavior become widespread.

3. “Tada Atmanam Srijamyaham”
“Then I manifest Myself (as an avatar)”: Lord Krishna explains His divine promise — He incarnates in human or divine form to restore balance by protecting the good and eliminating the evil.

He does not just create avatars arbitrarily — it's in response to the need for the restoration of cosmic order (Dharma-Sansthapanarthaya).

श्लोक 4.8

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम् ।
धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे ॥८॥

Meaning (Hindi): साधुजनों की रक्षा के लिए, दुष्टों के विनाश के लिए, और धर्म की स्थापना के लिए, मैं हर युग में अवतरित होता हूँ।

Meaning (English): For the protection of the righteous, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of dharma, I manifest Myself age after age.

This verse is part of a trio (verses 7, 8, and 9) where Lord Krishna reveals the purpose of His divine incarnations (avatars).

Paritrāṇāya sādhūnām - Protection of the virtuous:
The Lord incarnates to safeguard those who follow dharma, who live with integrity, devotion, and selflessness. “Sādhus” are not just saints, but anyone who strives to live a life aligned with truth and righteousness.

Vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām - Destruction of evil-doers:
This doesn't always mean physical annihilation. It can also refer to the destruction of ego, ignorance, adharma (unrighteousness), and harmful tendencies that destroy peace in society.

Dharma-sansthāpanārthāya - Establishing righteousness:
Dharma is not limited to religion—it means cosmic order, ethical duty, and moral responsibility. Whenever there is moral decline or confusion, the Lord appears to restore spiritual wisdom and ethical balance.

Sambhavāmi yuge yuge - I manifest in every age:
This suggests that divine intervention is not one-time. In every era (Yuga), when adharma rises, the Lord re-establishes dharma—sometimes through divine incarnations like Rama and Krishna, and sometimes through great souls, reformers, or even inner spiritual awakening in people.

श्लोक 4.9

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः ।
त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन ॥९॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे अर्जुन! जो पुरुष मेरे दिव्य जन्म और कर्म को तत्त्व से जानता है, वह इस शरीर का परित्याग करके फिर जन्म को नहीं प्राप्त होता, वह मुझे प्राप्त होता है।

Meaning (English): O Arjuna, one who truly understands the divine nature of My birth and actions, upon leaving the body, does not take birth again, but comes to Me alone.

This verse is a cornerstone of spiritual liberation (moksha) in the Bhagavad Gita.

"Janma karma cha me divyam"
Lord Krishna is saying that His birth and actions are not ordinary but divine (divyam). Unlike humans, who take birth due to karma and ignorance, Krishna incarnates out of compassion, by His own will, and for a higher purpose—to restore dharma.

"Yo vetti tattvatah"
If someone understands this in essence, not just intellectually but with real inner knowledge and realization...

"Tyaktva deham punar janma naiti"
...then when such a person leaves the body, they do not take birth again. This refers to freedom from the cycle of birth and death (samsara).

"Mam eti"
Instead, that person attains Krishna Himself — the Supreme Abode, or liberation (moksha).

Spiritual Meaning
Lord Krishna does not take birth due to karma (like we do), but rather descends (avatara) for divine purposes.
When we truly understand the divinity of Krishna — not just hear or read about it, but deeply realize it — our bondage to the material world ends.
This understanding is transformational, not just theoretical. It purifies the soul.

श्लोक 4.10

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः ।
बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः ॥१०॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो राग, भय और क्रोध से रहित होकर मेरे में मन लगाकर मेरे शरण में आए हैं, ऐसे बहुत से पुरुष ज्ञान रूप तपस्या से शुद्ध होकर मेरे स्वरूप को प्राप्त हुए हैं।

Meaning (English): Freed from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me and taking refuge in Me, many have become purified by the fire of knowledge and have attained My divine nature.

This verse is spoken by Lord Krishna, and it emphasizes the path of transformation through spiritual discipline and inner purification.

"Vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhāḥ" (Freed from attachment, fear, and anger):
These are the three major inner enemies on the spiritual path:
Rāga (attachment): Bondage to desires and material pleasures.
Bhaya (fear): Arises when one identifies with the body or ego.
Krodha (anger): Comes from unfulfilled expectations or frustrations.

We interact to the world through senses (see,hear,smell,touch,taste), these are the prime reason of raga (attachment) to material pleasures. Either we crave for the pleasurable experience in the past that these senses were responsible for or out of curiosity. Either way, when someone (person or a situation) comes in the way of attaining what we wanted, anger takes over. If that someone is more powerful than us and we have no control over them, it leads to fear. If we are more powerful than them, it leads to uncontrollable actions (due to anger) or sin (pap). This is how we fall into a pit of self destruction.

Those who conquer these have begun transcending the ego.

"Man-mayāḥ" (Absorbed in Me):
Their consciousness is fully aligned with the Divine. This implies constant remembrance of God, surrendering one's will, and cultivating inner devotion.

"Mām upāśritāḥ" (Taking refuge in Me):
They surrender their ego, seeking the Divine as their ultimate shelter and goal. This surrender is not weakness, but supreme strength.

"Bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtāḥ" (Purified by the fire of knowledge):
Tapas means austerity or discipline. Here, Jñāna-Tapas refers to intense contemplation on knowledge—especially the knowledge of the Self (Atma-Jñāna).
Through this, their ignorance burns away and they are purified.

"Mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ" (They attain My being / divine nature):
Ultimately, they are not just liberated, but united with the Supreme—becoming one in essence with the Divine (Brahma-bhāva or Krishna consciousness).

श्लोक 4.11

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम् ।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः ॥११॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान श्रीकृष्ण कहते हैं: "जो जैसे मेरी शरण लेते हैं, मैं उन्हें उसी प्रकार स्वीकार करता हूँ। हे पार्थ! सभी मनुष्य हर प्रकार से मेरे ही मार्ग का अनुसरण करते हैं।"

Meaning (English): Sri Krishna says: "In whatever way people surrender unto Me, I reciprocate with them accordingly. O Arjuna, everyone follows My path in all respects."

This verse is a powerful assertion of divine reciprocity and universal inclusiveness.

1. “Ye yathā māṁ prapadyante” - "Whoever surrenders to Me in whatever manner..."
People approach God in various ways - as a seeker of wealth, knowledge, liberation, or pure love.
Each soul has a unique motivation and level of understanding.

2. “Tāṁs tathaiva bhajāmy aham” - "...I respond to them accordingly."
God responds exactly in the manner one approaches Him.
If you approach with devotion, He responds with grace.
If you seek material benefit, He may grant that.
If you seek liberation, He guides you on that path.

3. “Mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ” - "O Arjuna, all beings follow My path in all respects."
Ultimately, all spiritual and even material efforts are indirectly on His path.
Even if one is ignorant of God, the pursuit of duty, love, truth, or even desire traces back to divine will.
God is the root of all dharmic paths - karma, jnana, bhakti - and even mistaken paths eventually bring learning and maturity.

श्लोक 4.12

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः ।
क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा ॥१२॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो लोग कर्मों के फल की सिद्धि (सफलता) की इच्छा करते हैं, वे इस संसार में देवताओं की पूजा करते हैं, क्योंकि कर्मों के द्वारा मिलने वाली सिद्धि मनुष्यलोक में शीघ्र मिलती है।

Meaning (English): Those who desire the fruits of their actions worship the celestial gods, for in this human world, success from actions comes quickly.

This shloka highlights the psychology of desire-driven action and the tendency of people to seek immediate results by worshiping devatās (demigods).

"Kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṁ siddhiṁ" - People who desire success or the fruit of their actions.
"Yajanta iha devatāḥ" - They worship devatās (celestial beings) in this world.
"Kṣipraṁ hi mānuṣe loke siddhir bhavati karma-jā" - Because in the human realm, results from action (karma) come more quickly through devatā-worship.

What does Krishna imply?
Krishna is not discrediting devatā-worship, but is pointing out its limitation—it is done for material gain, and bound by karma.
Devatās are appointed cosmic administrators. When you pray to them with sincerity, they can quickly grant material desires—wealth, health, rain, offspring, etc.
However, such worship is not liberating. It keeps you bound to karma and rebirth, because it's desire-driven.
Krishna, in contrast, encourages devotion to the Supreme (Himself) for moksha (liberation)—which may take time but leads to eternal fulfillment.

श्लोक 4.13

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः ।
तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम् ॥१३॥

Meaning (Hindi): गुणों और कर्मों के विभाग से चातुर्वर्ण्य की रचना मैंने की है। यद्यपि मैं उसका कर्ता हूँ, तथापि तू मुझे अकर्त्ता और अव्यय जान।

Meaning (English): The fourfold division of human society was created by Me according to the differentiation of guna (qualities) and karma (actions). Though I am its creator, know Me to be the non-doer and immutable.

This verse is often misunderstood, so a nuanced interpretation is important.

“Chāturvarṇyaṁ mayā sṛṣṭaṁ” - “The fourfold order was created by Me”
Krishna declares that He (as the Supreme Consciousness or Ishwara) is the originator of the varna system - not based on birth, but based on guna (qualities) and karma (actions).
Guna refers to the three modes of nature - sattva (purity), rajas (activity), and tamas (inertia).
Karma refers to the actions or duties aligned with one's inner nature.
Thus, the varna system is a psychological and functional classification, not a hereditary or social hierarchy. Krishna's statement reaffirms that a person's role or place in society should align with their nature and actions, not their lineage.

“Guṇakarma-vibhāgaśaḥ” - “According to qualities and duties”
Each varna reflects a blend of internal disposition (guna) and external responsibility (karma):
Brahmana - Predominantly sattvic - wisdom, discipline, teaching, spirituality
Kshatriya - Rajas-sattva - courage, leadership, protection
Vaishya - Rajas-tamas - commerce, agriculture, trade
Shudra - Tamas - service, support roles
This structure was intended as a fluid and merit-based system, promoting balance and harmony in society.

“Tasya kartāram api māṁ viddhi akartāram avyayam” - “Though I am the creator, know Me as the non-doer and imperishable”
Here Krishna resolves a philosophical paradox:
He says He created the system, yet declares He is not bound by it.
Why? Because as the immutable, transcendental Reality, Krishna (as the Supreme) acts without attachment or desire.
He is like the sun, which enables growth and motion without itself getting involved.
This introduces the idea of Nishkama Karma - action without doership or attachment to results.

श्लोक 4.14

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा ।
इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते ॥१४॥

Meaning (Hindi): मुझे कर्म (कार्य) नहीं बाँधते और न ही कर्मों के फलों की मेरी कोई इच्छा है। जो पुरुष इस प्रकार मुझे (ईश्वर को) भली-भांति जान लेता है, वह भी कर्मों से बंधता नहीं।

Meaning (English): Actions do not bind Me, nor do I have any desire for the fruits of actions. One who truly understands this about Me is also not bound by actions.

This shloka reveals a profound principle of karma-yoga and divine detachment:

1. Krishna as the Unattached Doer
Lord Krishna is emphasizing that although He may perform actions (like running the universe, incarnating, teaching), He is not attached to the results of these actions. He has no desire or personal stake in the outcomes. He acts out of duty, compassion, and balance, not selfish motives.
This is a vital attribute of divinity — acting without ego and attachment.

2. Freedom Through Right Knowledge
Krishna says that one who understands this divine attitude — that God acts without being bound — can also act without bondage. Such a person performs actions as an instrument of the Divine, not out of desire or personal ambition. In other words, right understanding leads to freedom from karma.

3. Key Terms Explained
Karmaṇi limpanti - "Actions do not taint/bind Me"
Na me karma-phale spṛhā - "I have no desire for the results of actions"
Abhijānāti - "knows or realizes truly"
Na sa badhyate - "he is not bound"
This knowledge makes a wise person free from the cycles of karma-bandhan (bondage due to action and reaction).

श्लोक 4.15

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः ।
कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम् ॥१५॥

Meaning (Hindi): इस प्रकार जानकर, कर्म को भूतपूर्व मुमुक्षुओं (मोक्ष की इच्छा रखने वालों) ने भी किया है। अतः तू भी वही कर्म कर, जो भूतपूर्वों ने किया था।

Meaning (English): Having known this, even the ancient seekers of liberation performed action; therefore, you too should perform action as was done by the ancients in earlier times.

This shloka comes after Lord Krishna explains the karma-yoga path, where actions are performed without attachment to their fruits. In this verse, Krishna reassures Arjuna with historical and philosophical validation of the path he is prescribing.

“Evam jñātvā”— "Having known this":
Refers to the knowledge of karma yoga—the path of action performed selflessly, with equanimity and without attachment to results.

“Kṛtaṁ karma pūrvair api mumūkṣubhiḥ”—
The path of selfless action is not new. It was practiced by earlier sages and seekers of liberation (mumūkṣu), who were spiritually evolved and sought moksha (liberation).

“Kuru karmaiva tasmāt”—
Therefore, you too should act accordingly. The emphasis is on performing duty (karma) as a sacred obligation, not as a selfish endeavor.

“Pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṁ kṛtam”—
Even those who came before the ancients followed this path. Thus, the tradition of selfless action has been time-tested and eternally valid.

श्लोक 4.16

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः ।
तत् ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् ॥१६॥

Meaning (Hindi): क्या कर्म है और क्या अकर्म (कर्म न करना) है, इस विषय में बुद्धिमान व्यक्ति भी भ्रम में पड़ जाते हैं। इसलिए मैं तुझे वह कर्म बताने जा रहा हूँ जिसे जानकर तू अशुभ (संसार के बंधनों) से मुक्त हो जाएगा।

Meaning (English): Even the wise are confused about what is action and what is inaction. Therefore, I shall explain to you what action truly is, knowing which you shall be freed from all misfortune and bondage.

This shloka is a pivotal point in Chapter 4 (Jnana Karma Sanyasa Yoga), where Shri Krishna begins to clarify the subtle nature of action (karma), inaction (akarma), and wrong action (vikarma).

1. Confusion Even Among the Wise:
Even learned scholars and sages can become confused about:
What constitutes karma (action)?
What is akarma (inaction)?
What is vikarma (wrong or forbidden action)?
This is because the essence of karma is not just physical movement, but also involves intention, detachment, and consciousness.

2. Why the Confusion Exists:
Many actions appear the same outwardly but are different in spirit:
A soldier killing in war vs. a murderer killing with malice.
A person meditating may appear inactive but is deeply engaged inwardly.
A person performing rituals may still be acting selfishly, despite "religious" behavior.
This shows that external appearance of action does not reveal the truth of karma. Hence even wise people may get trapped in superficial judgment.

3. Krishna's Assurance:
Krishna tells Arjuna that He will now reveal the real essence of action, which, when understood and internalized, will:
Liberate Arjuna from aśubha—inauspicious consequences, mental confusion, or karmic bondage.
Lead to moksha (liberation) through right knowledge and right action.

श्लोक 4.17

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः ।
अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः ॥१७॥

Meaning (Hindi): कर्म का स्वरूप जानना चाहिए, विकर्म का भी जानना चाहिए और अकर्म का भी जानना चाहिए; क्योंकि कर्म की गति (कर्म के स्वरूप, फल और प्रभाव की प्रक्रिया) गहन (गूढ़ और गूढ़तर) है।

Meaning (English): The nature of action (karma) should be understood; the nature of forbidden action (vikarma) also should be understood; and even the nature of inaction (akarma) should be understood. The path of action is indeed mysterious.

This verse emphasizes the complexity and subtlety of karma (action). Lord Krishna advises Arjuna—and through him, all of us—to deeply understand the different dimensions of karma:

Karma (Action):
Actions that are prescribed by the scriptures and aligned with dharma (duty). These include selfless actions done in service, righteousness, and in accordance with one's svadharma (personal duty).

Vikarma (Forbidden Action):
Actions that go against dharma. These are selfish, harmful, or indulgent actions prohibited by scriptures, leading to bondage and suffering.

Akarma (Inaction in Action):
This is the most subtle and profound idea—the state where one acts outwardly but inwardly remains detached, not seeking fruits of the action. This is the action done without ego or desire—a hallmark of the enlightened person.
Krishna says the “gati” (course, movement, consequence) of karma is “gahana” (deep, unfathomable) because:
Sometimes good intentions lead to harmful results.
Non-action may sometimes be more harmful than wrong action.
Even renunciation of action might still bind a person if done with attachment or delusion.

श्लोक 4.18

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः ।
स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् ॥१८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति कर्म में अकर्म को और अकर्म में कर्म को देखता है, वही मनुष्यों में बुद्धिमान है और वही योगी है, तथा सभी प्रकार के कर्मों को करने वाला है।

Meaning (English): One who sees inaction in action and action in inaction, is wise among men. He is a yogi and performs all actions in fullness.

This shloka is a profound spiritual teaching from Lord Krishna to Arjuna about the true understanding of karma (action). It carries deep philosophical meaning, often misunderstood on the surface level.

"He who sees inaction in action..."
This refers to someone who outwardly seems to be engaged in action, but internally is detached from doership and desire.
Their mind is steady, and they are not motivated by ego or selfish goals.
Thus, though actions are being performed, such a person is spiritually inactive — not bound by karma.
Example: A sage or karma yogi performing duties for the welfare of others without attachment to results — their actions are non-binding and spiritually neutral.

"...and action in inaction..."
This means even when someone appears to be inactive, their mental or emotional attachment, intentions, or even subtle ego can be considered a form of karmic activity.
True inaction is not simply physical stillness but a complete freedom from desires and ego.
Example: A person meditating may seem inactive, but if they are indulging in thoughts of ego or desires during meditation, they are mentally active — hence "action in inaction."

श्लोक 4.19

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसंकल्पवर्जिताः ।
ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः ॥१९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिस पुरुष के सब कर्म इच्छाओं और संकल्पों से रहित हैं, और जिसके समस्त कर्म ज्ञान की अग्नि में भस्म हो गए हैं, उस ज्ञानी को बुद्धिमान (पण्डित) कहा जाता है।

Meaning (English): He whose every action is free from desire and selfish motive, and whose actions are burned by the fire of knowledge—such a one, the wise call a sage (pandit).

This verse comes in the context of Karma Sannyasa Yoga and highlights the characteristics of a true Karma Yogi—one who acts in the world with wisdom and detachment.

“yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ”
“Samārambhāḥ” = all undertakings, all beginnings of actions
“Kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ” = devoid of desire and selfish intentions
A person who performs all their actions without personal desire, without seeking fulfillment of selfish plans, is being spoken of here. The word “kāma” (desire) and “saṅkalpa” (personal determination/motive) emphasize inner freedom from personal cravings and attachments.

“jñānāgni-dagdha-karmāṇaṁ”
“Jñāna” = Knowledge
“Agni” = Fire
“Dagdha” = Burnt
“Karmāṇaṁ” = of actions
The metaphor here is striking: just as fire burns wood, in the same way, the fire of self-knowledge burns the binding effects of actions.
This means, even though the person may appear to be acting in the world, their actions don't generate karma because they are performed with spiritual wisdom and detachment. Their ego is not involved.

“tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṁ budhāḥ”
“Tam” = him
“Āhuḥ” = (they) call
“Paṇḍitaṁ” = wise man
“Budhāḥ” = the enlightened ones, sages
The wise and spiritually awakened recognize such a person as a true Pandit (sage or learned one). Not because of scholarly learning, but because of realized wisdom that is reflected in his pure, detached action.

श्लोक 4.20

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

त्यक्त्वा कर्म-फलासङ्गं नित्य-तृप्तो निराश्रयः ।
कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किंचित्करोति सः ॥२०॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो पुरुष कर्म के फलों के प्रति आसक्ति को त्याग चुका है, सदा संतुष्ट रहता है और किसी पर निर्भर नहीं है, वह कर्मों में व्यस्त रहते हुए भी वास्तव में कुछ नहीं करता।

Meaning (English): He who has renounced attachment to the fruits of actions, who is ever content and independent—though engaged in action, he does nothing at all.

This shloka highlights the mindset of a spiritually evolved person — one who acts without attachment or desire for outcomes.

"Tyaktvā karma-phala-āsangam" — having renounced attachment to the fruits of action:
The wise person does not act with selfish motives or desire for personal gain.
This doesn't mean he avoids action, but he does not cling to the result.

"Nitya-tṛipto" — ever content:
Such a person is always satisfied from within, not dependent on external success or failure.
His happiness is stable and comes from inner fulfillment.

"Nirāśrayaḥ" — independent, without dependence:
He does not rely on others for emotional or material support.
His sense of self is self-sufficient.

"Karmaṇy abhipravṛtto'pi" — though fully engaged in action:
He continues to fulfill his duties and responsibilities.
He is not passive or lazy.

"Naiva kiñcit karoti saḥ" — he does nothing at all (in truth):
Since there's no ego-involvement or attachment, such action doesn't bind him karmically.
It is as if he does nothing, because the doer-ship is absent.

Philosophical Essence
This shloka presents a central teaching of Karma Yoga:
Renounce the fruits, not the actions.
Work with full dedication, but without being bound by success or failure.
Become a silent, detached doer—free from ego and expectations.
Such a person lives in the world, works in the world, but is not bound by the world.

श्लोक 4.21

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

निराशीः यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः ।
शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम् ॥२१॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो मनुष्य आशारहित है, जिसका चित्त और आत्मा संयमित है, जिसने सभी प्रकार के भौतिक संग्रह को त्याग दिया है, और जो केवल शरीर द्वारा कर्म करता है — वह पाप को प्राप्त नहीं होता।

Meaning (English): One who has no expectations, who is self-controlled and pure, who has given up all possessions, and who performs action only with the body, such a person incurs no sin.

This verse describes the nature of a true Karma Yogi, someone who acts without attachment or desire. Let's explore the key phrases:

1. Nirāśīḥ (निराशीः) - Without Desire: A person who has no longing for the results of their actions.
They're not acting out of greed, ambition, or fear of loss.
Desirelessness doesn't mean inactivity, but freedom from selfish expectations.

2. Yata-cittātmā (यतचित्तात्मा) - Self and Mind Under Control: Their mind is disciplined and senses are mastered.
Their actions are deliberate, conscious, and aligned with dharma, not impulsive or ego-driven.

3. Tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ (त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः) - Renounced All Possessiveness: Such a person has given up attachment to material possessions and ownership.
They're not accumulating wealth, fame, or control over others.

4. Śārīram kevalaṁ karma (शारीरं केवलं कर्म) - Performs Only Bodily Actions: They act only to maintain the body—i.e., fulfill life's necessities (like food, clothing, duties).
Their work is not driven by ego or indulgence, but to sustain righteous living.

5. Na āpnoti kilbiṣam (न आप्नोति किल्बिषम्) - Does Not Incur Sin: Because their actions are free from desire, ego, and attachment, they don't bind karma or sin.
Actions done in such purity are considered karmically neutral.

श्लोक 4.22

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यदृच्छालाभसंतुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः ।
समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते ॥२२॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति स्वेच्छा से प्राप्त हुए फल में संतुष्ट रहता है, द्वंद्वों (सुख-दुःख, लाभ-हानि आदि) से रहित है, ईर्ष्या से मुक्त है, और सफलता-असफलता में समभाव रखता है, वह कर्म करते हुए भी कर्म में नहीं बंधता।

Meaning (English): One who is satisfied with whatever comes by chance, who has transcended dualities, who is free from envy, and who remains balanced in success and failure—such a person is not bound, even while performing actions.

This verse describes the qualities of a karma yogi—a person who performs actions without attachment to results and remains spiritually free.

"yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭo” - "Satisfied with whatever is obtained by chance or destiny"
Such a person does not chase after desires endlessly. They accept what life offers with gratitude, without greed or discontent. This attitude leads to inner peace.

“dvandvātīto” - "Beyond the pairs of opposites (duality)"
This refers to opposites like pleasure-pain, gain-loss, heat-cold, etc. The wise remain unaffected by these changing conditions, maintaining emotional stability.

“vimatsaraḥ” - "Free from envy or jealousy"
He is not disturbed by others' success or possessions. There is no comparison or competition, only self-growth.

“samaḥ siddhāvasiddhau ca” - "Equanimous in success and failure"
A karma yogi sees both outcomes as part of a larger divine plan. He does his duty sincerely, without being attached to results.

“kṛtvāpi na nibadhyate” - "Though acting, he is not bound (by karma)"
Even though he performs his duties and actions, he does not accrue karmic bondage, because his actions are done with a detached, selfless spirit—not for personal gain.

श्लोक 4.23

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः ।
यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते ॥२३॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिस पुरुष का संसार से कोई लगाव नहीं है, जो मुक्त है, जिसकी बुद्धि ज्ञान में स्थित है, और जो केवल यज्ञ (त्याग और सेवा) की भावना से कर्म करता है — उसके सारे कर्म पूर्णतः समाप्त हो जाते हैं।

Meaning (English): He who is free from attachment, liberated, and whose mind is established in knowledge — performing actions as a sacrifice — all his actions are completely dissolved.

This verse is spoken by Lord Krishna to Arjuna, explaining the true nature of Karma Yoga.

1. "gata-saṅgasya" - One who is free from attachment
This refers to someone who performs actions without any craving for the results — neither for success nor failure, pleasure nor pain.
He has risen above personal likes and dislikes.

2. "muktasya" - One who is liberated
Such a person is not bound by the ego, desires, or material identifications.
He sees himself as a spiritual being, not just the body and mind.

3. "jñānāvasthita-cetasaḥ" - One whose consciousness is established in knowledge This person has spiritual wisdom.
He understands the deeper reality: that the self (Atman) is different from the body, and that performing duty without desire leads to liberation.

4. "yajñāyācarataḥ karma" - One who acts for the sake of sacrifice (Yajna)
Here, "Yajna" doesn't only mean ritual sacrifice but selfless service or offering every action to the Divine.
Actions done in this spirit become purifying.

5. "samagraṁ praviliyate" - All his actions are completely dissolved Such a yogi's actions do not bind him in karma.
Because they are performed with pure intent and detachment, they are “dissolved” — they don't leave behind karmic residue.

श्लोक 4.24

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् ।
ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना ॥२४॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति पूर्णतया भगवत्-चेतना में लीन रहता है, उसके लिए यज्ञ में आहुति डालना (ब्राह्मण कर्म) ब्रह्म है, वह आहुति (हविः) भी ब्रह्म है, हवन की अग्नि भी ब्रह्म है, और जो कर्म कर रहा है वह भी ब्रह्म है। ऐसे व्यक्ति को ब्रह्म ही प्राप्त होता है।

Meaning (English): For those who are completely absorbed in God-consciousness, the oblation is Brahman, the ladle/instrument with which it is offered is Brahman, the sacrificing fire is Brahman, and the act of offering is also Brahman. Such persons, who see everything as God, easily attain Him.

This profound verse conveys the following insights:

Non-dualistic vision: When the practitioner is fully absorbed in divine consciousness (samādhi), they transcend superficial distinctions—between the offerer, the offering, the instrument, and the fire itself. All become identified with Brahman, the ultimate reality.

Unity in multiplicity: Like energy and the energetic being one, yet appearing distinct, the individual soul (jīva) and Supreme Brahman are essentially non-different when perceived with vision free from ego.

Liberation through sacred action: When every action is performed as an offering to the Divine—without selfish desire or ego—the action loses binding force. Such selfless devotional work (karma-yoga) becomes a direct path to realizing Brahman.

In essence, this verse teaches that in the state of complete God-consciousness, the entire ritual, the elements, the doer, and the doing merge into one reality—Brahman. This is not mere symbolism; it is a radical shift in perception—seeing all as divine.

श्लोक 4.25

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते ।
ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति ॥२५॥

Meaning (Hindi): कुछ योगी भगवदर्पण के रूप में यज्ञ का अनुष्ठान करते हैं; अन्य लोग ब्रह्मरूप अग्नि में आत्मा के रूप में यज्ञ का हवन करते हैं।

Meaning (English): Some yogis perform sacrifice as an offering to God; others offer the self as a sacrifice into the fire of Brahman.

In this verse, Lord Krishna describes two distinct approaches to spiritual sacrifice (yajña):

Sacrifices to Devas (Demigods):
Some practitioners offer material offerings to celestial deities, seeking material gains or rewards—these are typical of ritualistic or devotional practices.

Sacrifice of the Self in Brahman's Fire:
Others (the realized yogis or jñānayogis) offer their very self— the individual soul (jīvātman)—as an oblation in the fire of the Supreme Reality (Brahman). This signifies complete surrender of individuality and merging into the ultimate truth.

Explanation:
The first type is external and goal-oriented, seeking worldly or heavenly benefits.
The second is internal, transformative, and aims at spiritual liberation—the ego and sense of separateness are sacrificed, leading to realization of unity with Brahman.

श्लोक 4.26

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति ।
शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति ॥२६॥

Meaning (Hindi): कुछ लोग अपनी सुनने जैसी इन्द्रियों को संयम के अग्नि में अर्पण करते हैं। वहीं कुछ लोग ध्वनि जैसी इन्द्रिय-वस्तुओं को स्वयं इन्द्रियों की अग्नि में यज्ञ स्वरूप अर्पित करते हैं।

Meaning (English): Others offer hearing and other senses in the sacrificial fire of restraint. Still others offer sound and other objects of the senses as sacrifice in the fire of the senses.

In this verse, Lord Krishna describes two distinct spiritual approaches, symbolized as two forms of yajña (sacrifice):

Sacrifice of the Senses in the Fire of Self-Restraint
Practiced by celibate students (brahmacārīs) or advanced seekers. They offer their senses—hearing, sight, etc.—into the “fire” of controlled mind. Through strict discipline, these senses become absorbed into pure consciousness, dissolving self-centered impulses.

Sacrifice of Sense-Objects in the Fire of the Senses
Often followed by householders who, while engaged in worldly life, cultivate detachment. They attend to sense objects (like sounds, sights) but offer them into the sense-fire, meaning they enjoy but remain unattached—viewing objects as neutral rather than desirable.
Both paths lead to mind purification and support spiritual growth—either by deep withdrawal from sense impressions or by transforming interaction into inner freedom.

श्लोक 4.27

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे ।
आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते ॥२७॥

Meaning (Hindi): वे (योगी), जो ज्ञान द्वारा आलोकित हुए होते हैं, अपने सभी इंद्रियों की क्रियाओं और जीवन-प्राण की क्रियाओं को नियंत्रणयुक्त मन की अग्नि में यज्ञ के रूप में अर्पित कर देते हैं।

Meaning (English): Those inspired by knowledge offer all the functions of their senses and the life-force into the fire of self-control, kindled by knowledge.

In this verse, Bhagavad-gītā describes an advanced spiritual discipline:

“Functions of the senses and life-force”: This refers to sensory activities (vision, hearing, etc.) and the vital energies (prāṇa and its divisions within the body).

“Offered into the fire of the controlled mind”: Just as offerings are made into a sacred fire, the yogi offers their sensory impulses and life energy into the internal fire of self-control (ātma-saṁyama)—a state of mastery over mind and senses.

“Kindled by knowledge”: This inward fire is brought to life by the light of spiritual knowledge. Through discrimination and understanding of the Self, the mind becomes disciplined.
This discipline aligns with the path of Jñāna-Yoga, wherein cultivation of knowledge and discrimination leads to mastery over senses and the inner life force, eventually guiding one toward Self-realization.

श्लोक 4.28

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे ।
स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतय: संशितव्रता: ॥२८॥

Meaning (Hindi): कुछ लोग अपनी संपत्ति को आहुति (भक्ति के साथ) अर्पित करते हैं; कुछ लोग कठोर तप (तपस्या) को बलिदान स्वरूप करते हैं; कुछ लोग अष्टांग योग का अभ्यास पुराण-भाव से यज्ञवत् अर्पित करते हैं; और कुछ लोग वेद-ज्ञान या अध्ययन को यज्ञ रूप में अर्पित करते हैं — ये सभी कठोर व्रतों का पालन करने वाले साधक हैं।

Meaning (English): Some offer their wealth as sacrifice; others offer austerities (hard penance) as sacrifice. Some perform the eightfold yogic discipline as sacrifice, and still others cultivate transcendental knowledge through scriptural study as their sacrifice—all of them are ascetics observing strict vows.

In this verse, Lord Krishna emphasizes that spiritual offerings—or yajñas—aren't limited to ritual fires and external rites. Different individuals, according to their nature (saṁskāras) and strengths, can offer their dedicated practices as sacrifices to the Divine:

Dravya-yajña - Offering material possessions in charity or divine service—acting selflessly by giving of one's resources.

Tapo-yajña - Performing austerities and penances, such as vows of silence, fasting, or disciplined discipline to transcend physical attachments.

Yoga-yajña - Practicing the eightfold Yoga (aṣṭāṅga), or other spiritual disciplines, and dedicating this disciplined practice as an offering to God.

Svādhyāya-jñāna-yajña - Embracing the study of scriptures and striving for transcendental knowledge—and offering one's learning, clarity, and insight as a form of sacrifice.
All these practices are undertaken by dedicated seekers (yatayas) who follow strict vows (saṁśita-vratāḥ), meaning they act with discipline, steadfastness, and commitment.

श्लोक 4.29

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे ।
प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः ॥२९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो लोग प्राण और अपान को ध्यानपूर्वक यज्ञ अर्थात समर्पण के रूप में नियंत्रित करते हैं: कुछ अपना प्राण (आउट-ब्रीथ) अपान (इन-ब्रीथ) में, और कुछ अपान को प्राण में अर्पित करते हैं; वे प्राण और अपान दोनों की गति को रोक देते हैं और पूरी तरह से प्राणायाम के अभ्यास में लगे रहते हैं।

Meaning (English): Others offer as a sacrifice the outgoing breath into the incoming breath, while some offer the incoming breath into the outgoing breath. Restraining the movement of both breaths, they are wholly absorbed in the practice of prāṇāyāma.

Prāṇāyāma as Yajña (Sacrifice):
Rather than thinking of yajña as merely fire rituals, here Krishna frames prāṇāyāma—the control of breath—as a spiritual offering. By merging prāṇa (inhalation) into apāna (exhalation), or vice versa, practitioners offer their vital energies in devotion.

Techniques Explained:
Puraka (inhalation): Here, offering the outgoing breath into the incoming is akin to Puraka.
Rechaka (exhalation): Offering the incoming into the outgoing corresponds to Rechaka.
Kumbhaka (breath retention): When both movements are suspended, the yogi practices Kumbhaka—complete breath retention.

Purpose and Impact:
This disciplined control of breath helps still the mind and senses by harmonizing the subtle life energies (prāṇas), sharpening focus, and easing distractions. The yogi gradually withdraws from sensory impulses and attains inner calm.

Cautions & Guidance:
Advanced pranayāma techniques, particularly Kumbhaka, should always be practiced under a qualified teacher's guidance—incorrect practice can be harmful.

श्लोक 4.30

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

अपरे नियताहारा: प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति ।
सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषा: ॥३०॥

Meaning (Hindi): कुछ व्यक्ति अपने आहार को नियंत्रित करते हैं और जीवन-शक्ति (प्राण) को जीवन-शक्ति में ही यज्ञ के रूप में समर्पित करते हैं। ये सब — जो यज्ञ को जानते हैं — अपने सारे पापों से मुक्त हो जाते हैं।

Meaning (English): Others, having regulated their food intake, offer the life-breath into the life-breath as a sacrifice. All these are knowers of sacrifice, and through sacrifice, all their impurities are destroyed.

This verse emphasizes discipline in diet and offering of one's own vital energy (prāṇa) as an act of worship (yajña):

Regulated Diet as Yajña: Krishna calls the disciplined intake of food—both in quality and quantity—a form of sacrifice. Controlling what and how much one consumes helps in stabilizing the body and mind. This is not mere ritual, but a mindful spiritual practice.

Life-Breath into Life-Breath: The phrase "offering the life-breath into the life-breath" symbolizes returning one's own vital energy in reverence to the larger cosmic life force—acknowledging that our prāṇa is not just personal but interconnected.

Knowers of Sacrifice: Those who practice such discipline with understanding are called yajña-vid—wise in the knowledge of sacriﬁce.

Purification: Through this self-discipline and offering, practitioners become freed from impurities (kalmashas)—physiological toxins, mental afflictions, and subtle karmic stains.

Path to Liberation: These practitioners also “taste the nectar of yajña” and ultimately “advance toward the supreme eternal atmosphere”—i.e., liberation or realization of Brahman.

श्लोक 4.31

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम् ।
नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम ॥३१॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो लोग यज्ञ (त्याग और कर्तव्य कर्म) के शेष अमृत को ग्रहण करते हैं, वे सनातन ब्रह्म को प्राप्त होते हैं। हे कुरुओं में श्रेष्ठ (अर्जुन), जो यज्ञ नहीं करता उसके लिए यह लोक भी सुखद नहीं है, तो फिर परलोक की प्राप्ति कहाँ संभव है?

Meaning (English): Those who partake of the nectar of the remnants of sacrifice (yajña-śiṣṭa) attain the eternal Absolute (Brahman). But for one who does not perform sacrifice, O best of the Kurus (Arjuna), neither this world is happy nor the next—how then can he attain liberation?

This verse highlights the importance of sacrifice (yajña) in human life. Here, yajña does not mean only ritualistic fire sacrifices, but any act of selfless service, duty, discipline, and offering to God or society.

"Yajña-śiṣṭāmṛta-bhujaḥ" -
Refers to those who accept life as prasāda (divine remnants of sacrifice).
It means living with the attitude that whatever comes to us is sacred, after we have performed our duties and sacrifices.
Such people purify themselves and ultimately attain Brahman (the eternal reality).

"Nāyaṁ loko 'sty ayajñasya" -
For those who do not engage in any form of sacrifice, neither worldly happiness nor spiritual progress is possible.
A selfish life, without contribution, duty, or service, becomes empty and leads to suffering.

"Kuto 'nyaḥ kuru-sattama" -
If such people cannot be happy in this world, how can they expect happiness in the next (spiritual world)?
It emphasizes the universal law of reciprocity: we cannot expect fruits without sacrifice.

श्लोक 4.32

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

एवम् बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे ।
कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे ॥३२॥

Meaning (Hindi): इस प्रकार अनेक प्रकार के यज्ञ वेदों के मुख अर्थात् उनके ज्ञान में प्रतिपादित हैं। ये सब यज्ञ कर्मजन्य हैं (कर्म से उत्पन्न हैं)। हे अर्जुन! इन्हें इस प्रकार जानकर तू मोक्ष को प्राप्त होगा।

Meaning (English): Thus, various kinds of sacrifices are spread out in the Vedas. Know them all as born of action (karma). By understanding this truth, you shall become liberated.

Krishna here concludes His explanation of different forms of yajnas (sacrifices or disciplines) that He described earlier in Chapter 4 — such as yajna of material offerings, yajna of knowledge, yajna of austerity, yajna of pranayama, yajna of sense-control, etc.

"bahu-vidha yajna" → means many forms of yajnas exist, suited to different temperaments and stages of seekers.

"brahmaṇo mukhe" → means they are prescribed in the Vedas, which are like the “mouth of Brahman” (the medium through which divine knowledge flows).

"karma-jān viddhi" → means all yajnas arise from karma (action). Whether it is meditation, study, charity, or worship — they are forms of spiritualized action.

"evam jñātvā vimokṣyase" → the key teaching: when one understands that all these yajnas are harmonized expressions of karma leading to purification, one moves towards moksha (liberation).

The central point is that all actions, when dedicated selflessly as a yajna, lead to inner purification and freedom. It's not the external ritual that matters most, but the spirit of sacrifice and the understanding behind it.

श्लोक 4.33

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप ।
सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते ॥३३॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे परन्तप (अर्जुन)! द्रव्य (धन, वस्त्र, अन्न आदि) से किया गया यज्ञ (दान या हवन) की अपेक्षा ज्ञान-यज्ञ श्रेष्ठ है, क्योंकि हे पार्थ! सम्पूर्ण कर्मज्ञान में ही अन्ततः समाप्त हो जाते हैं।

Meaning (English): O Arjuna, sacrifice performed in knowledge is superior to material sacrifices made with wealth, for all actions culminate in knowledge.

Two types of sacrifice (Yajna) are compared:

Dravya Yajna (Material Sacrifice): Offering external things such as food, wealth, or possessions. This helps others and purifies the giver, but its effect is limited to material well-being.

Jnana Yajna (Sacrifice of Knowledge): Sharing, receiving, and realizing spiritual knowledge. It is an inner sacrifice where ignorance is burnt away by wisdom. This is far superior, as it leads to liberation (moksha).

Why Jnana Yajna is superior:
Material offerings are temporary and tied to the physical world.
Knowledge transforms the self permanently. Once wisdom dawns, ignorance, delusion, and karmic bondage are destroyed.
Actions (karma), no matter how great, eventually find fulfillment in knowledge. For example, rituals, duties, and charity prepare the mind, but final liberation comes only through wisdom of the Self.

Krishna's emphasis:
All karma (actions, rituals, duties) ultimately point towards the higher truth of knowledge.
The culmination of every spiritual practice is self-realization — understanding "Who am I?" and "What is my relation with the Supreme?"

श्लोक 4.34

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया ।
उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः ॥३४॥

Meaning (Hindi): ज्ञान प्राप्त करने के लिए तुम उन ज्ञानी पुरुषों के पास जाओ जिन्होंने सत्य का अनुभव किया है। उनके चरणों में विनम्र होकर प्रणाम करो, विनम्रता से प्रश्न पूछो और उनकी सेवा करो। वे तत्वदर्शी महापुरुष तुम्हें उस ज्ञान का उपदेश देंगे।

Meaning (English): To understand the truth, approach those who have realized it. Surrender yourself with humility, inquire with sincerity, and serve them with devotion. The enlightened sages, who have seen the truth, will impart that knowledge to you.

This verse is very important in the Gita because it teaches the right attitude for gaining spiritual wisdom.

"Pranipātena" (by surrendering with humility)
True knowledge can only enter when pride and ego are dropped.
Approaching a Guru or teacher with arrogance blocks wisdom.
Humility is the key to receiving higher truths.

"Pariprashnena" (by sincere inquiry)
Blind following is not recommended in the Gita.
Asking thoughtful, respectful, and genuine questions helps clarify doubts.
Inquiry must come from a place of eagerness to learn, not to argue.

"Sevayā" (by service)
Serving the Guru (or teacher, mentor, guide) is not just physical service, but an attitude of respect and gratitude.
It shows sincerity and readiness to learn through action, not just words.

"Upadekṣyanti te jñānam jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ" (the wise will impart knowledge)
Only those who have direct experience of truth (tattva-darshi - seers of reality) can guide others.
A real Guru is not someone who just knows scriptures intellectually, but one who has lived and realized the truth.
Such realized souls can lead seekers to liberation.

श्लोक 4.35

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव ।
येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि ॥३५॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे अर्जुन! उस ज्ञान को प्राप्त कर लेने पर तुम फिर कभी मोह में नहीं पड़ोगे। और उस ज्ञान के द्वारा तुम सभी प्राणियों को सम्पूर्ण रूप से अपने आत्मा में और फिर मुझमें देखोगे।

Meaning (English): O Arjuna, once you have realized this knowledge, you will never fall again into delusion. Through it, you will see all living beings as one with your own self, and also as existing in Me.

Freedom from Delusion
Krishna assures Arjuna that spiritual knowledge (self-knowledge + realization of the Supreme) destroys ignorance. Once gained, Arjuna will never again be trapped in confusion, attachment, or illusion about who he is or what his duty is.
Delusion comes from identification with body, ego, and temporary roles. True knowledge liberates from this cycle.

Unity of All Beings
With this vision, one sees all living entities (humans, animals, plants, even the smallest forms of life) as part of the same eternal reality.
There is no higher or lower — all are manifestations of the same divine essence.
Seeing All in Self and Self in God
It reveals the non-dual truth: The individual soul (Atman) is not separate from others, and ultimately not separate from God (Brahman/Paramatma).
This is the shift from limited individual identity → universal consciousness → divine oneness.

Practical Implication for Arjuna
Arjuna's confusion in the battlefield was rooted in attachment (family vs. duty). Krishna says that once he realizes the oneness of existence, his heart will not waver. He will act with clarity, detachment, and divine alignment.

श्लोक 4.36

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः ।
सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि ॥३६॥

Meaning (Hindi): यदि तू सभी पापियों में सबसे बड़ा पापी भी हो, तो भी ज्ञान-नाव के द्वारा तू सम्पूर्ण पाप रूपी संकटों को पार कर जाएगा।

Meaning (English): Even if you are the most sinful of all sinners, still, by the boat of knowledge, you will surely cross over all sins.

Knowledge as a purifier:
Krishna says that no matter how many sins a person has committed, true spiritual knowledge (Self-knowledge / Atma-jnana) acts like a powerful boat that helps one cross the vast ocean of sins.
This means knowledge is not just intellectual, but a deep realization of the eternal truth—that the Self (Atman) is divine, eternal, and untouched by actions.

Sin is not permanent:
Sins or wrongdoings are like stains, but they don't define the eternal Self. Just as clouds cannot permanently cover the sun, sins cannot permanently corrupt the soul.
Once knowledge dawns, sins lose their binding power.

The metaphor of the boat:
Life filled with ignorance and sin is compared to a dangerous ocean.
Knowledge is the boat that carries us safely to the other shore—liberation (moksha).
Without knowledge, one drowns; with knowledge, one transcends.

Krishna's assurance:
This verse is very compassionate—Krishna reassures Arjuna (and all seekers) that even the gravest mistakes of the past cannot stop spiritual progress.
What matters is sincere pursuit of knowledge and transformation.

श्लोक 4.37

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन ।
ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा ॥३७॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे अर्जुन! जैसे प्रज्वलित अग्नि ईंधन को भस्म कर देती है, उसी प्रकार ज्ञान की अग्नि भी मनुष्य के समस्त कर्मों को भस्म कर देती है।

Meaning (English): O Arjuna, just as a blazing fire reduces wood to ashes, in the same way, the fire of divine knowledge burns away all reactions of material activities.

Fire as a Symbol of Knowledge
Fire consumes everything placed into it and leaves only ashes.
Similarly, true spiritual knowledge (realization of the Self and God) burns away the accumulated karma of countless lives.

Types of Karma Cleansed
Prarabdha Karma (already bearing fruit): This continues until exhaustion.
Sanchita Karma (stored from past lives): Burned by the fire of knowledge.
Kriyaman Karma (current actions): No longer binds a realized person, because they act without ego or attachment.

Liberation through Knowledge
Without knowledge, karma binds the soul in the cycle of birth and death.
With knowledge, even actions done in this world lose their binding effect. The person becomes liberated while still living (jivanmukta).

Why Knowledge is Supreme
Karma (actions) and Bhakti (devotion) are important, but knowledge is like the fire that transforms.
When a devotee gains wisdom of their true nature as the eternal soul, all doubts and bondage vanish.

श्लोक 4.38

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते ।
तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति ॥३८॥

Meaning (Hindi): इस संसार में ज्ञान के समान पवित्र करने वाला कुछ भी नहीं है। जो योगयुक्त व्यक्ति है, वह समय आने पर अपने आत्मा में उस ज्ञान को प्राप्त करता है।

Meaning (English): There is nothing in this world as pure and sacred as knowledge. A person perfected in yoga (discipline of self-realization) eventually realizes this knowledge within his own self, in due course of time.

Knowledge is Supreme Purifier
Here, "knowledge" means spiritual wisdom (ज्ञान of the Self and the Supreme, not just bookish knowledge).
All impurities of ignorance, doubt, and attachment get destroyed only through true knowledge.

Knowledge vs. Other Paths
Rituals, austerities, and charities purify to some extent.
But jnana (knowledge of the Self) removes the very root of ignorance, making it the highest purifier.

Attainment through Yoga
This wisdom is not obtained instantly by reading or listening.
One must walk the path of yoga (discipline, devotion, meditation, selfless action).
Over time (kālena = in due course), the yogi experiences this wisdom within, as realization—not as theory.

Inner Realization
Knowledge is not external but something already within us.
With spiritual maturity, the Self reveals its true nature.

श्लोक 4.39

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः ।
ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति ॥३९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति श्रद्धावान है, ज्ञान में तल्लीन है और इन्द्रियों को वश में कर चुका है, वह ज्ञान को प्राप्त करता है। जब वह ज्ञान प्राप्त कर लेता है, तो शीघ्र ही परम शांति को प्राप्त होता है।

Meaning (English): A person who has faith, who is devoted, and who has controlled the senses, attains knowledge. Having attained knowledge, he quickly reaches supreme peace.

Faith (Śraddhā)
Faith is the foundation. Without faith in the words of the Guru, scriptures, or divine truth, one cannot begin the journey of knowledge.
Here, "faith" does not mean blind belief, but a deep trust in the possibility of higher truths.

Devotion/Single-pointed focus (Tatparaḥ - dedicated/absorbed)
One must be wholeheartedly dedicated to seeking knowledge, not distracted or half-hearted.
Tatparaḥ means being fully inclined toward truth, with determination and perseverance.

Control of senses (Saṁyatendriyaḥ)
Even if a person is faithful and devoted, if the senses are uncontrolled, the mind will wander.
Discipline over desires, temptations, and restlessness makes the mind steady, allowing true knowledge to take root.
Once these three conditions are fulfilled, the seeker attains Jñāna (true wisdom). And with wisdom comes Parāṁ Śānti (supreme peace)—freedom from doubts, fear, and inner conflicts.

श्लोक 4.40

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति ।
नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः ॥४०॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो अज्ञानी है, श्रद्धा रहित है और संदेहशील है, वह नष्ट हो जाता है। संशययुक्त मनुष्य को न तो इस लोक में सुख मिलता है, न परलोक में और न ही परम आनन्द की प्राप्ति होती है।

Meaning (English): One who is ignorant, faithless, and constantly doubting is doomed to destruction. For the person who doubts, there is neither happiness in this world, nor in the next, nor any ultimate peace.

This verse highlights three enemies of spiritual progress:

Ignorance (Ajnana) -
Lack of true knowledge about the self, God, and the purpose of life.
Such a person is caught in material confusion, unable to differentiate between eternal and temporary.

Faithlessness (Ashraddha) -
Even when wisdom is presented, if one lacks shraddha (faith), they dismiss it.
Faith doesn't mean blind belief—it means open-minded acceptance and willingness to practice until realization comes.

Doubt (Samshaya) -
Doubt corrodes the mind.
It creates hesitation, prevents decisive action, and cuts the flow of devotion.
A doubtful person cannot surrender fully—neither to knowledge, nor to God, nor even to themselves.

Krishna warns that such a person finds no happiness:
In this world - because doubt and disbelief cause inner restlessness.
In the next world - because spiritual growth is blocked.
In liberation - because faith and clarity are prerequisites to union with the divine.

श्लोक 4.41

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

योगसन्न्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम् ।
आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय ॥४१॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे धनंजय! जिसका सब कर्म योग के द्वारा त्याग दिया गया है, जिसका संदेह ज्ञान द्वारा नष्ट हो चुका है और जो आत्मसंयमी है, उसको कर्म बंधन में नहीं डालते।

Meaning (English): O Dhananjaya (Arjuna), he whose actions are renounced through Yoga, whose doubts are destroyed by knowledge, and who is self-disciplined—such a person is not bound by actions.

This shloka highlights the transformation of a seeker when true knowledge (Jnana) is attained.

"Yogasannyasta-karmāṇam" - Actions renounced through Yoga
This doesn't mean physical inactivity or abandoning work.
It means performing actions with the spirit of Yoga—dedication to the Divine, without attachment to results.
The "I" or ego as the doer dissolves, and the seeker becomes an instrument of the Divine.

"Jnana-sanchinna-samshayam" - Doubts cut asunder by knowledge
Before realization, the seeker struggles with doubts: "Is this path correct?", "What is my duty?", "Am I the doer or is God?"
With spiritual wisdom, all doubts dissolve. The clarity that the Self is eternal and beyond body-mind comes.

"Atmavantam" - The Self-disciplined one
A person who is established in the Self (Atman) and not swayed by desires, distractions, or egoistic impulses.
Such a person is steady, calm, and centered in inner awareness.

"Na karmāṇi nibadhnanti" - Actions do not bind him
Normally, actions lead to karma (fruit—either good or bad).
But one who acts with wisdom, detachment, and surrender is free from bondage of karma.
They act in the world, but remain untouched—like a lotus leaf in water.

श्लोक 4.42

श्रीभगवानुवाच ।

तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः ।
छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत ॥४२॥

Meaning (Hindi): इसलिए, अज्ञान से उत्पन्न जो संशय तेरे हृदय में वास कर रहा है, उसे तू ज्ञानरूपी तलवार से छेदकर नष्ट कर और योग में स्थित होकर खड़ा हो, हे भरतवंशी अर्जुन!

Meaning (English): Therefore, O Bharata (Arjuna), with the sword of knowledge, cut asunder the doubt born of ignorance that dwells in your heart, and stand up, established in Yoga.

This verse comes at the conclusion of Chapter 4, “Jnana-Karma-Sanyasa Yoga” (The Yoga of Knowledge and Renunciation of Action).

The Core Idea:
Arjuna is plagued by confusion and doubt about his duty (to fight or not). Krishna tells him that doubt is born of ignorance (ajñāna).
Knowledge (jñāna), like a sharp sword, can cut through this inner confusion and hesitation.
Once doubt is destroyed, one must rise with clarity and perform their righteous duty (dharma).

The Sword of Knowledge:
Knowledge here refers not just to book-learning but spiritual wisdom—understanding the eternal Self (Atman), the difference between the perishable body and imperishable soul, and the true nature of action.
When this wisdom shines, doubts dissolve.

Yoga as Steadfastness:
After cutting doubt, Krishna tells Arjuna to establish himself in Yoga—which means self-discipline, balance, and alignment with duty without attachment to results.
“Stand up” here is symbolic—rise above weakness, confusion, and fear.

Click to view Itinerary
Click to view summary

श्लोक 5.1

अर्जुन उवाच।

संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि ।
यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम् ॥१॥

Meaning (Hindi): अर्जुन बोले—हे कृष्ण! आप कभी कर्मों के संन्यास (त्याग) की प्रशंसा करते हैं और कभी कर्मयोग (कर्तव्य का पालन करते हुए योग) की भी प्रशंसा करते हैं। इन दोनों में से कौन-सा मार्ग निश्चित रूप से श्रेष्ठ है, यह कृपया मुझे स्पष्ट रूप से बताइए।
