Meaning (English): Arjuna said: O Krishna, You praise renunciation of actions (sannyāsa), and again You praise the performance of action (karma yoga). Of the two, please tell me decisively which one is superior.

In this shloka, Arjuna expresses confusion.

Earlier, Krishna praised Sannyāsa (renunciation) in the context of controlling desires and being detached from material results.
At the same time, Krishna also glorified Karma Yoga—performing one's duties without attachment to fruits.
Because both seem noble, Arjuna is confused: Should I renounce all actions and live as an ascetic, or should I perform my duties in the world as a yogi? So he directly asks Krishna for a clear and decisive answer.

This sets the stage for Chapter 5 (Karma Sannyāsa Yoga), where Krishna explains the harmony between renunciation and action, and ultimately shows that Karma Yoga is the higher and more practical path for most seekers.

श्लोक 5.2

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

सन्न्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ ।
तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते ॥२॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान श्रीकृष्ण ने कहा — सन्न्यास (कर्म का त्याग) और कर्मयोग (कर्म करते हुए ईश्वरार्पण भाव) - दोनों ही परम कल्याणदायक हैं। परंतु इन दोनों में, कर्मसंन्यास की अपेक्षा कर्मयोग श्रेष्ठ है।

Meaning (English): Lord Krishna said: Renunciation (of actions) and Karma Yoga (selfless action with devotion) both lead to the supreme goal. But among the two, Karma Yoga is superior to mere renunciation of action.

Here, Arjuna is confused whether he should completely renounce actions (sannyasa) and go towards meditation and detachment, or remain engaged in action (karma yoga) while dedicating the results to God.

Krishna clarifies:
Both paths are good - whether you renounce all actions and pursue spiritual wisdom, or you remain engaged in action with detachment, both lead to liberation.

Karma Yoga is superior for most people - because total renunciation is difficult and often impractical. Action is a part of life. If one tries to forcibly give up action without inner maturity, it can lead to hypocrisy or inner conflict.
Karma Yoga purifies the mind - by doing duties without attachment, one grows spiritually while also fulfilling responsibilities. It harmonizes worldly life and spiritual life.
Renunciation (sannyasa) is meant for very few advanced seekers who are already detached from worldly desires. For others, prematurely renouncing action can be harmful.

In essence, Krishna tells us: You don't need to escape life to attain liberation — live in the world, perform your duties sincerely, but remain detached. That is higher than forced renunciation.

श्लोक 5.3

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति ।
निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते ॥३॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो न किसी से द्वेष करता है और न किसी वस्तु की इच्छा करता है, वह सच्चा संन्यासी है। हे महाबाहो अर्जुन! जो मनुष्य द्वन्द्वों (जैसे सुख-दुःख, लाभ-हानि, मान-अपमान) से मुक्त है, वह सहज ही बंधन से मुक्त हो जाता है।

Meaning (English): He should be known as a perpetual sannyasi (true renunciate) who neither hates nor desires. O mighty-armed Arjuna, such a person who is free from dualities (like pleasure-pain, gain-loss, honor-dishonor) is easily released from bondage.

Redefining Renunciation (Sannyasa):
Krishna explains that true renunciation is not about physically giving up work, family, or possessions. Instead, it is an inner state of mind where one is free from attachment, aversion, and desire.
If a person has left home but still carries hatred or longing in the heart, he is not a true renunciate.
But a person living amidst responsibilities, who is free from craving and aversion, is the real sannyasi.

Freedom from Dualities:
Life constantly throws opposites at us—joy & sorrow, profit & loss, praise & blame.
A yogi learns to remain steady and balanced in these dualities.
This balance prevents emotional highs and lows, leading to inner peace.

Bondage and Liberation:
Bondage comes from identification with the fruits of action and the rollercoaster of desires.
Liberation comes when one neither resents what comes nor clings to what goes.
Such a person moves freely in the world, untouched by circumstances.

श्लोक 5.4

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

सांख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः ।
एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् ॥४॥

Meaning (Hindi): अज्ञानी लोग सांख्य (ज्ञानयोग) और योग (कर्मयोग) को अलग-अलग बताते हैं, परन्तु ज्ञानी लोग ऐसा नहीं कहते। कोई भी व्यक्ति यदि इनमें से किसी एक मार्ग में दृढ़तापूर्वक स्थित हो जाए, तो वह दोनों के फल को प्राप्त कर लेता है।

Meaning (English): The ignorant speak of Sankhya (Path of Knowledge) and Yoga (Path of Action) as being different. But the wise do not see them as separate. One who is firmly established in either of the two attains the result of both.

Sankhya = Path of Knowledge (Jnana Yoga)
It emphasizes renunciation of actions through realization of the Self (Atman).
The seeker detaches from worldly duties and meditates on the truth of Brahman.

Yoga = Path of Action (Karma Yoga)
It emphasizes performing actions without attachment, dedicating the results to God.
The seeker remains engaged in the world but detached from desires.

The Conflict People Perceive
Many think “Should I renounce the world and meditate? Or should I act in the world?”
Krishna explains that both are complementary paths, not contradictory.

Why Both Lead to the Same Goal
In Jnana Yoga, the ego is dissolved through knowledge.
In Karma Yoga, the ego is dissolved through selfless action.
In both, the ultimate result is union with the Divine (Self-realization / Moksha).

Wisdom of the Shloka
The wise understand that what matters is inner detachment, not whether one outwardly renounces or acts.
A person can attain liberation through whichever path aligns with their temperament, provided they follow it with sincerity and discipline.

श्लोक 5.5

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते ।
एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति ॥५॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो परम पद सांख्य (ज्ञानयोग) के द्वारा प्राप्त किया जाता है, वही परम पद योग (कर्मयोग) के द्वारा भी प्राप्त होता है। इसलिए जो सांख्य और योग को एक रूप में देखता है, वही वास्तव में सही दृष्टि वाला है।

Meaning (English): The supreme state that is attained by the path of knowledge (Sankhya) is also attained by the path of action (Yoga). He who sees knowledge and action as one, truly sees.

In this verse, Lord Krishna removes the confusion between Sankhya (Path of Knowledge/renunciation) and Yoga (Path of Selfless Action).

Sankhya (ज्ञानयोग): Emphasizes wisdom, self-inquiry, and renunciation of worldly attachments. A jnani seeks liberation through inner realization.

Yoga (कर्मयोग): Emphasizes performing one's duties selflessly without attachment to the results.
Krishna says both paths ultimately lead to the same goal — liberation (moksha). They are not contradictory but complementary.
Knowledge without action is incomplete.
Action without wisdom may bind, but when performed with wisdom and detachment, it leads to freedom.
The true seeker realizes that whether one follows knowledge or action, both are valid spiritual disciplines leading to the same truth. Thus, the wise person does not divide them but integrates both into life.

श्लोक 5.6

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो
दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः ।
योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म
नचिरेणाधिगच्छति ॥६॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे महाबाहो! योग के बिना संन्यास को प्राप्त करना कठिन है; किन्तु योगयुक्त मुनि शीघ्र ही ब्रह्म को प्राप्त कर लेता है।

Meaning (English): O mighty-armed Arjuna, renunciation (sannyāsa) without yoga is difficult to attain. But the sage who is harmonized through yoga, soon reaches Brahman.

This shloka continues the discussion from previous verses where Krishna explains the difference and unity of Sannyāsa (renunciation) and Karma-Yoga (yoga through action).

Renunciation without Yoga is hard:
If someone gives up worldly duties and responsibilities (external renunciation), but has not cultivated discipline, self-control, and inner detachment (yoga), such renunciation will lead to struggle, frustration, or hypocrisy. It's very difficult to control the restless mind simply by abandoning action.

Yoga makes renunciation meaningful:
A person who practices Karma-Yoga, performing actions without attachment to results, develops an inner renunciation naturally. Such a yogi becomes purified gradually, and unlike the external renunciate, he is steadily moving toward the realization of Brahman.

The Yogic Balance:
Instead of a dry, forceful rejection of duties, Krishna promotes a balanced approach — acting in the world while being unattached, gradually reaching the state of liberation. Such a yogi advances faster toward Brahman than one who prematurely renounces without discipline.

श्लोक 5.7

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः ।
सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते ॥७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो मनुष्य योगयुक्त है, जिसका अन्तःकरण शुद्ध है, जिसने अपने मन को वश में कर लिया है और जिसने इन्द्रियों को जीत लिया है, वह सभी प्राणियों में आत्मा को आत्मरूप से देखने वाला है। ऐसा योगी कर्म करता हुआ भी पाप से लिप्त नहीं होता।

Meaning (English): The one who is united with yoga, whose mind is purified, whose self is under control, who has conquered the senses, and who perceives the Self in all beings—such a person, even while performing actions, is not bound.

Yoga-yukta (United with yoga)
Here yoga means not just meditation but the constant connection of the self with the Supreme. A yogi acts with the awareness of being an instrument of the Divine.
Such a person does not act for selfish gains but as a duty (karma yoga).

Vishuddhātmā (Pure-hearted)
Purity of mind comes from giving up selfish desires, anger, greed, and jealousy.
A pure heart allows one to see truth clearly without distortion.

Vijitātmā (Self-controlled)
This refers to victory over the restless mind. A yogi does not allow the mind to wander into material distractions.
Instead, the mind remains steady, focused, and content.

Jitendriya (Conqueror of senses)
Instead of being enslaved by senses (pleasures of sight, taste, touch, etc.), the yogi has mastery over them.
He uses senses for duty, not for indulgence.

Sarvabhūtātm-bhūtātmā (Sees the Self in all beings)
This is spiritual vision: recognizing that the same divine presence exists in all living beings.
Such a yogi treats everyone with respect, compassion, and equality.

Kurvann api na lipyate (Though acting, not bound)
Even while engaging in worldly duties, such a yogi remains untouched by karma (good or bad).
His actions do not bind him because they are performed selflessly, without attachment to results.

श्लोक 5.8

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित् ।
पश्यञ्शृण्वन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपंश्वसन् ॥८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो तत्व को जानने वाला योगी है, वह यह समझता है कि मैं कुछ भी नहीं करता हूँ। चाहे देखना हो, सुनना हो, स्पर्श करना हो, सूंघना हो, खाना हो, चलना हो, सोना हो या सांस लेना हो — इन सबको वह अपने कर्तृत्व से नहीं जोड़ता।

Meaning (English): The self-realized yogi, who is united in devotion and knowledge of truth, thinks, “I do nothing at all.” While seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving, sleeping, or even breathing—he knows that none of these actions are performed by the Self.

This verse emphasizes the state of a tattva-vit (knower of truth). Krishna explains that a liberated person, while living in the world and engaging in everyday activities, does not identify the actions with the Self (the soul).

The body, senses, and mind perform activities naturally, just like a machine.
But the Self (Atman) is merely the witness (sakshi), untouched and unaffected.
The yogi understands: “I am not the doer; the body acts according to nature.”
This detachment removes ego ("I am the doer") and also eliminates attachment to results of actions.
It is a step towards Karma Yoga and Jnana Yoga combined — doing actions without ego, attachment, or claim of ownership.

श्लोक 5.9

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्ण्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् ॥९॥

Meaning (Hindi): तत्वज्ञानी योगयुक्त पुरुष यह समझता है कि — बोलते हुए, त्यागते हुए, ग्रहण करते हुए, आँखें खोलते हुए और आँखें मूँदते हुए भी — इन्द्रियाँ ही अपने-अपने विषयों में प्रवृत्त होती हैं। वास्तव में आत्मा (स्वयं) कुछ नहीं करता।

Meaning (English): While speaking, releasing, grasping, opening the eyes, or closing them, the realized person maintains the understanding: “The senses are engaged with their respective objects, but I, the Self, do nothing.”

This verse continues the same theme as 5.8 — the distinction between the Self (Atman) and bodily activities.

Natural activities of the body
Even in the most ordinary and involuntary functions — speaking, letting go, taking, opening or closing the eyes — a wise person recognizes that it is only the senses interacting with their objects.

Self as the Witness
The Self does not speak, eat, or see. The mouth speaks, the hand grasps, the eyes open and close. These are bodily mechanisms functioning according to nature (Prakriti). The Self is only the silent witness.

Freedom from Doership
The yogi is free from the illusion of “I am doing.” He knows that the body is simply a field where sense organs and sense objects meet. This awareness prevents attachment, pride, or guilt.

Unbroken Detachment
This verse teaches detachment not just in big actions (like working or fighting) but also in the smallest, natural actions of daily life. A wise person remains inwardly free at all times.

श्लोक 5.10

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः ।
लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा ॥१०॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति अपने समस्त कर्मों को ब्रह्म (परमात्मा) को अर्पित करके, आसक्ति त्यागकर कर्म करता है, वह पाप से नहीं लिप्त होता—जैसे कमलपत्र पानी से लिप्त नहीं होता।

Meaning (English): One who performs actions by dedicating them to Brahman (the Supreme), abandoning attachment, remains untouched by sin, just as a lotus leaf is untouched by water.

Core Idea
Krishna explains the concept of Bhakti Yoga here.
When actions are done without selfish attachment and dedicated to the Supreme, the doer is not bound by karma.
The metaphor of the lotus leaf is used—though the leaf lives in water, it does not get wet. Similarly, a yogi lives in the world, acts in it, but remains untouched by sin or bondage.

Attachment vs. Detachment
The problem is not action itself but attachment to action and its results.
By surrendering all actions to the Divine, the sense of “I am the doer” is dropped. The ego dissolves, and karma does not bind.

Freedom from Karma
Normally, actions bind us through their fruits (good or bad).
But for one who works selflessly, dedicating everything to the higher reality, those actions leave no karmic residue.
Such a person remains free—living in the world, yet spiritually untouched.

श्लोक 5.11

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या
केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि ।
योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति
सङ्गं त्यक्त्वात्मशुद्धये ॥११॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति अपने समस्त योगीजन (आध्यात्मिक साधक) अपने शरीर, मन, बुद्धि और यहाँ तक कि इन्द्रियों से भी कर्म करते हैं। वे इन कर्मों को आसक्ति छोड़कर केवल आत्मा की शुद्धि के लिए करते हैं।

Meaning (English): The yogis (spiritual practitioners) perform actions with the body, mind, intellect, and even the senses, but without attachment. They do so solely for the purification of the self (inner being).

Role of Body, Mind, and Intellect
The shloka emphasizes that actions can be performed at multiple levels — physical (body), mental (mind), intellectual (buddhi), and sensory (indriyas).
Even though all these faculties are involved in action, the focus is not on "who is doing" but on how they are being used.

Key Principle - Non-attachment (सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा)
Actions are inevitable — no one can live without performing them.
But yogis act without selfish attachment to the results.
They see action as a duty, not as a means of gaining personal benefit.

Purpose of Action - Self-purification (आत्मशुद्धये)
The real aim is inner purification — cleansing of the ego, desires, greed, and attachment.
Work becomes a form of sadhana (spiritual practice), not just a material pursuit.
Every action done in this spirit brings clarity, peace, and spiritual growth.

Practical Implication
A yogi doesn't renounce action but renounces attachment.
By shifting perspective — from "What will I get?" to "How can this purify and uplift me?" — life becomes balanced and harmonious.

Do your duties wholeheartedly, but let go of ego and attachment to results. Actions then become a means of inner purification, leading you toward peace and liberation.

श्लोक 5.12

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम् ।
अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते ॥१२॥

Meaning (Hindi): योगयुक्त पुरुष कर्मों के फल का त्याग करके परम शांति को प्राप्त करता है। परंतु जो योगयुक्त नहीं है, जो कर्मफल की इच्छा से कर्म करता है, वह फल में आसक्त होकर बंध जाता है।

Meaning (English): The one who is united in yoga, renouncing the fruits of action, attains lasting peace. But the unsteady person, driven by desire and attached to the results, becomes bound.

This verse contrasts two types of people:

The Yuktah (disciplined, yogic person)
Such a person performs actions sincerely but does not cling to the results.
He sees himself as an instrument of the Divine, offering the fruits to God or higher purpose.
By this renunciation of attachment to results, he experiences deep, lasting peace (naiṣṭhikī śānti) because there is no anxiety, fear, or disappointment from outcomes.

The Ayuktah (undisciplined, desire-driven person)
Works mainly for personal gain and is attached to success or failure.
His motivation is fueled by desires (kāma), which keeps him restless.
Such attachment to the outcome leads to bondage (nibadhyate), meaning he remains tied to the endless cycle of joy and sorrow, success and failure, pleasure and pain.

In essence, Krishna is teaching that inner peace comes not from stopping action, but from detachment to the fruits of action. The difference lies not in "doing" but in the attitude while doing.

श्लोक 5.13

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी ।
नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् ॥१३॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिस पुरुष ने अपने मन से समस्त कर्मों का त्याग कर दिया है, वह आत्मसंयमी मनुष्य ‘नवद्वारों वाले’ शरीर-नगर में रहते हुए न तो स्वयं कर्म करता है और न दूसरों से करवाता है। इस प्रकार वह सुखपूर्वक स्थित रहता है।

Meaning (English): The self-controlled person, having mentally renounced all actions, lives happily in the city of nine gates (the body), neither performing actions himself nor causing others to act.

This shlok describes how a Sankya Yogi acts:

"Nine-Gated City (Navadware Pure Dehi)"
The human body is symbolized as a city with nine gates:
Two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, one mouth, anus, and genital organ.
The soul (Dehi, the indweller) resides in this city. The body functions like a city, and the Atman (soul) is its ruler.

Renunciation of Actions
Here, renunciation (Sannyasya) does not mean physical withdrawal from work.
It means mentally renouncing doership and attachment, understanding that the soul is different from the body and its actions.
The wise person knows that the body, senses, and nature (Prakriti) perform activities, not the pure Self.

Inner Freedom
Such a person remains unaffected by external actions.
Even while living in the body, he does not get entangled in worldly affairs because he has realized his true self.
He neither identifies with the physical activities nor considers himself the doer.

"Neither doing nor causing others to act"
This line stresses that the liberated person sees all activities as belonging to Prakriti (nature).
The Self is only a witness (Sakshi), not an actor.
Hence, he is free from bondage and enjoys inner peace.

श्लोक 5.14

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः ।
न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते ॥१४॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान न तो किसी को कर्ता बनाते हैं, न ही कर्म कराते हैं और न ही कर्मों के फल से जोड़ते हैं। ये सब तो जीव के स्वभाव (प्रकृति) से ही उत्पन्न होते हैं।

Meaning (English): Krishna does not create the sense of doership, nor actions, nor the connection between actions and their results in the living beings. All this is enacted by one's own nature (Prakriti / inherent tendencies).

This verse removes a common misunderstanding that God is directly making us act or binding us to karma. Instead, Krishna explains:

God as a Non-Doer
God (the supreme consciousness) does not force anyone to act.
He doesn't assign roles like “you are the doer of this action” or “you must suffer this fruit.”

Actions are Driven by Nature (Prakriti)
Each being has tendencies, desires, and instincts (gunas of sattva, rajas, tamas).
These push us into action, independent of God's will.
For example, fire burns not because God tells it to, but because it is its nature.

Karma-Phala (Results of Actions)
The link between what we do and what we experience as a result is a natural law, like cause and effect.
God doesn't intervene each time to decide the result—it's built into the fabric of creation.

Why this is Important
It highlights personal responsibility: we cannot blame God for our sufferings or mistakes.
It also highlights God's impartiality: He is beyond bias or favoritism.

श्लोक 5.15

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः ।
अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः ॥१५॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान न तो किसी के पाप को ग्रहण करते हैं और न ही किसी के पुण्य को। वास्तव में, जीव का ज्ञान अज्ञान से ढक जाता है, और उसी कारण से प्राणी मोह में पड़ जाते हैं।

Meaning (English): The Supreme Lord does not accept anyone's sins, nor does He accept anyone's pious deeds. In reality, knowledge is covered by ignorance, and it is this ignorance that deludes living beings.

This verse clarifies a very subtle principle of karma and divine impartiality:

God is Neutral and Unbiased
The Lord does not personally interfere in human beings' karma. He neither takes away someone's sins nor claims their virtues. He has established the law of karma, and each soul reaps what it sows.
God is like the sun — it shines equally on everyone. How much warmth or light one receives depends on where one stands (open field vs. closed room). Similarly, our karmas determine our experience, not God's personal favoritism.

Ignorance as the Real Cause of Suffering
Souls are inherently pure and divine, but when their knowledge is covered by ignorance (अज्ञान), they identify with the body, desires, ego, and material attachments.
This ignorance makes us believe “I am the doer” and leads us to suffer or enjoy based on our karmas.

Responsibility Lies with the Individual
People often blame God for their suffering or praise Him for their happiness. But Krishna clarifies here that it is our ignorance and past karmas, not God's partiality, that bind us.
Liberation comes when ignorance is destroyed by true knowledge (ज्ञान).

श्लोक 5.16

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः ।
तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ॥१६॥

Meaning (Hindi): परंतु जिन लोगों का अज्ञान आत्मज्ञान द्वारा नष्ट हो चुका है, उनके लिए वह ज्ञान सूर्य के समान उनके परम सत्य (परमात्मा) को प्रकाशित करता है।

Meaning (English): But for those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, that knowledge, like the sun, reveals the Supreme Truth.

This shloka is a continuation of Krishna's explanation about the power of knowledge.

Ignorance as Darkness
Ignorance (अज्ञान) keeps the soul bound to worldly attachments, desires, and misidentification with the body and mind.
Just like darkness prevents one from seeing things as they are, ignorance prevents one from realizing the eternal truth of the self.

Knowledge as the Sun
Spiritual knowledge (ज्ञान) is compared to the sun because it does not merely reduce darkness—it completely removes it.
Once true knowledge arises, ignorance vanishes instantly, just as darkness cannot exist when the sun shines.

Self-Realization
This shloka points to the idea that Self-realization is not about acquiring something new, but about removing the veil of ignorance to see what has always been present—the eternal soul (आत्मा) and its oneness with the Supreme (परमात्मा).

Supreme Goal
Knowledge reveals the highest truth (तत्परम्), i.e., Brahman/Paramatma, which is beyond dualities, beyond material illusions, and is the ultimate destination of the soul.

श्लोक 5.17

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मान
स्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः ।
गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं
ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः ॥१७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिनकी बुद्धि उस (परमात्मा) में स्थिर है, जिनका मन उसी में लगा है, जो उसी में स्थित हैं और जिन्होंने उसी को परम लक्ष्य बना रखा है - ऐसे ज्ञान द्वारा पापरहित हुए महात्मा उस धाम को प्राप्त होते हैं, जहाँ से लौटकर वे संसार में पुनः नहीं आते।

Meaning (English): Those whose intellect is fixed in That (the Supreme), whose self is absorbed in That, who are steadfast in That, and who take refuge in That alone — being purified of their sins by true knowledge, they attain the state from which there is no return.

This shloka emphasizes the transformation of a person through knowledge (jnana) and devotion to the Supreme Reality. Let's break it down:

"Tad-buddhayah" (Whose intellect is in Him):
Their discrimination (buddhi) is always directed toward the Supreme, not entangled in material distractions.

"Tad-atmanah" (Whose self is absorbed in Him):
Their inner being (atma) identifies with God, not with the body or ego.

"Tan-nisthah" (Steadfast in Him):
They practice constant spiritual discipline, maintaining unshaken faith and devotion.

"Tat-parayanah" (Who take refuge in Him):
They surrender completely, seeing the Supreme as their ultimate goal and shelter.

"Jnana-nirdhuta-kalmasah" (Sins destroyed by knowledge):
Through spiritual wisdom, their ignorance and karmic impurities are washed away.

"Gachhanti apunaravrittim" (They attain the state of no return):
Such realized souls reach moksha (liberation) — the eternal abode of the Divine, from where they do not come back into the cycle of birth and death.

श्लोक 5.18

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि ।
शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः ॥१८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो ब्राह्मण (ज्ञानी), गाय, हाथी, कुत्ता और चाण्डाल (अशुद्ध भोजन करने वाला) — इन सबमें समान भाव से देखता है, वही ज्ञानी होता है।

Meaning (English): The wise see with equal vision a learned and humble brāhmaṇa, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even a dog-eater (outcaste).

This shloka emphasizes the quality of true wisdom (prajñā).

External differences vs. inner unity:
On the surface, beings differ in form, status, learning, and conduct.
A Brahmana (scholar) is highly respected, while a dog or outcaste is considered low in society.
But a wise person sees the same soul (Ātman) within all — unchanging, eternal, and divine.

Equality beyond material distinctions:
Social designations, caste, species, or appearances do not affect the essence of life.
The pāṇḍita (knower of truth) perceives equality (samatva) because all beings are sparks of the same Supreme (Paramātman).

What this equality means (and what it does not):
It does not mean that worldly roles and practical differences vanish — a cow and a tiger cannot be treated the same materially.
It means spiritually, the wise recognize the same divinity in all beings.

Spiritual vision vs. material vision:
Ordinary people see "high" and "low" based on education, wealth, or birth.
The enlightened see unity: the Brahmana's soul, the dog's soul, and the outcaste's soul are all pure, eternal, untouched.

श्लोक 5.19

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः ।
निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिता: ॥१९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिनका मन समानता में स्थित है, वे लोग इसी जीवन में संसार को जीत लेते हैं। क्योंकि निष्पाप और समरूप ब्रह्म ही है, अतः वे ब्रह्म में ही स्थित रहते हैं।

Meaning (English): Those whose minds are established in equality and equanimity have already conquered material existence in this very life. For the Absolute Truth (Brahman) is flawless and the same to all; therefore, they are firmly situated in Brahman.

This verse highlights the power of equanimity (sameness of vision):

Victory over Material Existence (Samsara):
One who sees all beings equally—whether friend, enemy, or neutral—has overcome the binding influence of material dualities like pleasure-pain, success-failure, attraction-repulsion.
Such a yogi does not wait for liberation after death; he is already liberated while living.

Connection to Brahman:
Brahman (the Supreme Reality) is pure, faultless, and equal to all beings.
A person who cultivates the same outlook naturally becomes aligned with the nature of Brahman.

Equality is not Blindness:
This does not mean ignoring practical differences in life (like teacher vs. student, parent vs. child).
It means that deep inside, at the soul level, all beings are the same spark of divinity.
Therefore, one treats everyone with respect, compassion, and non-judgment.

श्लोक 5.20

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

न प्रहृष्येत् प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत् प्राप्य चाप्रियम् ।
स्थिरबुद्धिरसंमूढो ब्रह्मविद् ब्रह्मणि स्थितः ॥२०॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति प्रिय वस्तु प्राप्त होने पर अत्यधिक हर्षित नहीं होता और अप्रिय वस्तु मिलने पर उद्विग्न नहीं होता, जिसकी बुद्धि स्थिर है, जो मोह से रहित है और ब्रह्म को जानने वाला है, वही ब्रह्म में स्थित है।

Meaning (English): A person who neither rejoices on obtaining the pleasant nor laments on obtaining the unpleasant, who is stable in intellect, free from delusion, and established in the knowledge of Brahman—such a person is indeed situated in Brahman.

This shloka emphasizes equanimity—a state of balance and steadiness in all circumstances.

Not overly elated by gains:
When something favorable or pleasant comes to us (wealth, success, recognition, comforts), most people naturally feel joy. But excessive attachment to joy leads to dependency on external things. Krishna teaches that a wise person experiences these without being enslaved by them.

Not disturbed by losses:
Similarly, when something unpleasant or unfavorable happens (failure, insult, loss, pain), the yogi does not sink into sorrow. He accepts it as part of the natural play of life.

Stable intellect (स्थिरबुद्धि):
Such a person's wisdom is not shaken by the dualities of life. They maintain inner balance, unaffected by fluctuations of fortune.

Free from delusion (असंमूढ):
They are not confused by worldly illusions (maya). They see life as temporary and know the eternal Self (Atman) is beyond pleasure and pain.

Established in Brahman (ब्रह्मणि स्थित):
A person who realizes that their true Self is eternal, divine, and one with Brahman, lives with inner peace. They are not tossed around by external conditions.

श्लोक 5.21

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम् ।
स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते ॥२१॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति बाहरी इंद्रिय सुखों से आसक्त नहीं होता, वह अपने भीतर ही सुख पाता है। जो ब्रह्म योग में लीन होता है, वह अचूक और शाश्वत सुख प्राप्त करता है।

Meaning (English): One who is unattached to external sense pleasures finds happiness within the self. Such a person, united with the Supreme through yoga, attains unending happiness.

In this verse, Lord Krishna emphasizes the contrast between transient external pleasures and the eternal bliss found within. He explains that:

Detachment from External Pleasures: A person who is not attached to external sensory experiences—such as material comforts, wealth, or fleeting joys—discovers a deeper, more lasting happiness within themselves.

Union with the Supreme (Brahman): Through practices like meditation and self-discipline (yoga), such an individual unites with the Supreme, experiencing a profound connection with the divine essence.

Unending Happiness: This inner union leads to an inexhaustible state of bliss, transcending the temporary and often deceptive pleasures of the material world.

This teaching underscores the importance of inner contentment and spiritual connection over the pursuit of external gratifications.

श्लोक 5.22

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते ।
आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः ॥२२॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे कौन्तेय! जो सुख विषयों के संयोग से उत्पन्न होते हैं, वे दुःख के ही कारण हैं। क्योंकि वे आदि और अंत वाले (क्षणिक) हैं। इसलिए बुद्धिमान पुरुष उनमें आसक्त नहीं होते।

Meaning (English): O son of Kunti (Arjuna), the pleasures that arise from contact with the senses and their objects are indeed sources of misery. They have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna, and therefore, the wise do not delight in them.

Pleasures are temporary:
Sense pleasures (like taste, touch, sight, sound, smell) are not lasting. They arise only when the senses come in contact with external objects. For example, eating a delicious meal gives happiness for a while, but soon the taste fades, and if overindulged, it can even cause discomfort.

Pleasures carry hidden sorrow:
Every worldly pleasure brings along suffering:
Before enjoyment: longing, craving, restlessness.
During enjoyment: fear of losing it, anxiety of interruption.
After enjoyment: emptiness, dissatisfaction, or craving for more.

Beginning and end (अनित्य - impermanent):
They have a clear start and finish, hence cannot give lasting satisfaction. The true Self (Atman) and bliss of spiritual realization are eternal, unlike fleeting worldly joy.

The wise avoid indulgence:
The enlightened or wise person does not “delight” in such pleasures. This doesn't mean rejecting life, but understanding that real happiness doesn't depend on external contact — it comes from inner peace, self-control, and connection with the Divine.

श्लोक 5.23

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक् शरीरविमोक्षणात् ।
कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः ॥२३॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो मनुष्य शरीर छोड़ने (मृत्यु) से पहले ही कामना और क्रोध से उत्पन्न वेग (उत्साह, आवेग) को सहन करने में समर्थ है, वही योगी है और वही सच्चा सुखी पुरुष है।

Meaning (English): One who is able to withstand the urges born of desire and anger, before giving up this body, is a yogi, and he alone is a truly happy person.

“Urges of desire and anger”
Desire (kāma) creates longing for sense objects, pleasures, possessions, or recognition.
Anger (krodha) arises when desires are obstructed.
These two are the strongest forces binding a human being to suffering.

“Before giving up the body”
The shloka stresses self-mastery while alive, not postponing control until death or future births.
Spiritual growth is about managing emotions here and now.

“He is a yogi”
A yogi is not just one who meditates but one who has mastery over inner impulses.
Yoga here means union with inner balance and not being enslaved by impulses.

“He alone is happy”
True happiness (sukha) does not come from indulging in desire but from freedom from it.
By conquering desire and anger, one experiences deep peace (śānti) and contentment.

श्लोक 5.24

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तराराम
स्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः ।
स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं
ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति ॥२४॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति भीतर ही सुख पाने वाला है, भीतर ही रमण करने वाला है और भीतर ही प्रकाश पाने वाला है, वही योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाण (परम शांति) को प्राप्त करता है, और ब्रह्मस्वरूप हो जाता है।

Meaning (English): That person who finds happiness within, rejoices within, and whose light shines from within — such a yogi attains liberation in Brahman and becomes one with the Divine.

This shloka describes the inner state of a true yogi or seeker.

“Antah-sukhaḥ” (happiness within):
The yogi no longer depends on external pleasures for joy. Worldly happiness is temporary and comes with conditions, but inner happiness is permanent and independent.

“Antar-ārāmaḥ” (rejoicing within):
Instead of being restless and seeking entertainment or fulfillment outside, the yogi finds satisfaction in the self, in meditation, and in connection with the soul.

“Antar-jyotiḥ” (light within):
The yogi's wisdom and guidance come from the inner self, not from material possessions or societal validation. The inner consciousness (Ātman) becomes the guiding light.

Result:
Such a person reaches Brahma-nirvāṇa — liberation, eternal peace, and union with Brahman (the ultimate reality). They become Brahmabhūta — one who realizes “I am not this body or mind, but the eternal soul, connected with the Supreme.”

श्लोक 5.25

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः ।
छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः ॥२५॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिन ऋषियों के पाप नष्ट हो गए हैं, जिनके संशय दूर हो गए हैं, जिनका मन संयमित है और जो सदा सब प्राणियों के हित में लगे रहते हैं — वे ब्रह्मनिर्वाण (परम शांति और परमात्मा में लीनता) को प्राप्त होते हैं।

Meaning (English): The sages whose sins are destroyed, whose doubts are cut asunder, who are self-disciplined, and who delight in the welfare of all beings — such souls attain Brahman Nirvana (the supreme peace in union with Brahman).

This shloka explains who qualifies for ultimate liberation (Brahman Nirvana) and what inner qualities are necessary for such attainment:

Rishayah Ksheena-Kalmashah (Sages with sins destroyed)
Through righteous living, devotion, and selfless action, impurities of mind (lust, anger, greed, ego) are reduced and destroyed.
Liberation requires not just outer discipline but inner purification.

Chhinna-Dvaidhah (Freed from doubts / dualities)
Dualities mean confusion between right and wrong, joy and sorrow, honor and dishonor.
One who has clarity about the eternal truth and sees beyond worldly opposites remains unshaken.

Yatatmanah (Self-controlled)
Mastery over senses and mind is essential.
Without self-control, the mind gets carried away by desires and fears, which block liberation.

Sarva-Bhuta-Hite Ratah (Engaged in the welfare of all beings)
The liberated soul is not selfish.
True spirituality includes compassion, service, and seeing the same divine in all beings.
Such a person naturally works for universal well-being, not just personal gain.
Thus, Brahman Nirvana (union with the infinite, blissful Brahman) is not attained by external rituals alone but by a purified heart, clear understanding, disciplined mind, and compassion for all beings.

श्लोक 5.26

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम् ।
अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम् ॥२६॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो साधुजन काम और क्रोध से रहित हैं, जिनका मन वश में है और जिन्होंने अपने आत्मा को जान लिया है — ऐसे यतियों के लिए ब्रह्मनिर्वाण (परम शांति और परमात्मा में लीन होने की अवस्था) चारों ओर विद्यमान रहती है।

Meaning (English): For those ascetics who are free from lust and anger, who have subdued their mind, and who have realized the Self, absolute peace — Brahman Nirvana — is ever present all around them.

"Free from lust and anger"
Lust (kāma) and anger (krodha) are considered two of the strongest enemies of spiritual progress.
Lust arises from unfulfilled desires, and anger is its natural outcome when obstacles prevent fulfillment.
A person who rises above these impulses can maintain inner balance.

"Ascetics (yatis)"
Not necessarily monks or renunciates only — here it refers to anyone who sincerely strives for self-discipline, self-realization, and higher truth.
A yati is one who puts conscious effort into self-control and spiritual progress.

"Subdued their mind" (yatacetasām)
The restless mind is the root of dissatisfaction. By bringing the mind under control, one gains mastery over thoughts and emotions.
This doesn't mean suppressing thoughts, but channeling them toward higher ideals.

"Self-realized (viditātmanām)"
They have realized their true nature as the eternal Self (Atman), beyond body and ego.
With this realization, worldly ups and downs cannot disturb them.

"Brahman Nirvana"
The ultimate state of liberation — freedom from bondage, peace beyond dualities, bliss that is unshaken by external events.
It is not something to be attained in a distant future — Krishna says it is “present all around them” (abhito varta-te).
Meaning: such peace pervades their existence here and now.

श्लोक 5.27

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः ।
प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ ॥२७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो साधक बाहरी विषय-संसार से अपने इन्द्रियों को हटाकर, नेत्रों को भौंहों के बीच केंद्रित करता है, और प्राण व अपान वायु को नासिका मार्ग में सम कर लेता है, वह योग में स्थित होता है।

Meaning (English): Shutting out all external sense-objects, fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, and balancing the incoming and outgoing breaths moving within the nostrils — such a yogi remains steadfast in meditation.

This verse belongs to the section where Krishna is describing the qualities and practices of a yogi (a true renunciate and meditator).

“Sparshān kṛtvā bahir bāhyān” - Shutting out external contacts
The yogi consciously withdraws the senses from external pleasures and distractions.
It doesn't mean he rejects the world, but he controls his senses so they don't dictate his mind.

“Chakṣhuśh chaivāntare bhruvoḥ” - Fixing the gaze between the eyebrows
This is a meditative technique.
By directing vision towards the space between the eyebrows (ājñā chakra), concentration deepens.
This helps still the restless mind.

“Prāṇāpānau samau kṛtvā nāsābhyantara chāriṇau” - Equalizing inhalation and exhalation
Refers to prāṇāyāma (breath control).
When inhalation (prāṇa) and exhalation (apāna) are balanced, the mind naturally becomes calm.
It symbolizes balance in life — neither extremes, but harmony.
In essence, Krishna is giving a glimpse of the yogic process of pratyāhāra (withdrawal of senses), dhāraṇā (concentration), and prāṇāyāma (breath regulation), which leads to inner steadiness.

श्लोक 5.28

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः ।
प्विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः ॥२८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिस मुनि ने अपनी इन्द्रियों, मन और बुद्धि को वश में कर लिया है, जो सदा मोक्ष की प्राप्ति में ही तत्पर रहता है, जिसकी इच्छाएँ, भय और क्रोध नष्ट हो गए हैं — वह सदा ही मुक्त (जीवन्मुक्त) रहता है।

Meaning (English): A sage who has controlled his senses, mind, and intellect, who is steadfastly devoted to liberation, and who is free from desires, fear, and anger—such a person is forever liberated.

This verse comes near the conclusion of Chapter 5 (Karma Sannyasa Yoga), where Shri Krishna is describing the qualities of a yogi who is truly free.

Self-Control (Indriya, Mana, Buddhi):
The verse emphasizes mastery over the senses (indriya), the mind (manas), and the intellect (buddhi). These are the three primary forces that govern human behavior. Unless they are harmonized, one remains bound by desires and distractions.

Focus on Liberation (Moksha-parāyaṇa):
The sage is not merely disciplined for worldly success; his entire orientation is toward liberation—freedom from the cycle of birth and death. This higher goal gives him unwavering direction.

Freedom from Desire, Fear, and Anger (Icchā, Bhaya, Krodha):

Desire (icchā): Attachment to pleasures keeps the mind restless.
Fear (bhaya): Arises when one identifies with the body or possessions, worrying about loss.
Anger (krodha): Springs from unfulfilled desire or obstruction. A yogi transcends these, remaining equanimous in all situations.

Ever Free (Sadā Mukta):
Such a person doesn't have to “wait” until death for liberation. He lives in freedom here and now—a state called jīvanmukti (liberated while alive).

श्लोक 5.29

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

भोक्‍तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम् ।
सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति ॥२९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो मनुष्य मुझे यज्ञ और तप का भोक्‍ता, समस्त लोकों का महेश्वर तथा सब प्राणियों का सच्चा मित्र जानता है, वह शांति प्राप्त करता है।

Meaning (English):The wise person who realizes that I (Krishna / Supreme Lord) am the enjoyer of all sacrifices and austerities, the Supreme Lord of all worlds, and the well-wisher of all living beings, attains peace.

This verse beautifully summarizes three essential truths about the Divine, which are crucial for spiritual realization:

Bhoktāraṁ yajña-tapasāṁ (Enjoyer of all sacrifices and austerities)
All the efforts we put into yajña (sacrifice), tapas (austerities), or any good action should be offered to God.
If we think “I am doing this for myself, for my ego, or for recognition”, then we bind ourselves in karma.
But if we accept that ultimately God is the enjoyer, our actions become free from selfishness and karma.

Sarva-loka-maheśvaram (Supreme Lord of all worlds)
God is not limited to one country, one religion, or one species. He is the Lord of all creation.
Understanding this helps us rise above narrow thinking, pride, or possessiveness.
It reminds us that nothing truly belongs to us—everything belongs to the Supreme.

Suhr̥daṁ sarva-bhūtānām (Well-wisher of all living beings)
Unlike worldly friends who may be selfish, God is the true eternal friend, wishing the best for every soul.
Realizing this builds deep trust—whatever happens in life, even if painful, is ultimately for our spiritual growth and well-being.

Śāntim ṛcchhati (Attains peace)
When we accept these truths—God as the enjoyer, controller, and true friend—we stop resisting life, stop struggling with ego, and surrender to divine will.
This surrender brings inner peace, freedom from anxiety, and liberation from fear of loss or death.

Click to view Itinerary
Click to view summary

श्लोक 6.1

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः ।
स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः ॥१॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान श्रीकृष्ण ने कहा — जो मनुष्य अपने कर्मों के फल पर आश्रित नहीं होता और केवल कर्तव्य समझकर कर्म करता है, वही सच्चा संन्यासी और योगी है; न कि वह जो अग्नि (यज्ञ की अग्नि या गृहस्थ की अग्नि) को त्याग देता है और न ही वह जो कर्म करना छोड़ देता है।

Meaning (English): Krishna said — He who performs his prescribed duty without depending on the fruits of action, he is a true renunciate (sannyasi) and a true yogi; not he who merely renounces the sacred fire or abstains from action.

False Idea of Sannyasa (Renunciation):
Many people think renunciation (sannyasa) means giving up all worldly duties, family life, or external rituals (like maintaining the sacred fire in Vedic tradition). Krishna corrects this misconception. True renunciation is not about running away from life or ceasing action.

True Sannyasa and Yoga:
A real sannyasi and yogi is one who performs his duties but does not get attached to the results.
Sannyasi = one who has renounced attachment to results.
Yogi = one who is disciplined in action and mind. Both are essentially the same when understood rightly.

Action vs. Inaction:
Simply abandoning duties is not yoga. Doing one's duty with detachment is yoga. This means even a householder, student, or professional can be a yogi if they act with the right mindset.

Essence of Karma Yoga:
The foundation of Yoga lies in karma performed without expectation — “Work is worship, but without selfish desire.”

श्लोक 6.2

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव ।
सन ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन ॥२॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे अर्जुन! जिसे लोग संन्यास कहते हैं, उसी को तू योग जान। क्योंकि बिना संकल्पों (कामनाओं और इच्छाओं) को त्यागे कोई भी योगी नहीं हो सकता।

Meaning (English): O Arjuna! What is called renunciation (sannyasa), know that to be the same as yoga. For no one becomes a yogi without renouncing selfish desires and worldly intentions.

This verse bridges Sannyasa (renunciation) and Yoga (discipline of union with the divine).

Renunciation vs. Yoga
People often think renunciation means giving up worldly duties, family, or possessions.
Krishna clarifies: True renunciation is giving up the selfish desires and attachments in the mind, not merely abandoning external actions.
Yoga is the practice of uniting the mind with God through discipline. So, true renunciation and yoga are one and the same.

Key Principle
A person cannot be a yogi (one who is united with the Divine) if they still cling to desires, ambitions, and mental attachments.
Renunciation is not inactivity, but detachment in activity.
The essence: It's not about what you renounce externally, but how you renounce internally.

Practical Dimension
Krishna does not ask us to leave our worldly duties. Instead, He wants us to perform them without attachment, without the ego of “I” and “mine,” and without being enslaved to the outcome.
Renunciation = purifying intention. Yoga = disciplined pursuit of spiritual connection. Both are inseparable.

श्लोक 6.3

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते ।
योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते ॥३॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो साधक (मुनि) योग में आरम्भ करना चाहता है, उसके लिए कर्म (कर्तव्य कर्मों का पालन) ही साधन माना गया है। परन्तु जब वह योग में सिद्ध हो जाता है (योगारूढ़ हो जाता है), तब उसके लिए शम (सभी कर्मों का त्याग और मन का शांत होना) ही साधन कहा गया है।

Meaning (English): For a sage who wishes to ascend to Yoga (union with the Self), action (karma, prescribed duties) is said to be the means. But for one who has already attained Yoga (steadfastness in meditation and self-realization), tranquility (cessation of action, inner calmness) is said to be the means.

This verse makes a distinction between two stages of a yogi's journey:

Ārurukṣuḥ (The Aspirant - Beginner Stage)
A seeker who wants to rise towards Yoga should perform karma (duties, actions, discipline).
Why? Because without purification of the mind through righteous action, one cannot enter deep meditation.
Performing duties selflessly helps reduce attachment and ego, preparing the mind for higher yoga.

Yogārūḍhaḥ (The Established Yogi - Advanced Stage)
Once a seeker becomes established in Yoga (deep meditation, inner awareness), then śama (tranquility, renunciation of action) becomes the path.
Here, the yogi's mind is withdrawn, peaceful, beyond worldly desires.
Outer action is no longer the focus; inner stillness and union with the Self dominate.

In simple words:
Action (karma) purifies beginners.
Quietude (śama) sustains the advanced.
It's like learning swimming:
In the beginning, practice and effort (karma) are needed.
Once mastered, relaxation and flow (śama) carry you forward.

श्लोक 6.4

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते ।
सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते ॥४॥

Meaning (Hindi): जब मनुष्य इन्द्रियों के विषयों और कर्मों में आसक्त नहीं रहता, और सब संकल्पों (इच्छाओं/कामनाओं) का त्याग कर देता है, तब उसे योगारूढ़ (योग में स्थापित) कहा जाता है।

Meaning (English): When a person is no longer attached to sense objects or to actions, and has renounced all desires and mental resolutions, then such a person is said to have attained the state of Yoga.

This verse comes in the Dhyana Yoga (the Yoga of Meditation). Krishna explains what it means to be "yogārūḍha" — established in Yoga.

Freedom from attachment to sense-objects
Usually, our mind runs toward pleasures of the senses — food, wealth, comfort, recognition.
A yogi is one who does not get trapped in these cravings. He may interact with the world, but he is not enslaved by it.

Freedom from attachment to actions
Many people are attached to the results of their actions (success, failure, praise, blame).
A yogi performs duties sincerely, but with detachment. He doesn't identify himself with “I am the doer” or with the outcomes.

Renunciation of all desires (sankalpa)
Here, “sankalpa” means mental imaginations, desires, and plans rooted in ego or selfishness.
When one gives up such restless longings, the mind becomes steady.

The real meaning of Yoga
Yoga here is not just physical postures.
It is the union of the mind with the higher Self by transcending distractions of sense pleasure and ego-driven actions.
Thus, a yogi is not someone who has abandoned action, but someone who has transcended attachment and desire while performing action.

श्लोक 6.5

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

उद्धरेदात्मनाऽत्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत् ।
आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः ॥५॥

Meaning (Hindi): मनुष्य को अपने द्वारा स्वयं को ऊपर उठाना चाहिए, और स्वयं को अधोगति में नहीं डालना चाहिए। क्योंकि मनुष्य स्वयं अपना मित्र है और स्वयं अपना शत्रु है।

Meaning (English): A person must elevate himself by his own self and not degrade himself. For the self alone is one's own friend, and the self alone is one's own enemy.

This shloka emphasizes self-mastery and inner discipline.

“Uddharet Atmanātmānam” (Elevate yourself by yourself):
Krishna instructs that no external force is responsible for our spiritual progress.
Through discipline, right thinking, and self-control, one can raise oneself to higher levels of consciousness.
The greatest responsibility for growth lies within our own choices and actions.

“Na Atmanam avasādayet” (Do not degrade yourself):
Neglect, laziness, indulgence, and negative habits pull us downward.
By wrong actions, one becomes the cause of one's own downfall.

“Ātmaiva hi ātmanaḥ bandhuḥ” (Self is the friend of the self):
When the mind is disciplined, pure, and aligned with dharma, it helps in spiritual upliftment.
Such a controlled mind becomes a guide, protector, and friend.

“Ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ” (Self is the enemy of the self):
If uncontrolled, the same mind drags a person into attachment, greed, fear, and misery.
One becomes the enemy of one's own progress by succumbing to harmful desires and habits.
Essentially, the shloka conveys that our own mind is both the key to liberation and the cause of bondage.

श्लोक 6.6

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः ।
अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत् ॥६॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिसने अपने मन और इन्द्रियों को वश में कर लिया है, उसके लिए उसका मन ही उसका मित्र बन जाता है। परन्तु जिसने अपने मन को वश में नहीं किया है, उसके लिए वही मन उसका शत्रु के समान आचरण करता है।

Meaning (English): For one who has conquered the mind, the mind is the best friend. But for one who has failed to do so, the very same mind will act like the worst enemy.

This shloka is extremely practical and psychological in nature.

The Mind as a Friend:
When the mind is disciplined through practice (abhyasa) and detachment (vairagya), it supports spiritual progress.
A controlled mind brings peace, concentration, clarity, and allows a person to rise above distractions and temptations.
Such a mind becomes a true companion in the journey of self-realization and success in worldly duties too.

The Mind as an Enemy:
An uncontrolled mind pulls a person into desires, attachments, fears, anger, greed, and restlessness.
Instead of guiding us, it drags us toward downfall and suffering.
In this way, the same mind behaves like an enemy, creating internal conflict and sabotaging one's own progress.

Dual Nature of the Mind:
This verse emphasizes that the mind itself is neither inherently good nor bad.
It is neutral but takes the role of friend or enemy depending on how we handle it.
Just like fire can cook food or burn a house, the mind can either elevate us or destroy us.

Connection to Yoga:
In this chapter, Krishna is teaching about Dhyana Yoga (the yoga of meditation).
The first step in meditation is mastering the mind.
Without self-mastery, higher states of meditation are impossible.

श्लोक 6.7

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः ।
शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः ॥७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिसने अपने मन और इन्द्रियों को जीत लिया है, ऐसा शान्तचित्त साधक परमात्मा में स्थित रहता है। वह शीत-उष्ण, सुख-दुःख और मान-अपमान में समभाव रखता है।

Meaning (English): For one who has conquered the mind and is peaceful, the Supreme Self remains steadfastly realized. Such a yogi remains balanced in cold and heat, in pleasure and pain, and also in honor and dishonor.

This verse emphasizes the qualities of a true yogi (spiritual practitioner) who has gained mastery over the mind:

Jitātmanaḥ (One who has conquered the self)
Here, “ātman” refers to the mind and senses.
Conquering the mind doesn't mean suppressing it, but disciplining it, so that it doesn't drag one into restlessness and cravings.

Praśāntasya (of the peaceful one)
A mind that is calm, free from unnecessary agitation, desires, and anxiety.
Such a yogi naturally finds stillness, which leads to clarity and strength of character.

Paramātmā Samāhitaḥ (situated in the Supreme Self)
Once the inner turmoil is pacified, the person becomes established in awareness of the Supreme (God, universal consciousness).
This is the state of yoga - union with the Divine.

Equanimity in Dualities (heat-cold, pleasure-pain, honor-dishonor)
Life naturally comes with ups and downs.
A yogi does not become disturbed by favorable or unfavorable circumstances.
Instead of reacting, he remains steady like an anchor in a storm.

श्लोक 6.8

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

ज्ञाने विज్ఞान-तृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः ।
युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी सम-लोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः ॥८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिस योगी का आत्मा ज्ञान और विज्ञान से संतुष्ट है, जो स्थिरचित्त है, जिसने अपनी इन्द्रियों को जीत लिया है और जिसके लिए मिट्टी, पत्थर और सोना समान हैं, वह योगी कहा जाता है।

Meaning (English): A yogi who is content with knowledge and wisdom, who is steadfast and has conquered the senses, and to whom a lump of clay, a stone, and gold are alike—such a person is truly established in yoga.

This shloka highlights the qualities of a true yogi or spiritual seeker:

Content with Knowledge and Realization
Jñāna = theoretical knowledge of karma (actions).
Vijñāna = staying still and neutral in success and failure of one's actions (karma).
A yogi is satisfied not by material gains but by inner wisdom and realization.

Steadfast and Unshaken (Kūṭastha)
The word "Kūṭastha" implies something like an anvil that remains unmoved even when struck.
A yogi's mind remains steady and unaffected by ups and downs of life.

Master of the Senses (Vijitendriyaḥ)
The yogi does not allow the senses (sight, sound, taste, etc.) to control him.
Instead, he controls them, directing them toward higher pursuits.

Equanimity towards Matter (Samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanaḥ)
Lump of clay, a stone, or gold—all are the same to him.
This doesn't mean he cannot use them in the world, but emotionally he has no attachment or preference.
Wealth, status, or possessions do not define his happiness.
In essence, the verse defines the inner qualities of a perfected yogi—contentment, equanimity, sense-control, and detachment from material valuation.

श्लोक 6.9

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु ।
साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते ॥९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो योगी अपने सुहृद (भला चाहने वाले), मित्र, शत्रु, तटस्थ (निष्पक्ष व्यक्ति), मध्यस्थ (समझौता कराने वाले), द्वेषी, बन्धु, साधु और पापी — सब में समदृष्टि रखता है, वही श्रेष्ठ माना जाता है।

Meaning (English): That yogi is considered superior who views with equal mind a well-wisher, friend, enemy, neutral person, mediator, hater, relative, righteous person, and even a sinner.

This verse is central to Krishna's teaching on equanimity (samatva) in yoga.

Universal equality of vision
Krishna explains that a true yogi does not discriminate between people based on their external behavior or relationship with him.
Whether someone is friendly, hostile, neutral, or sinful — the yogi sees them all as souls (Ātman), which are inherently divine.

Why is this vision superior?
Because it transcends likes and dislikes, which are products of ego and attachment.
By rising above bias, the yogi attains steadiness of mind (sthita-prajñatā).
This mindset aligns with the Gita's broader theme of detachment and self-realization.

Not ignorance, but wisdom
Krishna doesn't mean the yogi can't recognize right from wrong, or good from evil.
Rather, he means that the yogi doesn't let personal prejudice, hatred, or attachment cloud his inner peace and judgment.
He treats every being as part of the same divine whole.

Spiritual maturity
To reach this state, one must go beyond emotional reactions, cultivate compassion, and develop inner strength.
Such a yogi becomes unshakable, peaceful, and compassionate even in the face of enmity or injustice.

श्लोक 6.10

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः ।
एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः ॥१०॥

Meaning (Hindi): योगी मन और आत्मा को संयमित करके, सदा एकांत स्थान में स्थित होकर, अकेले, बिना किसी वस्तु या संपत्ति के आश्रित हुए, और इच्छाओं से रहित होकर ध्यान करे।

Meaning (English): The yogi should constantly engage the mind in meditation, residing in a secluded place, alone, with controlled mind and body, free from desires, and without possession or dependence.

This shloka begins the practical instructions for meditation. In the earlier verses, Krishna explained the importance of yoga, discipline, and equanimity. Now, He describes how a yogi should live and practice:

Seclusion (rahasis sthitaḥ - residing in solitude):
A yogi should practice in a quiet, undisturbed place, free from distractions and worldly chaos. Solitude allows the mind to turn inward.

Aloneness (ekākī - alone):
Meditation is an inner journey. Though we may live socially, deep meditation requires being mentally alone, detached from external influences.

Self-discipline (yata-citta-ātmā - controlling the mind and body):
The yogi should discipline thoughts, senses, and actions. A restless mind cannot meditate.

Freedom from desire (nirāśīḥ):
Desires pull the mind outward. Freedom from material cravings allows inner stillness.

Non-possession (aparigrahaḥ - without possessions):
Not being attached to material belongings reduces anxiety, fear, and distraction. The yogi owns only what is necessary for living simply.

Constant practice (satatam - continuously):
Meditation is not a one-time activity but a consistent, disciplined lifestyle.
Essentially, this verse lays the foundation for a yogi's external and internal environment: solitude, discipline, simplicity, and detachment.

श्लोक 6.11

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य
स्थिरमासनमात्मनः ।
नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं
चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम् ॥११॥

Meaning (Hindi): भगवान श्रीकृष्ण कहते हैं: योगी को चाहिए कि वह किसी स्वच्छ (पवित्र) स्थान में, न बहुत ऊँचा और न बहुत नीचा आसन जमाकर बैठे। उस आसन पर कुशा, मृगचर्म और कपड़ा बिछा हो।

Meaning (English): Lord Krishna says: In a clean place, the yogi should establish a firm seat for himself, neither too high nor too low, and covered with sacred grass (kusa), a deer skin, and a cloth, one over the other.

This verse comes in the context of meditation and discipline for a yogi. Lord Krishna is describing how a yogi should prepare his place and posture for meditation.

"Shuchau deshe" - In a clean place
Cleanliness is emphasized because the external environment influences the internal state of mind. A pure, sattvic environment fosters concentration and mental calmness.

"Sthiram asanam aatmanah" - A steady seat
The yogi should sit on a stable seat to maintain physical balance and avoid distractions. Stability of the body leads to stability of the mind.

"Na atyuchchritam na atinicham" - Neither too high nor too low
Balance is essential in every aspect of yoga. Extremes should be avoided. If it is too high, then there is a chance of falling and getting hurt. If it is too low, then insects, ants, may crawle up and bite causing a disturbance in meditation. This also symbolizes avoiding pride (too high) and depression or lethargy (too low).

"Chaila-ajina-kusha-uttaram" - Grass, deer skin, cloth arrangement
Traditionally, kusa grass represents purity and protection, deer skin symbolizes steadiness and detachment, and cloth provides comfort. It shows that the yogi must prepare both physically and mentally for meditation.

श्लोक 6.12

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा
यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः ।
उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्
योगमात्मविशुद्धये ॥१२॥

Meaning (Hindi): उस आसन पर बैठकर, मन को एकाग्र करके और चित्त तथा इन्द्रियों की क्रियाओं को संयमित करके, साधक अपने अन्तःकरण की शुद्धि के लिये योग का अभ्यास करे।

Meaning (English): Sitting on that seat, making the mind one-pointed, controlling the activities of the mind and senses, the yogi should practice yoga for the purification of the inner self.

This shloka comes in the context of Krishna explaining how a yogi should meditate. In the earlier verses, Krishna described the seat (āsana) arrangement—firm, clean, not too high or too low, covered with kusa grass, deer skin, and cloth. Now, he tells us what to do after sitting on it.

Ekāgram manah (One-pointed mind)
The mind must be focused, not scattered. A distracted mind prevents deep meditation.

Yatacitta-indriya-kriyah (Control over mind and senses)
Sense organs must be disciplined; otherwise, they keep pulling attention outward.
Yoga requires withdrawal from distractions to move inward.

Ātma-viśuddhaye (For the purification of self)
The purpose of this meditation is not material gain but purification of consciousness.
This means removing impurities like desires, attachments, ego, anger, jealousy, and restlessness.
Once purified, the self naturally experiences peace and connection with the Divine.
Thus, Krishna is emphasizing that yoga is not a physical posture alone—it is a disciplined state of mind, sense-control, and purity of intention.

श्लोक 6.13

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः ।
सम्प्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन् ॥१३॥

Meaning (Hindi): योगी अपने शरीर, सिर और गले को सीधा और स्थिर रखे। वह अपनी दृष्टि नासिका के अग्र भाग (नाक की नोक) पर स्थिर करे और इधर-उधर किसी भी दिशा में दृष्टि न डाले।

Meaning (English): The yogi should hold the body, head, and neck erect, steady, and firm, gazing steadily at the tip of the nose, without looking around in any other direction.

This verse is part of Dhyana Yoga (the Yoga of Meditation), where Krishna is guiding Arjuna on the practical posture and discipline of meditation.

"Samam kāya-śiro-grīvam" → The body, head, and neck should be in one straight line. This symbolizes balance and alignment, not just physically but mentally and spiritually.

"Dhārayan nacalaṁ sthiraḥ" → They must be held firm and steady, representing stability and control over restlessness.

"Samprekṣya nāsikāgraṁ" → Gaze should be fixed at the tip of the nose. This is not about straining the eyes but about concentrating attention inward, reducing distractions.

"Diśaś cānavalokayan" → The yogi should not glance around here and there. This implies detachment from external distractions and focus on the inner self.
So, this shloka emphasizes the discipline of posture and concentration in meditation. Physical stillness supports mental stillness.

श्लोक 6.14

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्भ्रमचरिव्रते स्थितः ।
मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः ॥१४॥

Meaning (Hindi): प्रशांत आत्मा (शांत मन वाला), भय रहित, ब्रह्मचर्य व्रत में स्थित, मन को संयमित कर, मुझमें चित्त को लगाए हुए, मन को मेरे परायण बनाकर योगी ध्यान में स्थित हो।

Meaning (English): With a peaceful mind, free from fear, firmly established in the vow of celibacy (discipline of self-control), controlling the mind, focusing the consciousness on Me (the Supreme), and regarding Me as the supreme goal, the yogi should sit steadfastly in meditation.

This verse explains the inner state of a yogi who practices meditation (dhyana yoga).

Prashanta Atma (Peaceful mind) -
The yogi's inner self is calm, not disturbed by worldly desires or agitation. Peace is the foundation of meditation.

Vigata-bhīḥ (Fearless) -
Fear arises from attachment and duality. When one sees the self as eternal (Atman), fear of loss or death disappears. A yogi meditates without anxiety.

Brahmachārī-vrate sthitaḥ (Established in celibacy / discipline) -
Brahmacharya here does not only mean celibacy in the physical sense, but also self-restraint, control over senses, and a life of moderation. The yogi conserves energy for spiritual growth.

Manaḥ saṁyamya (Controlling the mind) -
The restless mind must be trained to withdraw from distractions and focus inward.

Mac-cittaḥ (Mind fixed on Me) -
The yogi focuses on Krishna (the Supreme Reality). This gives direction to meditation; otherwise, the mind wanders.

Mat-paraḥ (Seeing Me as the Supreme Goal) -
The yogi does not meditate for powers, pleasures, or personal gain, but solely for union with the Divine. The purpose of yoga is God-realization.

श्लोक 6.15

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

युञ्जन्नेवं सदा आत्मानं योगी नियतमानसः ।
शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति ॥१५॥

Meaning (Hindi): इस प्रकार निरंतर अपने मन को मुझमें लगाकर, संयमित मन वाला योगी परम निर्वाण रूप शांति को प्राप्त करता है, जो मुझमें स्थित है।

Meaning (English): Thus, constantly engaging his mind in meditation on Me, the disciplined yogi attains supreme peace—Nirvana—which abides in Me.

In this verse, Lord Krishna concludes His detailed guidance on meditation (Dhyana Yoga). The essence here is attaining oneness with the Divine through continuous, disciplined meditation.

“Yuñjann evaṁ sadātmānam” — Constantly engaging the mind in Yoga
Krishna emphasizes constancy. Meditation is not a one-time act but a continuous inner connection. The yogi must remain mentally united with the Divine, whether sitting in meditation or living daily life.

“Yogī niyatamānasaḥ” — The yogi with controlled mind
The mind is naturally restless. But through practice (abhyāsa) and detachment (vairāgya), the yogi learns to discipline the mind. Such mastery allows one to direct thoughts toward higher consciousness rather than worldly distractions.

“Śāntiṁ nirvāṇa-paramāṁ” — Attains supreme peace (Nirvana)
The result of deep meditation is not ordinary peace, but Nirvana, the peace beyond all dualities—beyond pleasure and pain, success and failure. It is the extinction of the ego and the realization of the Self's unity with the Supreme.

“Mat-saṁsthām adhigacchati” — Established in Me
Krishna says this peace dwells in Me. It means the yogi's consciousness merges into the Divine consciousness. This is the state of God-realization — when one experiences that the individual self (Atman) and the Supreme (Paramatman) are one.

श्लोक 6.16

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः ।
न चाति स्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन ॥१६॥

Meaning (Hindi): हे अर्जुन! जो न तो बहुत अधिक खाता है और न ही बिल्कुल नहीं खाता, जो न तो बहुत अधिक सोता है और न ही हमेशा जागता रहता है — ऐसे व्यक्ति के लिए योग (ध्यान) सफल नहीं हो सकता।

Meaning (English): O Arjuna, there is no possibility of becoming a yogi for one who eats too much, or who eats too little, who sleeps too much, or who sleeps too little.

This verse comes from the Dhyāna Yoga (Yoga of Meditation) chapter, where Lord Krishna teaches Arjuna about the discipline required for meditation and spiritual practice.

Here, Krishna emphasizes moderation — a balanced lifestyle is essential for success in yoga and self-realization. The verse points out four aspects that affect one's ability to meditate or practice yoga sincerely:

Food (Āhāra) — Overeating makes the body heavy and the mind dull, while fasting excessively weakens the body and distracts the mind. Both extremes disturb mental balance. The ideal is mitāhāra — balanced and mindful eating.

Sleep (Nidrā) — Oversleeping leads to laziness and mental inertia; undersleeping causes restlessness and fatigue. The ideal is samyak-nidrā — enough rest to refresh the body and mind.

Activity and Rest (Vyavahāra & Viśrāma) — Similarly, one should neither overexert nor be inactive. Too much activity scatters the mind, while too much inactivity leads to stagnation.

Mind Discipline — The verse subtly indicates that yoga is not just about meditation postures, but about mastering body, habits, and mind so that one can reach inner steadiness.
In short — Yoga succeeds in balance, not in extremes. Spiritual growth is sustainable only when the body and mind are in harmony.

श्लोक 6.17

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु ।
युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा ॥१७॥

Meaning (Hindi): जो व्यक्ति अपने भोजन-आदतों और विश्राम / विहार में संयमित है, जो अपने कर्मों में युक्तचित्त प्रयास करता है, जो अपने सोने-उठने में संतुलन रखता है — उसके लिए योग दुःखों का नाशक बनता है।

Meaning (English): He who is regulated in his eating and recreation, balanced in his work, and regulated in sleep and waking, yoga becomes the destroyer of all suffering for him.

In this shloka, Lord Krishna explains the importance of balance and moderation in life as a prerequisite for successful yoga (union of the self with the Divine).

“Yuktāhāra-vihārasya” - one who eats and enjoys moderately:
Krishna emphasizes that self-discipline doesn't mean self-denial. Neither overindulgence nor starvation helps in attaining peace. Proper nourishment is vital for both body and mind to function in harmony.

“Yuktacestasya karmasu” - one who acts with measured effort:
All actions must be performed with balanced energy — neither laziness nor overexertion. Too much attachment to results causes stress; too little effort leads to stagnation. The yogi maintains steadfast effort with detachment.

“Yuktasvapnāvabodhasya” - one who is balanced in sleep and wakefulness:
Oversleeping breeds inertia; lack of sleep causes restlessness. Krishna teaches the value of rhythmic living — a state where both rest and activity are aligned with one's inner balance.

“Yogo bhavati duḥkhahā” - such a yoga destroys sorrow:
When life is lived in moderation and harmony, one's body, mind, and soul become aligned. This inner equilibrium destroys sorrow because one is no longer tormented by extremes — neither pleasure nor pain can disturb such a mind.

Thus, Krishna declares that discipline and moderation are not restrictions but the path to true freedom and lasting happiness.

श्लोक 6.18

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते ।
निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा ॥१८॥

Meaning (Hindi): जब मन पूरी तरह से नियंत्रित होकर आत्मा में ही स्थिर हो जाता है, और सभी भोगों की कामनाओं से रहित हो जाता है, तब वह योगी कहा जाता है जो योग में स्थित है।

Meaning (English): When the controlled mind rests in the Self alone, free from craving for all material desires, then one is said to be steadfast in Yoga — truly united with the Divine.

This shloka comes in the context of Dhyana Yoga (The Yoga of Meditation), where Lord Krishna explains the state of true meditation and self-realization.

"Yadā viniyataṁ cittam" — When the mind is well controlled.
Krishna refers to a disciplined, calm, and purified mind — one that is not wandering toward desires or distractions.
Such control is not forced suppression but a result of inner clarity and understanding.

"Ātmany eva avatiṣṭhate" — And rests in the Self alone.
The mind, instead of chasing outer objects, becomes absorbed in the inner Self (Atman).
This is the state of self-awareness and inner contentment, where the seeker realizes that lasting peace exists within, not outside.

"Niḥspṛhaḥ sarva-kāmebhyo" — Free from longing for all desires.
“Niḥspṛhaḥ” means without any craving, without attachment.
Desires don't vanish magically, but the yogi transcends them through understanding their impermanence and futility.
The mind no longer depends on sense pleasures for happiness.

"Yukta ity ucyate tadā" — Then he is said to be truly united (in Yoga).
“Yukta” literally means “connected” or “united.”
Such a person is truly in union with the Divine (Brahman) — the ultimate goal of Yoga.
This is not merely sitting in meditation; it's a living state of inner balance and divine connection.

श्लोक 6.19

श्रीभगवानुवाच।

यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता ।
योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगम् आत्मनः ॥१९॥

Meaning (Hindi): जिस प्रकार एक दीपक हवा (पवन) रहित स्थान में लड़खड़ाता नहीं है, उसी प्रकार वह योगी, जिसका चित्त संयत हो और जो आत्मा पर योग करता है, अडिग रहता है।

Meaning (English): As a lamp in a windless place does not flicker, so the disciplined mind of a yogi remains steady in meditation upon the Self (or the Supreme).

This verse is one of the classical and beautiful comparisons (upamā) that Krishna uses to help us grasp how an ideal meditator's mind should behave.

The Analogy (Lamp in Windless Place):
A lamp's flame, when exposed to wind or drafts, flickers, sways, becomes unstable, perhaps even extinguished.
But if that same lamp is placed in a calm, windless place, the flame becomes steady, unwavering.
This is used as a metaphor for the mind: in ordinary life, thoughts, senses, distractions, desires — these are like gusts of wind — they disturb the mind.
But when external “winds” of desire, restlessness, sense-attraction are minimized, the mind can remain calm, stable, centred.

“Yogino yata-cittasya” — of the yogi whose mind is controlled:
This points to someone who has disciplined the mind through practice (abhyāsa), self-control, withdrawal from overstimulation, etc.
To “control the mind” doesn't mean forcefully suppressing it, but bringing it under the discipline of wisdom, concentration, and detachment.

“Yunjato yogam ātmanaḥ” — who applies or engages in yoga upon the Self:
Here “yoga” means meditative union or absorption in the Self (ātman) or the Supreme, depending on one's understanding or path.
The mind is turned inward, focused, oriented toward the inner reality, rather than being scattered outside.
The yogi is not distracted by transient impressions but holds steady on the inner light.

Steadiness and inner stability:
The core idea: when the mind becomes steady, it does not waver with every thought, every external stimulus. It remains focused.
That steadiness is considered a sign of advanced meditation or inner maturity.

Relation to preceding verses:
In verses like 6.17 and 6.18 Krishna sets up the conditions: moderation, withdrawal of desires, control of mental fluctuations.
Verse 19 then gives the ideal image — what to aim for: a mind unwavering like a lamp in a calm environment.
So shloka 19 acts as both encouragement and goalpost.

Practical aspect:
The verse teaches that inner calm is not spontaneous in ordinary conditions — one must remove or shield from “winds” (desires, distractions, restless thinking).
A steady mind is not a passive blankness, but a dynamic clarity, like a flame that illuminates steadily without swaying.
In essence, this verse gives us a vivid picture — if you can cultivate an inner environment (psychologically) free from constant disturbances, your mind can remain stable, conscious, alert, and focused.
